PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and The Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

``We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself''.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
- gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
- gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
- fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
- could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
- request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said ``The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution-``Relying on the Blessings of Almighty God . . .''
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
1. The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem-``God Bless Australia'' to the tune of ``Waltzing Matilda''.
2. The adoption of a Christian National Motto-``One Nation Under God'', for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3. The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4. The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5. The retention of ``God Save the Queen'' for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6. The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7. Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
. . . request the Australian Government-to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
- the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
- the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
- the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Video Cassettes
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, having great concern over the effect that increasing availability of pornographic material is having in hastening the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to:

1. Dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's guidelines for classification of video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which obtain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc. or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
2. Resist moves to have Federal Funds granted to subsidise the production and export of X-rated videos; and
3. Implement the decision of all State Attorneys-General to have the distribution of X-rated videos from the Australian Capital Territory outlawed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children, from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself. We urge you to rescind the decision.
2. We urge you to request the AWM Council to reverse their decision.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on the Australian War Memorial to rescind their decision to charge an entrance fee.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Charges and Savings Account Interest
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Retired Citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. Charging for prescriptions is causing hardship particularly to the people on more than one medication and also those with chronic illnesses.
2. Proposals to assess all retired peoples' savings above $2000 as receiving 10% interest is punitive, oppressive and discriminative.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled urge the Government to stop the charge for Pensioners prescriptions and scrap the proposals to assess savings at 10% interest.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ambassador to Ireland and Holy See
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable, the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recall Australia's Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, (Mr Brian Burke) and suspend his appointment while matters of propriety relating to his actions as Premier and subsequently which have been referred to the Minister are investigated, and moreover during the term of the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.
And your petitions as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee earlier this year considered the first set of regulations made under this Act and detected a number of apparent deficiencies. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, the Hon. Peter Staples, MP, then helpfully undertook to amend the regulations to meet the concerns of the Committee. However, the regulations were subsequently disallowed by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The present regulations are therefore the second set of principal regulations made this year under the Therapeutic Goods Act. These present regulations include almost all the considerable changes suggested by the Committee. The Committee is grateful to the Minister for his cooperation. Nevertheless, there is one undertaking which does not appear to be included. This was to limit the power of delegation of the Secretary to waive or reduce fees to senior executive officers of the Department. At present this power may inappropriately be delegated to any officer of the Department, no matter how junior.

On behalf of the Committee I shall write to the Minister seeking clarification. Owing to the efforts of the Committee any adverse exercise of the discretion in respect of fees is now subject to Administrative Appeals Tribunal review. However, there is still the apparent problem of junior officers having the power to waive unlimited amounts of Commonwealth revenue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Insurance Amendment Bill contains amendments to section 37 of the Insurance Act 1973. These amendments are of a straightforward and noncontentious nature, and are required to avoid potential difficulties which may arise as a consequence of the monetary limit currently specified in that section.

Section 37 of the Insurance Act provides that insurers whose activities are confined to conducting insurance business with limited classes of persons (generally only members or employees of a company or a particular trade, industry or profession) and whose annual premiums do not exceed $500,000 may be exempted from certain provisions of the Act. Such exemptions are principally concerned with a reduced statutory reporting requirement and, consequently, less resources are required by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to supervise these companies.

The specified limit on annual premiums was increased to $500,000 with effect from 19 January 1984. Since then, the real value of this amount has been gradually eroded to the extent that one of the insurers operating with a restricted authority under section 37 may shortly exceed the limit. Accordingly, this amendment proposes an increase in the limit on annual premiums these insurers may receive, from $500,000 to $750,000. The exemption granted to the insurer currently approaching the limit is due for review at the end of this year, and passage of the amendment will enable the Treasurer to give consideration to granting a further exemption.

To facilitate further routine adjustments that may need to be effected to this limit, the Bill also provides that any future increases in the limit on annual premiums specified in section 37 may be effected by regulation.
Financial Impact
The amendments to the Insurance Act will result in minor indirect administrative savings. There will be no increased costs to the Commonwealth.
I commend the Insurance Amendment Bill 1990 to the Senate, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian War Memorial Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 448 and made under the Australian War Memorial Act 1980, be disallowed.

The Opposition has taken the decision to oppose the Government regulations which allow for an entry fee to be levied at the Australian War Memorial as a matter of principle. I notice that in the House of Representatives yesterday it was suggested that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was rolled by the Party room on this issue. Let me make it quite clear: the Leader led discussion on the issue in the shadow Ministry on Monday, after which a recommendation to oppose the fees was made to the Party meeting on Tuesday. This was wholeheartedly endorsed and let that be the end of the matter.

The concerns that the Opposition has had with respect to the introduction of entry fees at the Memorial have been on the public record for some time. I would like to remind honourable senators of a speech I made in this chamber on 17 December. It is worth re-examining this speech. For instance, at the time I said:

The decision that was announced . . . to charge for admission gives the Opposition some major concerns. We accept generally the principle of user pays. But in this case there are very real concerns that we are turning something which is a memorial to our dead into just another museum.
I also said:

I urge the Memorial Council to think again. It has no guarantee of funding. It is not giving proper access to the men and women who have fought for this country or the people who have given to the Memorial.
A few days later I sent a copy of that speech to the Chairman of the Memorial. The disallowance motion being debated here today should therefore come as no surprise.

Since the decision of the Memorial Council regarding fees was announced publicly on 23 November, I have had ongoing correspondence with the Chairman of the War Memorial Council, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire. The information received from Dame Beryl has been most unsatisfactory in my view. Dame Beryl had indicated that approximately $1m was expected to be raised each year as a result of the introduction of an entry fee. She failed to make clear whether this was gross or net income.

In a letter sent to Dr Hewson in the first week of February, Dame Beryl indicated that the admission charges would generate $750,000. In just two months, therefore, projected income had declined by a quarter of a million dollars. Once again, there was no indication as to whether this referred to gross or net income.

In a letter I received dated 17 January, Dame Beryl suggested that there had been no discernible difference in the number of people visiting the Memorial in the first two weeks of January. However, sources from within the Memorial have suggested that visitor numbers have in fact fallen quite substantially.

It has been reported to me that in the first two weeks of 1990, approximately 59,000 visitors passed through the Memorial. In the first two weeks of this year this figure dropped to 44,000. This represents a downturn of approximately 25 per cent. Of course, interpretation of the downturn must be cautious. With no internal validity, it is difficult to say clearly what has caused this downturn. For instance, current economic conditions almost certainly have had some impact on tourist numbers. In reality, it is likely that a combination of factors is responsible for the decline, of which the introduction of a fee would be one.

Of the 44,000 people who visited in that first couple of weeks, I am informed that numbers of people visited the commemorative wall in the centre of the Memorial and then turn on their heel and left rather than go into the galleries. Nevertheless, it can unequivocally be said that the net revenue from these fees would not have been large nor, indeed, even able to be forecast with any certainty.

The War Memorial says that it has so far raised $90,000. This has occurred in the first six weeks of 1991 which, I remind the Senate, is the peak tourist period of the year. On this basis it could achieve a net revenue of $750,000 over a full year. But quite clearly, it is most unlikely. Anybody in the tourist industry who tried to undertake projections of revenue based on the best period of the year would be destined to go out of business pretty smartly.

Also of concern to the Opposition has been the somewhat haphazard and inconsistent implementation of the fees. Ex- service organisations from around the country have expressed their disappointment at the new arrangements which mean that a veteran is required to pay for a visit to an institution whose role it is to commemorate those who have fought and died for our country. I am sure honourable senators would also have received letters from people who have said that veterans of Australia have paid for this Memorial in their blood and in their sacrifice; widows have paid in the loss of their loved ones- does it have to be paid for again?

Dame Beryl has claimed that those who have donated valuable personal effects and memorabilia-unlike veterans-are admitted free. It is not made clear by Dame Beryl how the word `valuable' should be interpreted. Many people have given items of sentimental value of a highly personal nature. Apparently it is intended that they should queue up to explain their status to possibly gain free entry. Students under 25 automatically receive free entry, yet the men and women who fought for this country are not entitled to that. They have to queue up to claim their status in order to get concessional entry. There is also no clear way of determining who is a veteran. In fact, the question of whether someone is a veteran has been determined by the honour system.

As I said in my speech in the Senate on 17 December, we generally accept the principle of user pay. Particularly in times of fiscal restraint, every dollar of expenditure must be scrutinised, although individual claims must necessarily be assessed on their merits. The real issue here is not about potential revenue gains, whatever they may turn out to be, but what the War Memorial signifies and how our national objectives can best be served. It is in this context that we believe that the introduction of an entry fee to the Memorial runs counter to the ideals that inspire it.

I think it was Senator McLean who this week described the decision as crass. I am not sure whether I am quoting him accurately, but, certainly, his sentiments were to that effect. He expressed it with very strong feeling, which I support. The War Memorial is a national institution of deep symbolic value to the Australian people and I hope and expect that it will remain so for generations to come. We would not want any Australian to be deterred or prevented from visiting the Memorial because of the existence of a fee. If additional funds are needed to help with the Memorial then there are other options which we urge the Government and the Council to consider and to discuss with the Opposition.

For example, consideration could be given to the introduction of admission fees at separate museum annexes such as the proposed technology pavilion, for which the Government has already provided the first $5m. Also, it may be that fees could be charged for tourist buses or the use of guides. A levy could be collected from those wishing to use the Memorial's car parking facilities. All of those are acceptable ways of raising additional revenue. Revenue savings may also be possible in the area of administration. I have received information from a variety of sources which suggests that the Memorial Council should be looking at improving its management practices. We urge the Council, particularly at a time when expenditure restraint is called for, to re-examine its own management practices to eliminate possible areas of waste and duplication.

I understand that the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Tate, will be proposing to the Senate that the question of fees should be referred to a Senate committee for investigation. I can see this only as a delaying tactic. If the purpose of that is to enable the War Memorial to explain its position, then it is unnecessary because the Chairman of the Council, in correspondence with me over the last two months, has quite clearly attempted to justify the decision. She has also written to newspapers explaining the basis of the Council's decision. If any further explanations were needed, it was always open to the War Memorial Council Director or Chairman to seek an appointment with me as the relevant shadow Minister. They made no attempt to do so and all communications have been on my initiative.

In one of her letters to me, Dame Beryl claimed that the question of charging admission to the Memorial has been on the agenda of Memorial boards and councils since the early 1920s. She also said that the issue has been freely debated without any automatic or clear cut decision one way or the other. Information available to me suggests that this is not entirely accurate and that on a number of occasions over the last 15 years, whenever the question of charges was discussed, a firm decision was taken to reject the proposal, and rightly so.

As I have already said, the Opposition is happy to consult with the War Memorial on any alternative proposals for raising revenue, but a committee is not the solution. Dame Beryl has expressed, in correspondence with me, that all political parties are supportive of the need to maintain funding at current levels. She has also said that the funds raised by the entry fee were to help with the acquisition, preservation, exhibition, education and public access programs. She also explained that the Memorial had been seeking and obtaining private sector sponsorship of projects. That is an important avenue of support which needs to be fully utilised. I believe much more can be done in that area.

Getting back to basics, it is absolutely vital that the Parliament speak clearly, once and for all, on the issue of fees at the Australian War Memorial. We reject them utterly. That has to be the message we give by our decision here today. Any proposal for a committee simply clouds the issue.

In summary, the Opposition is opposed to the imposition of an entry fee at the Australian War Memorial because we believe that the Memorial is a national institution of deep symbolic value for the Australian people and should remain so for the generations of Australians who will follow. This disallowance motion recognises the importance of these sentiments. Therefore, I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Government to oppose this disallowance motion and I do so while speaking as the Minister in this chamber representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Ben Humphreys. We are not talking about a decision of government; it is a decision of the distinguished Council of the Australian War Memorial. I believe that needs some emphasis and it would explain some of the course of action which has been alluded to by Senator Newman, although I have, after consultation with the Australian Democrats through Senator Paul McLean, modified the proposal I spoke to Senator Newman about just before coming into the chamber. I think the Clerk has arranged for my foreshadowed motion to be circulated to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that the Council is a body of distinguished persons, appointed for the contributions they make to the furtherance of the Memorial's objectives. We know that they are distinguished war veterans, persons with service histories, the current chiefs of the defence forces and former junior Legatees. We are talking about a council which has come to a unanimous decision that in order to supplement the funds available for the War Memorial and its activities an entrance fee should be levied in respect of certain areas of the War Memorial complex. That needs more emphasis.

The fact is that the formal commemorative areas such as the Roll of Honour, the courtyard, the cloisters, the Hall of Memory, all those areas which have a sacred aura and are dedicated in a special way to the memory of those who have fallen in the service of Australia in the various armed forces, have been designated as free, and quite rightly so. All Australians and all overseas visitors can spend some meditative time in those more sacred areas of the Memorial, without having to pay some fee, in order to reflect upon the supreme sacrifice of those who are honoured in those particular areas.

On the major commemorative days, Anzac Day and Remembrance Day, all people would be entitled to enter any area of the War Memorial free of charge. Again, children and students would be entitled to enter any part of the Memorial free of charge because of its educative value. The formation of values and the providing of the history of Australia's commitment to various armed conflicts, all of these matters so essential for the better understanding by younger generations of Australians of our history, led the Council of the Australian War Memorial to decide that youngsters ought to be able to enter the War Memorial free of charge.

We are talking about the levying of the fee in respect of areas of exhibits which do not have that particularly sacred aura, if you like, and then only in respect of adults visiting those particular exhibits. As I understand Senator Newman, she was proposing that some annexes be able to be visited on the payment of a fee. So she, herself, does not preclude the possibility of fees being charged in respect of the visit to some areas of the War Memorial in the future.

Also, we ought to emphasise that it was the Opposition, when in government in 1980 and when Mr Ellicott was the Minister for Home Affairs, which introduced the provision in the Australian War Memorial Act 1980, section 42, which permits the fixing of charges for entry on to any land or into any building owned by or under control of the Australian War Memorial. So it was the Liberal-National Party coalition Government in 1980 which thought that the Parliament ought to provide for the possibility of the Council coming to the decision which it did last year. In other words, it was the present Opposition when in government which persuaded the Parliament to make this particular enabling provision. The Council of the War Memorial had every reason to think that it was fulfilling a function which had been conferred on it by the Liberal and National parties when in government. Therefore, I guess Council members were totally astonished at the reaction, which was manufactured by Senator Newman, amongst others, when the fee was actually levied.

The assurances that backed up that general expectation of support from the Opposition parties, which have been referred to in the press recently, I believe, were considerations which swayed the Council so that a unanimous decision was taken by members of that Council only on the basis-as they understood it and as conveyed to them by their distinguished chairperson, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire-that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) had signified their support for the levying of that particular fee. It was only on that basis that the unanimous decision of the Council was forthcoming.
I do not believe that the Opposition has acted as honourably as it should have in this regard--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not suggesting they are acting dishonestly, are you?
—The Council of the Memorial was lulled, let us put it that way, into a false sense of security in thinking that the Opposition was supportive of the levying of this particular fee.
—No way. I have just explained that that is not true at all. Aren't you prepared to listen when I speak?

—Senator Newman speaks of the moneys that might be received from admission charges. It is true that there has been some decline in the amounts that have been received, and it is not clear precisely what has led to that shortfall in expectations. Except for generally speaking, of course, the fact is that with the decline in the tourist trade experienced throughout Australia in this time of depressed economic activity, certain expectations as to the numbers of tourists passing through Canberra, and particularly the War Memorial, have not been fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I believe that a considerable amount of money might have been expected to be raised by this particular charge fee and now it will not be available for the Council of the War Memorial to undertake the tasks which it considered to be important.

What had been intended, of course, was that the War Memorial would be able to apply the moneys to securing and preserving for many years the materials and the artefacts that are our military history and heritage, including famous national relics, such as the Gallipoli landing boats that are seen only rarely. These are the materials and artefacts which are the essential foundations of the Memorial's programs to educate younger generations of Australians about the impact of war on our people and our nation.

I believe that the Australian War Memorial Council took a very difficult decision, but a very justifiable decision, in determining that this supplement to its funds was an essential part of building up sufficient moneys to enable it to maintain the finest possible tribute to the nation's war debt and the sacrifices of our service men and women. It may be that my advocacy is not adequate to the task, and that is why I thought it would be useful for the Senate to have the benefit of a short discussion before a relevant Senate committee of the issues involved relating to this particular regime of charging proposed by the Council of the Australian War Memorial.

I have tried to outline my understanding of the Council's decision, but I may not have done justice to its cause. I would be distressed personally if it felt that I had not sufficiently canvassed the considerations which led to its decision. I think that the course of its deliberations perhaps could be usefully outlined to the Senate through the services of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

I believe that the Democrats have indicated that they want the passage of the disallowance motion to go ahead. They want the regulations to be disallowed today rather than have the regulations referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which was the original suggestion I put to Senator Newman earlier this morning.

In light of the decision by the Democrats not to support the referral of the regulation to the Committee, I will be seeking leave, after the disallowance has been achieved, to move a motion in the terms that have been circulated; namely, to allow the issues arising from the making of the regulations to be referred to the Committee. I think that this will give the Senate an opportunity to be better apprised of the considerations which led to the deliberations of the Council and the way that led to its conclusion and its decision.

It may also give the Australian War Memorial an opportunity to understand better the mood of the Senate in relation to this matter and what might be acceptable. I found it astonishing that Senator Newman, for example, should say in her rhetorical flourish at the end that the Parliament needs to speak clearly. Of any proposal to charge fees, she said, `We reject them utterly'. Yet, as I understand it, Senator Newman has circulated a press release which, amongst other things, says that she would approve or be prepared to support a fee being paid by tourist buses, for example, which, of course, the operators would then pass on to the passengers, to those tourists who visit the War Memorial. In fact, it would end up being a per head fee on those tourists who happen to visit the Memorial via the services of a tourist bus operator rather than perhaps in a hire car or by private transport.

So some tourists would end up paying a fee under Senator Newman's proposal. What is more, it would be a fee which would be in relation to their visit to the whole of the War Memorial and not simply in relation to the annexes showing various exhibits, which is what the War Memorial Council intends by its particular proposal excluding, as I say, any fee for visiting the more sacred areas: the Roll of Honour, the courtyard and so on. I believe that this particular ambiguity or lack of clarity in the Opposition's position in relation to the levying of fees for visits to the War Memorial is a matter which could also be usefully looked at in a short inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I will be recommending that to the Senate when the regulation is disallowed, as it apparently will be shortly.

I do believe that we have a situation where a most distinguished body of Australians has deliberated on this matter and come to a unanimous decision that a fee ought to be levied for entrance to certain exhibition galleries of the Australian War Memorial. I believe they were very sensitive indeed to the claims that the areas which are those for more meditative moments-as we honour the dead and commemorate the sacrifices of those who have served Australia in the armed forces-should be preserved for free access. But they have made decisions which would enable the Council of the War Memorial to further the other major task of the Memorial; that is, to exhibit the memorabilia and the artefacts which have been gathered so painstakingly and which ought to be displayed in a fitting manner as a tribute to the service of Australians overseas and as an educative part of the formation, particularly, of generations of younger Australians.

I wish to commend the regulations to the Senate. I believe that they ought be allowed to stand. I believe that, in doing so, we would be doing the right thing by the Memorial and, in particular, we would be passing a vote of confidence in the integrity and the care with which the members of the Council have undertaken their very onerous statutory duties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats, obviously, to support the disallowance of these regulations that would impose an entrance fee at the Australian War Memorial. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that, from the very moment that this proposal became public, the Australian Democrats expressed their opposition to it. Indeed, as Senator Newman has said, I described it as crass commercialism of the worst kind.

SPEECH.PARA: We stated our position as being quite simple in principle-that taxpayers fund wars and we believe that taxpayers should fund the memorial to those who paid the ultimate sacrifice in those wars. We were disheartened to find that the Opposition was reluctant to support that position initially. We know, and are grateful for the fact, that finally that support has been forthcoming after intense lobbying from the veterans community. I know that that lobbying has been intense because they have lobbied me intensely and, in doing so, have explained to me that they have had intense negotiations with both the Council and with members of the Opposition.

I also know that Senator Newman's commitment to her position was a real one and a very early one. Unfortunately, she did not win the support of her party room immediately, nor did she win the support of her Leader immediately. I have it on good information that it was not an easy cause to be won on the Opposition side. I can understand that because the Opposition supports privatisation as an essential principle and it must have found some conflict in terms of its fundamental philosophical position about privatisation and this suggestion of crass commercialism in relation to the Australian War Memorial.

I will not take long in making my remarks, Madam Acting Deputy President. I accept the acknowledgment of the fact by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) that the War Memorial Council is indeed a group of very distinguished Australians-very distinguished indeed. There is no denying that. But even a distinguished group of Australians unanimously can arrive at a bad decision. I believe it was a lack of their consultation with the veterans community which led them into this bad decision, because the reaction within that community has been very strong indeed. They have found the suggestion of commercialising the War Memorial as utterly unacceptable and they have reacted strongly.

I think they were even more deeply offended by the fact that Dame Beryl Beaurepaire actually described some of the distinguished members of the veterans community as `fanatics' in expressing that resentment. I think that decision was unfortunate, and the manner and the words with which an attempt was made to justify it were equally unfortunate. I quote from one of those `fanatics', Major General John Whitelaw, who wrote a superb letter to the Canberra Times on 3 February. I would like to read that letter to the Senate because I think it expresses superbly the feelings of the veterans community. It is under the heading of `A tomb most glorious'; it was received on 29 January and published on 3 February. The letter is over the signature of Major General John Whitelaw, Red Hill, and it reads as follows:

Sparked by controversy about the charges now being levied for entrance to the Australian War Memorial, I consulted my copy of the Guide to the Australian War Memorial (2nd Edition, June 1942). The first edition of this handsome little work was produced for the opening, in 1941.
I was taken with the quotation on the front piece:

``They gave their lives. For that public gift they received a praise which never ages and a tomb most glorious-not so much the tomb in which they lie, but that in which their fame survives, to be remembered forever when occasion comes for word or deed . . . ''

Also I was impressed by the two opening paragraphs, which show with absolute clarity the nature of the AWM as a shrine in toto: in a spiritual sense the many elements of the AWM and its environs are indivisible. Read them:

``The Memorial to the Australians who died in the two Great Wars consists of the national collection of war relics and the building in which it is preserved. The collection includes the documentary records of the Australian fighting forces, and the pictures, photographs, dioramas, and material relics in which their story is enshrined. The gathering of these relics began on the battlefield and the decision that they should become part of Australia's memorial was made by the Commonwealth Government on a suggestion emanating from the front.

Conceived on the battle front, born amid the thunder of the guns at Bullecourt, the Memorial has been raised by the living members of the Australian forces to their former mates. Thus this national collection is unique in that it constitutes not a general museum portraying war, much less glorifying it, but a memorial conceived, founded and, from first to last, worked for by Australia's soldiers, sailors and airmen.''

The imposition of entrance charges shows the present council does not accept the conception of the memorial suggested by these gallant men in 1917, and subscribed to by the tens of thousands of veterans throughout our land. The council should be replaced by one which will re-establish our memorial as an enduring ``tomb most glorious''.

I think that is a superb statement of the intention of those who proposed the Memorial in the first place and of the Government that endorsed it and undertook to fund it, and it is a superb statement of the resentment that is felt throughout the veterans community at large-by more than a `few fanatics', as they were referred to by Dame Beryl Beaurepaire- and I believe by the community at large. It is a superb expression of that deep and profound resentment at this bad decision made by this group of distinguished Australians. The Australian Democrats support the motion of disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, support the motion of disallowance. I was disappointed that Senator McLean sought to draw some political advantage from the fact that the Opposition met on this matter only on Tuesday of this week. There has not been a party meeting prior to that when the matter could have been discussed. To suggest that, because the meeting was not held until Tuesday of this week, there was some reluctance on the part of the Opposition does not do credit to his argument. I have not heard a voice against it in the party room, and there is very strong support for disallowing this and a very strong comprehension of what the War Memorial is and what its role is. Certainly nobody who knows me or has spoken to me about the matter could suggest that I did other than oppose it right from the beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to go back into the history of the War Memorial. I have a few notes I wish to refer to-not in the depth that one might, but I think there are some things that are worth referring to. It was early in 1917 when the war correspondent Mr C. E. W. Bean submitted a proposal for a memorial to the generals at the time. In 1919, the Australian War Museums Committee said:

To establish (from a selection of the Commonwealth share of the trophies and relics) the battle models, the official pictures and photographs, and the historic documents, maps and air photos, so that the `Commonwealth War Museum will be Australia's National Memorial to Australians who fell in war.'

In 1922, the Committee used the official title Australian National War Memorial, rather than the word `museum', to differentiate it from other memorials, shrines and museums of that nature. From the very earliest time it was to be a memorial to those who fell in war. Bean's draft to Cabinet said:

The Australian National War Memorial, comprising a monumental building containing the war records of the Australian Forces-archives, pictures and relics and the engraved names of every Australian who fell during the War, thus dedicating to the memory a temple to which for all times students and the people generally will resort in order to have knowledge of their deeds.

Right at the very beginning it was envisaged that the displays and the engraved names would constitute part of the National War Memorial. To my understanding of the situation it is a very new and contemporary suggestion that there is some distinction between the Hall of Memory and the halls which house the relics and memorabilia of those who were involved. The Australian War Memorial Act was passed in 1925 and the inauguration of it occurred on Anzac Day in 1929. The program includes the words:

Conceived on the actual battlefront, born amid the thunder of the guns at Bullecourt, this memorial, raised by the living members of the Australian forces to their fallen mates, grew with the vicissitudes of battle in 1917 and 1918 . . . a memorial conceived founded, and from first to last, worked for by Australian sailors and soldiers themselves in honour of their fallen comrades.

It is not for us to impose a fee on the access to this memorial at this time. The word `museum' was dealt with on other occasions and rejected. In 1941, at the official opening, the words were changed to include airmen in addition to soldiers and sailors. There were memorable occasions. In 1987 there was a program management and performance review of the Australian War Memorial by John White &Associates. Section 20 of that report, referring to discretionary funding, said:

In this context, it should be noted that there is a strong feeling amongst Memorial staff and interested external groups that the Memorial itself should remain free of commercialisation such as general admission fees or levies.
I also refer to the plaque at the entrance to the Australian War Memorial, which reads:
This is the Australian National Memorial to those who died while serving their country. Visitors are asked to respect the sanctity of the building and its contents.

That has been there for a long time. I repeat that to me it is a very new concept to suggest that the Hall of Memory is a different place from the rest of the Memorial. Rather than read it out now, I seek leave to have quotes from the official publication at the time of the opening in 1941 incorporated in Hansard. There are some four paragraphs which I think sum up what it was that people were creating at the time.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Memorial to Australians who have died in defence of their country comprises the National collection of war relics and the building in which these are preserved. The collection consists of the documentary records of the Australian Fighting Forces and the pictures, photographs, dioramas and other models, as well as the material relics, of their campaign.

The gathering of these relics began on the battlefields of World War I and the decision that they should become part of the Nation's War Memorial was made by the Commonwealth on the suggestion from the Battlefront in 1917.

Conceived at ANZAC on Gallipoli, born amid the thunder of the guns at Bullecourt in France, the Memorial has been raised by the living members of the Australian Forces to their fallen mates. It constitutes not a general museum portraying war, much less one glorifying it, but a Memorial conceived founded and from first to last, worked for by Australian Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen.

The collection has been enhanced by gifts of valuable relics from the governments of Great Britain, the sister Dominions, our allies and in some cases our former opponents. To these have been added, through the generosity of Diggers, and relatives of the fallen, many personal relics of historic interest. The Memorial Building was the design of Emil Sodersten and John Crust.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) referred to the distinguished Council of the War Memorial. I have not heard anyone challenge its integrity. I think its motives were sound in trying to get more funding to display the material which is in its possession. I have seen some of it. I have been into the basement of the Memorial. There is an annex as well which is full of material. I would dearly love to think that it will be displayed and be available. I hope that we as a community will assist in that happening. I think the Council made an error of judgment in challenging access in the way that it has by imposing a fee. I have to say that `fanatics' is an unfortunate word to refer to those who oppose the introduction of the fee. I say that with Mrs Moore sitting in the Gallery today. She is well known to me and was a guide very much opposed to the imposition of an entrance fee. Nobody could call her a fanatic, but she made the stand that she did.

SPEECH.PARA: I have referred to the distinction between the Hall of Memory and the rest of the building. The Minister sought to draw that distinction. I reject it and, as I said, I believe it is a new concept. He indicated that there was a sacred aura about the Hall of Memory which does not apply to the rest of the Memorial. There is a sacred aura about the Hall of Memory. However, I think it is somewhat subjective to suggest that the rest is merely a museum; merely a place to look at things. I think that to many people visiting there is a sacred aura about a number of places. It is different from one visitor to another.

The Minister referred to the Opposition's amendment to the War Memorial Act in 1980 enabling the Council to set a fee. It was not for the entrance to the Memorial exclusively. It does not set it out. There could be an annex, special exhibitions or an exhibition in the new building which may well attract a fee. It may be established purely as a museum. I think that the Memorial itself, though, in the eyes of those who know it, is a particular building.

I remind the Senate of the fuss there was a few years ago when the National Capital Development Commission put up a proposal to change the front of the Memorial. It wanted to enclose a bit and do a few things which would have changed the appearance of the Memorial when looking at it from Anzac Parade. The Opposition fought against that. The Memorial is as it is, representing what it represents, and its appearance should not be changed. The fee to go into it should not be imposed. That is not to say that there are not changes to exhibitions and changes which occur in the way they are presented, but I think that if we go back to what was established it is quite clear what should happen and what should not.

The Minister seemed to draw some rather convoluted argument to a conclusion, saying that the phone calls to members of the Opposition after the event led the Council to make the decision. It is unworthy of Senator Tate to attempt to put an argument in that fashion. We all know that that is not the way he does things. I received a phone call from the Director of the War Memorial after the event. He rang me at home and told me of the decision that had been made the previous day and apologised for the fact that Dame Beryl had not been able to get on to me herself. I thanked him for the information and I indicated that I understood what they were trying to do in seeing that more of the material was displayed. I would have been disappointed if he had drawn the conclusion from that that I was supporting what he was doing.

The drop in numbers of people visiting the Australian War Memorial has been dramatic. Numbers were down 29 per cent in January. There is a drop overall in Canberra, as is not surprising, of 12 per cent in tourist numbers. The War Memorial is the flagship of tourist attractions in the Australian Capital Territory. It was overtaken in recent times by Parliament House-naturally, because it is new-but the War Memorial is very significant and its numbers were down 29 per cent in January. That is significantly lower than other attractions in Canberra. I think that there is a message to be drawn from that. I guess we can do anything we like with figures one way or another. I merely mention that there is a very significant drop. In passing, I say that the drop in numbers has had a devastating effect on the shop and cafeteria that operate in conjunction with the War Memorial. I wonder whether the Council ever thought of the small business that operates there when it did what it did and the effect that it would have on that business. There are other artefacts to be shown and I hope that they will be shown.

There has been quite significant expansion in expenditure and staffing in recent times and I wonder whether, as Senator Newman said, there should be a review of the management of the Memorial in this respect. Maybe there is a case for saying that more money needs to be spent, but that should be made out in a way that the people of Australia will understand it. Perhaps as taxpayers they would like to contribute. There are other ways of raising money. We built an opera house with a lottery once. There are ways that the War Memorial may consider before it again contemplates bringing in a fee to go into what I believe is a significant, symbolic place. There are two such places in this country, in my opinion; one of them is Parliament House and the other is the War Memorial.

The question of user pays comes up. For some reason, we are supposed to be committed to that principle, no matter what. That is clearly not the case. It is a general principle that the Liberal Party of Australia agrees to, and I agree to. We did introduce a fee to go to the Australian National Gallery, which is not in any way the same as the Parliament House or the War Memorial. It was opposed, of course, by the Australian Labor Party at that time. I remind the Senate how Labor screamed about that. I can remember Senator Ryan in this place going on and on about introducing a fee for the Australian National Gallery.

Labor was going to abolish the fee when it was elected. It was elected in 1983 but there has never since been a whisper of abolishing the fee for the Australian National Gallery. Now Labor senators come in here supporting a fee for the Australian War Memorial. How does the Minister reconcile that? I had hoped the Minister would tell us, but he has spoken and cannot speak again.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is blushing.

—He is blushing; I recognise that. How could they do such a thing? I think that needs to be explained. One could go on and refer to the organisations which have opposed this. I think we all know who they are. They have been very active, and rightly so. I support the motion before the chamber at present, which is that the fee be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I want to start my remarks by quoting what somebody has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to impose admission charges for entry is a national disgrace. . . . The decision is an insult to every former and current service person and their families . . . And it is even worse that veterans themselves should be charged $2 . . . The war memorial is neither a museum nor a fun park . . . Its intended role is a memorial to honour service people who gave their lives for their country, and all Australians should have the right to visit it free of charge.
That statement was made by none other than Senator Colston, the Deputy President of the Senate, and I believe it indicates a view that is widely held among members of the Government Party.

It seems to me that as the Council of the Australian War Memorial decided that because some top-up for the proper running of the War Memorial was needed, it would need to charge for admission in certain areas. If there is a need for further moneys to maintain the Memorial and to improve it, that is a matter which we as a parliament must face up to. It should not be done, however, in the manner in which it has been done-by levying a charge on the public of $3.

I might say that I sympathise with the Council. It has an enormous job to do. The people who are currently serving on the Council and their predecessors have, by and large, done a very fine job of work on behalf of Australia and on behalf of those who made the supreme sacrifice for their country. For that they deserve our wholehearted support and praise. Therefore, when Budget time comes around we should consider this question more thoroughly than perhaps we have done up to the present time. In that context we could hear from the Council as to what is required.

Suggestions have been made that more corporate sponsorship should be obtained for certain sections. This is something, as suggested by the Council, that needs to be pursued. But if, at the end of the day, there needs to be some further action taken, it should be taken by the Government and put to the Parliament. I do not think any one of us would begrudge the money required to preserve and maintain properly the War Memorial as an important memorial for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak so that I am on the public record opposing the imposition of an entry fee to the Australian War Memorial. The Australian War Memorial is one of the great institutions of the world. I do not think any other country has a memorial of the calibre and stature that we have in Australia. It is a marvellous memorial to those men and women who served this country in times of our great need. It is a memorial; it is not, as other speakers have said, a museum. It is quite different from the Australian National Gallery and from the National Science and Technology Centre, which are in the Parliamentary Triangle.

SPEECH.PARA: How we got into this position is one of those completely inexplicable things that happen in life. A very tragic mistake has been made by a body of well-meaning, well-intentioned people. I cannot explain at all how the Council of the Australian War Memorial so misread the Australian ethos that it imagined it could impose a fee on entry to this memorial and not suffer the intense public reaction that it has. Make no mistake about it: there has been a universal rejection. I have not met one person anywhere at any level of Australian society who supports the imposition of this fee. Everyone to whom I have spoken is, like myself, outraged that this should have been done. It is a tragic misreading of the Australian ethos by the War Memorial Council.

As Senator Newman said, the Australian War Memorial is one of the most popular sites in the country from a tourist's point of view. It is second only to Parliament House and probably in previous years it outranked Parliament House as a building tourists felt they had to visit. Not only Australian tourists but also international tourists came here because, as I said at the outset, it is one of the great institutions of the world.

I do not wish to turn this disallowance motion into a political debate but there has been a rather serious misrepresentation of the point of view of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia by both the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, and by Senator McLean, on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

All I can say is that from the moment I learnt of the imposition of this fee I was totally opposed to it. I raised it almost the same day with the relevant shadow Minister, Senator Newman, who is present in the chamber today, and said that in no way would I support it. It came into our Party room for the very first time this week at our regular Party meeting and the recommendation of the shadow Ministry that the disallowance motion be supported was accepted unanimously by the Liberal-National parties. That is the historically accurate representation of the events.

No-one in support of disallowing the motion has in any way or at any time reflected upon the personal integrity or attributes of the members of the War Memorial Council. I was saddened to hear that note injected into the debate at one stage. What we are-and what I am personally-concerned about are the actions of the Australian War Memorial Council and that is quite different from reflecting on the personalities of the members of that Council.

I think the Australian War Memorial Council has made some strange decisions in the last five or six years. When one looks at some of the things it has done, one can see that the Council has made some decisions of which I am sure it is not too proud. I was very concerned, before we rose at Christmas, to read a letter in the Canberra Times from a woman who said that she had been a voluntary guide at the War Memorial for 11 years or 14 years. She was opposed to the imposition of a fee. When she made her views publicly known, she was summarily dismissed from the staff of the War Memorial. I do not know whether that is absolutely true but it certainly was the purport of the letter in the paper. I find that an indefensible action to have been taken by whoever the authority was at the War Memorial. It is just part and parcel of some of the concerns I have about decisions made by the Council in recent years.

The purpose of the Council of the Australian War Memorial is very clear. Its duties lie in maintaining as high a curatorial level as possible for the huge possession of irreplaceable artefacts that it has. I have a personal interest in that. My father was an officer in the Australian Imperial Force and he contributed on behalf of his battalion quite a large number of artefacts to the War Memorial, along with thousands of other Australian service men and women. The curatorial role of preserving the collection, cataloguing it and making sure that it does not deteriorate with the passage of time is very important. It is really the Council's prime responsibility, because without this materiel we simply do not have the Memorial. It is far more than the bricks and stones that make up the building.

The second duty of the Council is to see that that material can be displayed. I remember in 1981 or 1982 a parliamentary committee investigating the Australian War Memorial. I cannot remember whether it was a House of Representatives or a Senate committee, but the central point of its finding was that the Australian War Memorial was grossly underfunded and had been underfunded for years. That was when a Liberal-National party government was in power. Nothing was done about it, and I suspect that the financial situation and financial support for the Australian War Memorial has deteriorated considerably since that parliamentary committee looked at it.

The fundamental problem we face with the Australian War Memorial is a lack of adequate funding and support. In rejecting the imposition of an entry charge, the obligation is clearly on the Parliament to make the funds available, or more funds available, so that the Council can adequately fulfil its duties.

The final point I wish to refer to in the political area is the business of the user pays doctrine. Memories must be very short in this chamber, but the principle of user pays was enshrined into Australian public debate by the Whitlam Labor Government. It was not a feature of any of the Liberal governments before that. It came in with a whole variety of charges, principally in the transport field. We have no objection to the general direction of the policy of user pays provided there is an element of fairness and justice in it. There is not much point in going into a deep debate on that but, while we accept that people who gain a benefit should make a contribution to it, we recognise that certain institutions in the country are above mere monetary concerns, and we certainly place the Australian War Memorial, because of its central part in the culture of Australia, outside that value. On behalf of my colleagues I support the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to underline the fact that the coalition is strongly united against this imposition of a charge. As shadow Minister for heritage, I would like to strengthen the case against the imposition of this charge by saying that I am opposed to it. I have been opposed to it, I remain opposed to it and my opposition has been reinforced by the reality of the fall in attendances that has taken place.

SPEECH.PARA: One would think that a government which claims to be a supporter of heritage matters would regard with major concern a 25 per cent fall in attendance in the first two weeks of January compared with the first two weeks of January last year, at such a place of major significance to our heritage, following the imposition of a charge. We have heard no response from the Government on that issue, but it would seem to me as shadow Minister for heritage that, if we are to substantially discourage people from attending a place of such significance in our heritage as a result of such a charge, that is a real cost to our country. It is a cost that is far greater than the $1m which is the measure of the revenue to be gained from this charge. One cannot simply look at costs in the base and material way that the Government has in agreeing that this charge be imposed because there are far more serious costs, I believe, in discouraging people from visiting a place which is so significant, so substantial, in our heritage.

It can be argued, of course, that because of the recession-the recession we had to have-all tourism is down, all visits are down; that people cannot afford to go to look at anything, let alone the War Memorial. If that is so, this is exactly the wrong time to impose another burden on Australians in visiting a place that is part of our heritage. In fact, it makes the decision to impose a charge all the more indefensible. To resist any suggestions that have been floated around this chamber that the Opposition is not totally opposed to the imposition of this charge, and to enforce the fact that not one voice was raised in our party room in opposition to the shadow Minister's recommendation, I join the shadow Minister in supporting the disallowance of the War Memorial regulations imposing a charge on visiting such an important part of our heritage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That issues arising from the making of the Australian War Memorial Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules No. 448 of 1990, be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report on or before 14 March 1991.

I foreshadowed that I would move such a motion. I had originally intended that the regulation itself be referred to an appropriate committee. In this case, the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs seemed then, and seems in relation to this motion, to be the appropriate committee, dealing as it does with matters arising under that portfolio. I have mentioned to Senator Zakharov, the Chairman of that Committee, that it was my intention to move this motion this morning.

I believe that the issues arising from the making of this regulation warrant consideration by a Senate committee. I understand the fact that the regulation is now disallowed, but I think we deserve to know how the Australian War Memorial Council understood its role and what was required of it in relation to the enabling provision that was inserted into its governing Act by this Parliament in 1980.

How did the Council come to its decision on this occasion? It is a decision which has caused division. According to the contributions of Opposition senators and Senator McLean, it has caused some distress and resentment in the community, particularly the veterans community. Now we have the fact of the rejection of its regulation by a majority in the Senate. I believe that in that situation the Council needs to indicate what imperatives led it to be compelled to make such a regulation. I believe that the alternatives that might have been considered and might be considered by the Council in relation to the provision of sufficient revenue and adequate funding to enable it to discharge its duties could be looked at, as Senator Harradine indicated, in a Budget or Estimates committee process, but can also be looked at by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs in this case.

It is important for the Council to get some sense from the Senate Committee of the Senate's mood and its receptivity to any other variation of the user pays principle. With due respect to Senator Newman, the extent of the permissible limits are not clear, in the sense of securing the approval of the Senate, of the raising of the funds from, for example, the levying fee from tourist buses visiting the Memorial and how that is to be correlated with the Senate now telling the Council that it cannot levy a fee for per capita or turnstile type entry of visitors to the Memorial.

A reading of the Hansard would make it very difficult for the Council of the Memorial to proceed safely in relation to fund raising of any kind. We owe the body of distinguished Australians, as they have been conceded to be by Senator McLean and others, the opportunity and the Senate Committee and its members an opportunity to discuss these issues more fully to try to understand the situation. As Senator Harradine has said, we will then be in a position to more clearly understand our responsibilities as senators and as members of parliament and as those who have a role in relation to budget matters in the working of the War Memorial.

We ought to allow this matter to go to the Senate Committee on Community Affairs for a short inquiry. I do not see this taking a very long time. Two or three witnesses would be all that would be required. We can clarify the situation so that this dreadful matter need not be repeated. I say that it is dreadful because I believe that those in the Council who took part in the decision making and who acted in good faith now find themselves in this position of having been repudiated and rejected by the Senate in the making of this regulation. We ought to do everything in our power to ensure that such a situation does not arise again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware that the Government would be moving this motion this morning until I arrived in the chamber, as Senator Tate has acknowledged. Although he did foreshadow that he wanted to do something about a committee, he was not specific about what he intended. The Opposition has not had time to examine the question in great detail. Therefore, I am in the difficult position, in one sense, of needing to give an answer straight away this morning. But my immediate reaction is quite strong. Therefore, I must state clearly at the outset that we do not see a need for this motion. We do not believe that it needs support or that it should get support. I will keep the reasons short and simple. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That issues arising from the making of the . . . Statutory Rules . . . be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report . . .

One wonders what Senator Tate means by the `issues'. I will come to some of the things he said later. As I can see, there is only one issue; that is, in the terms that the Government often likes to talk, one of access and equity in our national War Memorial.

Interestingly, only late last year the War Memorial reported to Parliament on that very question-access and equity. I spoke in this chamber then about that. But it was then very much restricted to the question of access and equity for Australians of non-English speaking background. Obviously a great deal of time had gone into reporting to the Parliament on how the War Memorial was performing in relation to questions of access and equity of people of non-English speaking background.

The director of the War Memorial, only in August last year-late August I think-said that the question of fees for the War Memorial was not on the agenda. Three months later it was not only on the agenda; it was decided. As I now find, it was decided with no consultation not only with the Australian Democrats but also with the Opposition. When the two coalition spokesmen on veterans' affairs have had no prior discussions or subsequent discussions with the Council of the War Memorial about the question of fees-the director is on the record as having said in August that fees were not on the agenda; we also know that they were not discussed with veterans' organisations-it certainly seems that this has been a question of indecent haste. It also means that questions of access and equity for people of non-English speaking background were given a lot of time and attention-I have no quarrel with this at all-but the same degree of attention was not given to the questions of access and equity for all Australians, and especially those who have actually fought and made sacrifices for their country, and whose sacrifices are honoured and remembered in that memorial. I find that extraordinary. That to me is the issue of the question of the fees. There is no other issue. It was decided to charge a fee; it was decided to limit access to our national Memorial.

The War Memorial has a number of opportunities to put its point of view to the Parliament and to parliamentarians. Only in December it presented its annual report to the Parliament. I spoke on that. I think Senator McLean did too. I do not think there was a great deal of other debate on the matter; I have not checked and I cannot remember precisely. But certainly there were no burning issues at the time except for the recent decision on the fees, on which I certainly spoke and expressed my real concerns.

The War Memorial, as an independent body, is perfectly able and entitled to express its real concerns about its finances, its directions for the future, its plans, the quandary it might find itself in if it is not receiving sufficient funding from the Government, and proposals it is considering for finding alternative finance. It can, must and should do those things. Then again, twice a year the War Memorial has the opportunity to come before the Senate Estimates Committee to answer questions and to put a point of view on its budgets and policy implementations. The Estimates Committee will be sitting again in just a few weeks time. There will then be a perfect opportunity for the matters to be investigated.

The War Memorial is a statutory body. It must consult with the Government; I am sure it does. If it is not getting sufficient funding from the Government, it should say so. It must and should consult with the Opposition; it should consult with other parties in the Parliament; and it should consult with the veterans' organisations. It has plenty of opportunities, if it cares to take them, to make sure that its situation is well understood by those who play a vital and important role in supporting the War Memorial. It does not need a community affairs committee to investigate its current situation.

I do not believe that Senator Tate has made out any real case for referring this matter to any committee at all, let alone Community Affairs, which, as we all know, is usually heavily burdened with legislative matters. The War Memorial and the Government also have access to the 1987 John White study. I think somebody has already referred to that today. There is no need for an inquiry about the way ahead. It has the information. It is a question of making a decision, but not making a decision without proper consultation, which unfortunately was what happened on this occasion.

Senator Tate said that we needed to look at understanding the role of the War Memorial and what was required of it by its Act. I do not think there is any doubt about that, either on the part of the Memorial or on the part of this Parliament. Certainly from the debate today it could be quite clearly understood what was required of it in terms of access to the Memorial.

How did the Council come to this decision? That is an interesting side issue, if you like, but it is certainly one that can properly be pursued in Estimates. It has caused distress to all of us, certainly on this side of the chamber, and, I understand, to members of the Government, as Senator Colston is on the public record as having said. It has certainly caused widespread distress amongst those who have had some connection with Australian veterans and war service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, I have a proposal.
—Would Senator Tate like me to conclude, or is he trying to interject?
—I think you will be happy to conclude.

—Let me wind up by saying that Senator Tate listed a number of reasons, of which I took note, as to why he considers this matter should go to the Community Affairs Committee, none of which were really convincing and all of which could have been considered in an Estimates committee format and, of course, I have no doubt will be. He said also that only two or three witnesses would be required and it could all be over very quickly. I think that is perhaps whistling in the wind. I have grave doubts that it could be over quickly, and certainly there would be more than two or three witnesses pressing to give evidence to that Committee. It is not a wise solution and I look forward to hearing the Minister's proposal. I am just concerned as to whether I will then get an opportunity to respond to him if I do not like it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My proposal would be, given the assurance, the undertaking or the indication from Senator Newman that this matter could be raised at an Estimates committee, that that be done during the consideration of the Additional Estimates this session rather than through this process.

SPEECH.PARA: My fear had been-not being privy to the additional estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs and not being sure whether the Australian War Memorial itself would be seeking any funds-that perhaps the more technical point might be taken in the Estimates Committee that, because no funds were being sought for the War Memorial in the Additional Estimates, it was not appropriate that this matter be discussed before the Committee.

I think Senator Newman has given sufficient indication that the more usual practice-and the allowance and the flexibility-of Additional Estimates committees would be allowed to prevail. This matter could be dealt with by that Committee and it would be more appropriate than the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I have briefly discussed this matter with the Chairman of that latter Committee, Senator Zakharov, and she agrees to that course of action so long as that assurance is forthcoming.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This seems like a satisfactory outcome to the problem. Of course, if the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) is not in a position to know whether the Australian War Memorial will be in the Additional Estimates, the Opposition certainly is not in a position to know. But I would have expected that, if the War Memorial needed additional revenue, it would have been necessary for it to be in the Additional Estimates. Certainly I was hoping that it would be appearing before us on the Estimates Committee because, quite understandably, I have a number of questions to raise about the Memorial. If the Minister can undertake that the War Memorial will appear on the Additional Estimates, we certainly will be happy-in fact, enthusiastic-to pursue this issue in that forum.
