—I speak to the motion to refer issues arising from the making of the Australian War Memorial Regulations (Amendment) to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs simply to indicate that I had in mind, when I was speaking to the previous motion, that the matter would eventually come before an Estimates committee either by way of seeking Supplementary Estimates or, indeed, at the usual time of Estimates committees' consideration of the estimates of various Government departments in October. I am never one to suggest that those Estimates committees should be so narrow as to preclude discussions about matters such as this, and I certainly will not be raising any objection to what the Minister proposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first instance the Australian Democrats were most anxious to support the original motion to refer the Australian War Memorial Regulations (Amendment) to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Part of that anxiety was to see that the issues that have been identified by Senator Tate were, in fact, raised. We saw those issues as constituting more than simply a question of money. However, with the assurance of Senator Tate that there will be room-as Senator Harradine has indicated-in this instance for the Estimates Committee to consider the wider issues, we have no option other than to agree with this course.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion-by leave-withdrawn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sloppy manner of presentation of the Australia Council Amendment Bill 1990 is an accurate reflection of the Government's severe downgrading of the Australia Council. This Bill was first presented to the Parliament in mid-1988. The Government was so enthusiastic about pursuing it that it lapsed at the 1990 elections and here we are now, in 1991, at last dealing with it. I might mention that it has been on the Notice Paper all this week. Apparently it has been the least important matter, from the Government's point of view, this week, and has been shuffled off continually, in line with the method of presentation of this legislation since 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that lack of concern for, and interest in, the Australia Council by the Government is reflected by its failure to appoint a chairman something like two months after the previous Chairman had retired, having completed the maximum term possible. This Government, fired with enthusiasm about the arts, took almost three years to get around to bringing this Bill into the chamber, has taken two months from the end of the term of the Chairman to find another and still has not found one, having hawked it around Australia, and now, at last, we are dealing with the legislation to alter the Australia Council.

The Bill restructures the Australia Council in line with most of the recommendations of the McLeay report, entitled Patronage, Power and the Muse, which was tabled in the Parliament so recently-four years ago! This Government is fired with enthusiasm for the arts, and one can see that by its speedy response.

The Bill has two major purposes: firstly, to clarify the right of the Minister to give written directions to the Australia Council on any matter except for the making of individual grants, where the Council's independence regarding grant provisions will remain, although the Minister will still be entitled to inform the Council of his wishes in particular cases; and, secondly, to oblige the Council to have regard to Commonwealth Government policies and, where practicable, to the policies of the State and local governments as they relate to the arts-and the Australia Council may comment in its annual report on any such directions it receives.

While the size of the Council remains unchanged, the chairpersons of all boards are to become ex-officio members of the Council. The requirement for two Government nominees on the Council has been dropped, but provision has been made for the appointment of two representatives of community interest.

The maximum number of members on each board is raised to nine and the minimum is reduced from six to five. There is to be a special coordinating board which may comprise the chairman, members of council, board members and members representing the community and arts practitioners. Its role is to advise on community cultural development, it will have a maximum of 13 members and no additional funds are required.

When the Bill was first presented to the Opposition in August 1988, former Senator Chris Puplick was of the view that the Bill as a whole should be opposed because it envisaged an even greater bureaucratisation of an inadequate Australia Council and of the arts in general. That is still the coalition's view. We will be opposing these changes to the Australia Council on that ground. There is no doubt that there is a massive duplication of grants mechanisms between the three tiers of government and an evident need, which is already recognised in part by the Hawke Government, to remove flagship arts companies from the unnecessarily bureaucratic control of the Australian Council; for example, as the Fraser Government did with the Australian Opera-which the Hawke Government has done now-with the Australian Ballet and the Elizabethan Theatre Trust. We need legislation that goes to the heart of the major problems with the Australia Council, not fiddling around at the edges after four years after the McLeay report. The clear evidence that has emerged from Senate Estimates inquiries, for example, is that about half the Australia Council's 1,090-odd grants to organisations are duplicated by grants from State bodies. The question of duplication of functions is simply not addressed in this Bill.

We should look at what should be done to the Australia Council, and the Opposition feels that the Government has not faced up to that in this legislation. Certainly former Senator Puplick had a great deal of difficulty in his dealings with the Australia Council. Certainly he was of the view that it had indulged in `playing favourites with arts grants to a scandalous degree'. As I noted when I was Chairman of the coalition's Waste Watch Committee some years ago, there is no doubt that much of the community arts budget had been used to fund all manner of political activities-much of it looking like square-offs to those bodies whose political objectives had not been met by the Government and were being paid off through the `arts industry'. As it is, large volumes of grants go to trade unions for what are alleged to be artistic matters, but which do not seem to stand up very well to close examination, as was given to it by the Waste Watch Committee. It resulted in the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) admitting publicly on radio that many of those grants were silly.

There is no doubt, as the coalition maintained in its arts policy at the last election, that there needs to be a major readdressing of Commonwealth-State-local government arts responsibilities. There seems to be a requirement for better representation on advisory bodies for arts consumers and for the States directly. There should be a withdrawal of the Commonwealth from any responsibility for community arts funding because there are better ways of going about it. There should be a greater direct role for the Minister in terms of policy setting for the arts in general and for the responsible advisory bodies. This legislation addresses that in part.

The coalition will oppose the Bill on the grounds that it does not resolve the major issues relating to federal funding of the arts, such as the need to establish clear lines of responsibility in arts funding; to avoid duplication of Federal, State and local programs; the need to remove mainstream national arts bodies from the unnecessary bureaucratic control of the Australia Council, as the Government has already done with the Australian opera; and the misuse of arts funding for blatant political purposes, particularly through the art and working life program and direct grants to trade unions.

That is fair enough in itself, but let us examine what has been happening to the Australia Council under this Government. There is no doubt that the status and standing of the Hawke Government's primary arts funding body, the Australia Council, has been severely damaged by the fiasco over its chairmanship. Two months after the retirement of Professor Horne at the end of 1990 the Government still cannot find a suitable chairman of the Australia Council, despite having hawked this highly prestigious job around for months.

There is no doubt that when the coalition went to the last election with a policy of disbanding the Australia Council and adopting the same successful direct arts funding approach as exists in New South Wales under the State arts Minister, the Hon. Peter Collins, sections of the arts community, spurred on by some blatant political public comment by the Australia Council, actively organised to defeat former Senator Chris Puplick at the 1990 Senate election. However, these same people have expressed very little public concern about the Hawke Government's damaging incompetence over the Australia Council's leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was Bronwyn Bishop.

—I shall respond to that interjection, because that sort of nonsense deserves it. Former Senator Puplick was beaten by 490 votes and if the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support had bothered to read the newspapers after the event, he would have seen the letters written to newspapers by various arts bodies congratulating themselves for having organised former Senator Puplick's defeat and saying how welcome it was to them. The Minister might like to let a few facts interfere with his mischievous nonsense. These same people have expressed very little public concern about the Hawke Government's damaging incompetence over the Australia Council's leadership and over aspects of this legislation, which I thought may well have worried them, particularly as to the capacity of the Government to direct the Australia Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The standing of the Australia Council within the arts community is important because there is a need for some kind of body, some kind of reorganised structure, in arts funding. Some kind of structure like the Australia Council may be an appropriate one for doing some of the non-duplicated work of individual grants. I have been examining that matter in my review of coalition policy.

The problem is that the Australia Council's standing, as such, has been so downgraded by this Government's incompetence-the damage being done to it by the Government's failure to appoint someone-that I wonder whether the Australia Council is at a stage where it is recoverable.

There has been much comment about the Australia Council by people in the media, relating not simply to the failure to find a replacement for Professor Donald Horne. There has been widespread criticism. In an article in the Australian newspaper entitled `Cultural dinosaur needs streamlining', Maria Prerauer states:

The Australia Council has become an obsolete monster left over from our artistic stone age. It was great when Dr H.C. Coombs, its first chairman, set it up in the late 1960s. Those were exciting pioneering days when The Australian Council for the Arts, as it was first called, began all sorts of projects, established a tradition of government subsidies and made our cultural desert bloom with lively new companies.
But as we go into the `90s the council has outlived its usefulness-at least in its present form. It needs trading in for a completely different model.

In recent years, with quite some flourish, the council has pulled lots of fluffy rabbits out of hats. At one stage talkfests were all the rage. Erudite blokes and sheilas were flown in from around the country to hold seminars and give speeches in this city or that. The converted preached at each other. But it all looked marvellous when immortalised later on glossy paper. Yet what came out of it? Nothing much, unless you count impressing politicians.

And as for the much-vaunted principles of ``arm's length'' and ``peer group assessment'' when it comes to applications for grants . . . who are they fooling? It's a jungle out there in the arts world.

Being assessed by a ``peer group'' is very often synonymous with being assessed by rivals. Or, conversely, there's the danger of mutual backscratching. (You scratch mine today, colleague. I scratch yours tomorrow.)

That kind of criticism cannot simply be ignored. I have noticed, too, a great deal of comment about the failure to replace Donald Horne as Chairman. I might say in passing that I have a great deal of personal regard for Professor Horne. Although I disagree with much of what he has done, he has lifted public recognition of the need for arts funding to a far higher level than existed before.

He did provide-as, I think, the Sydney Morning Herald said-a high level of intellectual leadership in this area. He has managed to help the Prime Minister by finding appropriate words, such as `the clever country', which the Prime Minister has now decided to latch onto. I suppose that, if we are going to be the broke country, we may as well be the clever one as well. It might divert people's attention away from the reality of just how broke we are. An editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

The test of the merit of Professor Horne's arguments is that they are now virtually accepted as doctrine . . . The arts are no longer regarded as a fringe activity indulged in by the basket-weaving class from Balmain. The challenge for the new chairman is to keep the arts up in the mainstream of Australian life.
If only we had a chairman to do so. We do not have one. In the absence of one, I notice that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio personality, Mr H.G. Nelson, made this suggestion:
. . . the new chairman should be Mark Geyer, the second rower from Penrith. Maybe that's who we need-someone with more biff up the centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit more push.

—Yes, a bit of push in the scrum. I suppose that Mark Geyer would be only one of the many people added to the list of those who are being touted as the potential Chairman of the Australia Council. In a recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald, Valerie Lawson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Among the many names mentioned as possible replacements are the writers David Williamson and Tom Keneally, public relations man Leo Schofield, Justice Michael Kirby, magazine publisher Richard Walsh, theatre director George Fairfax and a former editor of The Age, Creighton Burns.
The most serious contender is Professor David Throsby, professor of economics at Macquarie University . . . (He is the brother of radio announcer Margaret Throsby.)
But his name, along with the others, has been put back into the hat. ``It's back to square one,'' . . .

It is interesting that nothing has happened, despite the fact that I understand that many of these people have been approached and have knocked it back-as did Noni Hazlehurst, who was approached a couple of weeks before Horne's time had expired. Fancy a government allowing a situation where this significant role is being touted around Australia and being knocked back by people at the last moment. Noni Hazlehurst, herself, said:
Being aware that this position is one of the most prestigious and influential appointments available in the Arts arena . . .

She did regard it as an unusual honour for it to be offered to her but she said, `Thanks, but no thanks'. We have a highly prestigious position being touted around but not filled. Yet initially Professor Horne was appointed to this job seven months before he was due to take it over. He was appointed in 1984 for an initial three-year term. So it is no surprise that he had to be replaced. He was appointed for a three-year term; his chairmanship was then renewed for a further two years; and, then, for a further one year up to the absolute maximum limit of six years.

I do not know who the present favourite is. I do not know who has been offered the position and knocked it back. In the last month I know who was offered it and knocked it back in the run up to Horne's retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should ask your question in Question Time today.

—It might be interesting to ask whether the Government has at last found someone who is prepared to do the job. I make the point in passing that the Australia Council has often been accused of being the Sydney Council because it is so Sydney oriented. At present, in view of Horne's departure, there is no New South Wales member of the Australia Council, as I recall. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support who is sitting at the table, may correct me. There has been criticism from places such as Queensland that they are not getting a fair go. I guess that is one of the difficulties we find when we have a body such as this Australia Council. Maybe that is one of the reasons there should be a clear re-examination of the right way of funding the arts so that there is, at least, a perception of fairness in arts funding. Getting back to the question of who should be the Chairman, Valerie Lawson's article also states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Max Bourke, general manager of the Australia Council, said yesterday-
that was back in November-
``We wish a decision would be made. We've put up lots of names. No-one is more anxious than me.''
I am glad to hear the suggestion that perhaps at Question Time we might find whether Mr Bourke's anxiety has been resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested myself to find out.
—I was getting a false impression from the Minister.
—I have some interest in the Australia Council.
—The Minister might know whether something is happening. I doubt that Mr Geyer will make himself available, I regret to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Referring to the question of the Australia Council itself now that the Government has managed to downgrade its chairmanship, it is some measure of the lack of importance the Government attaches to this Bill that it has taken about three years to come before the Parliament. Essentially, this Bill is an attempt to find some sort of compromise between the arm's length principle of arts funding, adopted by all Federal governments to some degree since the Council was established, and the widespread criticism of that arts link principle. I understand that the Australia Council itself is happy with this legislation and was involved in the drafting of the changes.

Arm's-length funding has been an article of faith with the Council for many years. This means that grants are determined by an independent statutory body and not directly by a Minister. Theoretically, it means that if a grant is subject to criticism, the Minister himself will not be subject to criticism. There is no doubt that there is a perceived need for that sort of thing when we get public outcry, particularly from minority groups, about a grant on various grounds. The Robert Maplethorpe case in the United States is a case in point where there is strong pressure against the grant of funds for a very significant photographic exhibition which was claimed to be homosexual and obscene.

Involving that sort of thing in political disputation creates some problems and results in a situation where there is a risk that politics and the arts could well become too closely intertwined. On the other hand, this arm's-length funding does not seriously resolve this issue, if we end up in a situation-which the Government has-where it can give directions. We end up with a situation where if it is a good grant the Government will try to claim credit for it; when it is a bad grant it is the Australia Council's fault. Strangely enough, it has been a different situation in Australia. If it is a good grant the Australia Council claims the credit; if it is a bad grant it is the Government's fault. In practice it is not easy or convenient to enforce this system, at least in public perceptions.

There is a strong argument that an elected Minister with ultimate responsibility for public funds should take the decisions as he or she sees fit in the public interest. The Federal Government has frequently intervened, either directly or indirectly, in the grant giving process.

The decision to remove the Australian Opera from the Australia Council and give it a direct allocation in the Budget was seen by some as an abrogation of the Council's independence, although, as I said earlier, the same thing was done by the Fraser Government with not only the Australian Opera, but also the Australian Ballet and the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust. Now that the Hawke Government has removed the Opera from the Council again, it clearly underlines the fact that arm's-length funding is not entirely appropriate, according to the Government, in each case.

The proposed amendment to the Australia Council Act that will allow the Minister to give directions to the Council in general terms, but on the specific amount of a grant, is another example, if you like, of diminishing the extent of arm's-length funding in my view. For example, it may be possible for the Minister to say to the Australia Council, `Give more to young people's theatre in accordance with our policy, but do not, for example, give x amount of money to the major young people's theatre organisation'. While this may seem clear in this case, it may not always be so because, for example, if the Minister were to say, `Give more to the national opera company'-without saying what the name of that national opera company is; there is only one of them-that clearly means directing funds to a specific company. Undoubtedly, there will be grey areas between the general and specific. In theory, the amendment seems quite sensible, but it will not make much difference in practice. It will simply legitimise what Ministers have always done, in effect, anyway.

The matters to be taken into account by the Council are also of no great significance, but are some sort of welcome change. Under the Act currently the Council has power to cooperate with the States and local government bodies, but in future it shall-I emphasise `shall'-have regard to the policies of State governments and local government bodies. This will impose a duty to consult, but in practice there is usually some consultation between the Council and the State Ministers on matters of common concern, in any event. So in practical terms, it probably will not make much difference. The fundamental question is about what role the Australia Council should have in a field that is pre-eminently one for the States and local authorities.

Under any program of worthwhile micro-economic reform, many people would expect to see much of the Australia Council's powers devolved to the States. This is an area of government where duplication of functions can and should be avoided. As I discovered in Senate Estimates-the hearing that I mentioned earlier-1,000-odd grants were made and half of those organisations also received grants from State bodies. The New South Wales Government's view, when I asked it for it, was basically that the national Government should be responsible for major national companies and programs, including Australia's international arts profile and, perhaps, such matters as Aboriginal arts, but it should not be supporting or maintaining services in the States.

The Australia Council's future role should be more like that of the British Council than the Arts Council of Great Britain. It should carry the flag for Australian arts and artists in the world, but not be another funding body on top of State governments. That is a point of view that is respectable and should be looked at. There may be a case for having the Australia Council look after grants to individuals. I am certainly examining that in looking at the way this should be restructured. But there are many problems with peer group assessment. There are many problems of bureaucratic duplication. There are many problems relating to what the Australia Council is and should be doing-whether it should be intervening as much as Donald Horne wanted it to in the policy creation process. None of those major issues is addressed in this legislation. This legislation is an inadequate and a belated approach to the problem of what the Australia Council is and should be doing. As a result of its inadequacy and, I say in passing, its lateness, the Opposition will be opposing this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators are aware, the Australia Council Amendment Bill is, to a large extent, based on the 1986 report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee looking into Commonwealth assistance to the arts. The Committee also investigated ways to streamline operations of the Australia Council. At the outset, I would like to say how pleasing it is to see the Government actually responding in a positive way, even if four years late, to the recommendations contained in a parliamentary committee report, as has been done in this case. The principal recommendations of that report revolved around the need to clarify the communication links between the Minister and the Australia Council. The secondary group of recommendations was to the effect that both the Council and the various arts boards which are responsible to the Council should have memberships which are broadly based to reflect the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that in clause 2 of this Bill there is an allowance for members of the community to be appointed to special arts co-ordinating boards. According to the definition of `community interest representative', this should permit people who are not necessarily professional artists, but who understand what community needs are in relation to the arts, to take an active part in this decision making process. This is undoubtedly a significant step forward in the Australian arts scene and we commend the Government for the inclusion of this provision. I noted that on this matter the House of Representatives Committee in 1986, at the time of its report, on page 82 stated:

That greater attention should be paid to the component of Council and Board membership chosen from outside the arts community. Administrative skills and different representation of the public interest are important . . . and should be actively sought when appointments are made.

As we see it, this amendment will effectively allow the arts industry to harness the variety of views and talents available in the general community. We hope that the funding and decision making processes of the kind the Australia Council have to make will be enhanced because of that amendment. In fact, this was something to which the House of Representatives Committee gave particular emphasis-the need to have a membership which could be more responsive to the development of community and cultural activities.

We believe there is, certainly, a need to create an environment which is more conducive to helping the community understand the contributions which both Aboriginal and multicultural art have made to this country. In this way, we believe this reform will encourage the development of an Australian arts scene which is more in tune with the broader perspective of attitudes in Australian society today.

It is true that some parts of this Bill are contentious. In particular, I refer to those proposed new sections which deal with the matters which the Australia Council Board will now be required to take into account in clause 3 of the Bill. At first glance, this amendment could be seen by some as raising all sorts of questions-and obviously it has-about the intervention of government into the direction taken by Australia's premier arts funding body. We share some of those concerns. In fact, it is an object of our policy on the arts that the arm's-length relationship between the Government and our arts funding and advisory body be maintained.

Nevertheless, in this instance, it is not difficult to understand why such a provision has been included. It is true that over the last 10 or 15 years there has been a dramatic increase in our awareness as a society of the importance of the arts in nurturing a culturally diverse national identity. This has been accompanied by an explosion in the variety of arts activities undertaken in Australia. While this explosion of interest has been welcome, it is not difficult to recognise that in many instances there has been little cooperation between Australia's cultural arts-based agencies regardless of whether they are funded by the Commonwealth, by the States or by both.

The simple fact is that there are now so many agencies all up and running at the same time with a variety of activities that it is inevitable that some will be doing the same sort of thing in some cases, while totally ignoring the need for programs in some other area of the arts. The point is that while Australians seek to increase our understanding and experience of the arts, governments should accept responsibility for avoiding, where possible, unnecessary duplication of arts-based activities.

One aim of this Bill before us today is to overcome some of those problems of policy direction which the arts area has faced in the past. In addition to this, however, we must recognise that in the case of the arts, which is so often at the lower end of the scale of government funding priorities, every dollar spent should be made to count for something. In this context, it is important for all levels of government involved in arts funding, including the Commonwealth, the States and, in some cases, local government, to avoid duplication and to coordinate their efforts wherever possible.

We are not arguing for some sort of centralised government control of the arts, but we do see the necessity for some improved coordination in regard to arts activities and arts priorities in this country. Certainly, the sort of recommendations made by the Committee and now set out in the Bill aim to allow for better channels of communication between the Government and the various arts bodies involved.

Accordingly, we accept the need for the Australia Council, as Australia's prime arts funding and advisory body, to pay some regard to the arts policy of the current Commonwealth Government and following Commonwealth governments `as far as is practicable to do so'. We do not believe that this is an unreasonable request and certainly the significance of those last words which I quoted from the Bill should allow the Australia Council enough flexibility and independence to continue to run its own course.

We are also somewhat relieved to note that proposed new section 6b (4) emphasises that this new relationship between the Minister and the Council should in no way impinge upon the decisions the Council wishes to make in regard to funding grants. Otherwise, we may well have found ourselves in a similar situation to those States where the ministry of arts model has been adopted.

As some senators will be aware, in some of our Australian States, decisions on arts funding are made on the grounds other than those of artistic merit as a direct result of governments obviously interfering in arts funding-a model which the Democrats reject and which I am sure the majority of artists themselves also reject.
Clearly, such arbitrary political decision-making is unacceptable and there is no need for it, certainly not in the case of the Federal Government's relationship with the Australia Council.

We commend the Government also for the inclusion of proposed new section 6b (3) which, quite importantly, places a statutory requirement on the Minister to table a statement in the Parliament if that Minister does happen to exercise his or her power and gives a specific direction to the chairperson of the Council.

This parliamentary scrutiny of the Minister's decision should not be underestimated. Effectively, these requirements on the Minister at proposed new sections 6b (3) and (4) in clause 3 of the Bill mean that the Minister's new powers of direction cannot be applied to decisions on individual funding grants. We are encouraged that this will be the case. We should never allow ourselves to get into a situation where a Commonwealth Minister, responsible for the arts, makes decisions on individual grants.

I would like to take this opportunity that the debate provides to place on record the Democrats' strong concern at the decreasing level of funding which has been going to the arts area generally, and to the Australia Council in particular, over the last few years. As honourable senators will appreciate, in dealing with the operations and structures of the Australia Council-which this Bill does-one of the most central issues that should be addressed is the question of funding.

The fundamental problem with the Bill, as we see it, is that the reforms to the Council's operation and the introduction of better levels of communication will essentially amount to nothing if that organisation is starved of funds, as is the case with the Council at the moment. In this year's Budget, for instance, we find the Commonwealth Government allocated a total of $57.9m to the Australia Council. On its own, that sounds like an impressive amount but, by way of comparison, we decided to look at the Commonwealth Government allocation in recent years. We were greatly disturbed to find that the Australia Council has been suffering from real cuts to its budget for some time. For example, in the 1987-88 financial year the Commonwealth allocation to the Australia Council amounted to $51.8m. Compared with this year's allocation of $57.9m, this represents an effective real cut in funding to the Australia Council over the three-year period. Regrettably, that underlines what we feel is a very low priority that this Government is placing on the arts.

In its annual report of 1988-89 the then Chairman of the Council, Donald Horne, said the Council's most pressing issue of concern at that moment was the low level of funding to the Council and the staffing and administrative cuts which had resulted from that. It is interesting to note that Donald Horne sounded what we would consider to be a rather ominous word of warning when referring to the funding cutbacks. He stated in the annual report:
We must now face the unpleasant consideration that this may have gone too far.
We hope the Federal Government will take note of that comment and also of another statement from the Council's 1988-89 report, in which Mr Horne stated:
The Australia Council is a service organisation, not just one which provides assessment of applications for grants, then administers them.

Our staff consult with and provide advice to thousands of artists and arts organisations around Australia every year. And it is the only Federal or State agency commissioning and conducting research on any significant scale into issues which affect the arts and artists.

It is worth observing that Donald Horne made a similar statement of concern in the Council's most recent annual report, for 1989-90-it was a rather personal plea-that the Council's good work and various arts programs are now threatened by the present funding situation.

The Australian Democrats and community based arts organisations are understandably concerned therefore that, as a result of continued funding cuts, community based arts activities have deteriorated to what we consider to be critical levels. We fear that, unless the Federal Government takes note of these legitimate concerns, we stand to lose all the advances made in the Australian arts over the last 15 years, and that would be a tragedy indeed.

The Australian Democrats are realistic enough to acknowledge, taking into account the country's present economic circumstances, that organisations such as the Australia Council are unlikely to receive additional funding from the Government. However, we believe that the point we are making is valid: that at the very least a commitment should and could be made to index the funding which is provided to organisations such as the Australia Council and the Australian Film Commission. This would certainly allow the Australia Council to plan its activities better and would provide the Council's arts boards with a more conducive atmosphere in which to introduce community based programs, knowing that existing funding would be maintained, and not cut.

Indeed, if we accept that the Australia Council's purpose is to foster the cultural life of a nation and of its people, then how will future generations judge us when they see that successive governments have given a lower and lower priority to the arts? The Democrats-and indeed, I would imagine, most of Australia's arts community as well-will be watching closely on Budget night later this year to see whether the Federal Government is serious about the arts in this country or whether another funding cut will be executed on this funding organisation.

On top of that, though, we feel strongly that we, as parliamentarians, need to recognise that government support for the arts is more than just a question of handing out funds. It is actually one of the very best ways available to us to reinforce our national and cultural identity through the activities that are organised by agencies such as the Australia Council in our community.
Madam Acting Deputy President, the Australian Democrats support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to support the Australia Council Amendment Bill. I want to use the opportunity to express what I believe is a widely held concern about the Opposition's intentions in relation to the Australia Council. As Senator Michael Baume has already indicated, at the last election Opposition members went to the people with a clear intention to abolish the Australia Council. While I concede that they appear to have backed down from this position, it is still clear that they intend, at the very least, to interfere with the operations of the Australia Council fairly fundamentally, as Senator Baume has already suggested and as Mr Jull suggested in the House of Representatives, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe there is a role for the Australia Council, but it will be in a form which is very different from the way it exists today.

It is a matter of some concern that in the Opposition policy, which seems to be changing with time-I had hoped that these changes were a sign of mellowing but I am not convinced of that yet-no supporting arguments are given for the fairly drastic changes proposed, except some fairly generalised and, I think, prejudiced comments about specific aspects of arts funding, which I will come to.

Few people with any knowledge of the arts, whatever their views about the Australia Council now and how it is operating in relation to the States, would disagree that it has been a central and important part of Australia's national awakening in the arts since the early 1970s. It is ironic that it is perhaps its success as a generator of arts activities and arts development that has led to some of the more informed criticisms of its current role. It can be argued that the Australia Council has been so successful in encouraging arts development in the States that in some areas the States have overtaken the Australia Council and, to some extent, supplanted its role.

I agree in that respect with Senator Bourne's comment, that there is a case for looking at some of the contradictory things that are done by the various arts bodies, State and Federal, and the overlapping that occurs. There is a constant need to look at those sorts of things.

So it is the case, I think, that the States now have a lead in things such as the link between arts and economic and social development. They have a lead in looking at art as part of trade policy. Some States have a lead in the area of public art. They are leading the Australia Council, whereas the Australia Council used to lead the rest of the country. The Council's role in support for individuals and support for arts companies and organisations has been very largely supplanted. All of those things are developing things and need to be looked at continuously, but they do not necessarily lead to the conclusion that we need a total revamping of what has been a very successful institution.

I welcome the informed criticism that comes from arts practitioners of the developing role of the Australia Council, but I worry about what appear to be uninformed and fairly emotionally based responses of members of the Opposition who, with one breath, want to abolish the Australia Council and, with the next, want to truncate it or bring it under political control. They appear to be willing to make fundamental and far-reaching changes which could easily revert arts funding to the dark ages of the Menzies era, the days of Australia's cultural cringe. I think the Australia Council has been very largely instrumental in dragging us out of that situation. They appear to be willing to make these fundamental changes without any supporting arguments.

This is not to say that the Australia Council is or should be immutable or that it should not be subjected to reasoned criticism. If a good case can be made for change, then change should occur. But no case has been made by the Opposition, in my view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty per cent of the grants are duplicated. What sort of a case is that?
—I have said it is not a sufficient case for the fundamental changes that you are proposing.
—You just said `no case'. Make up your mind.

—Let me say `next to no case'. I correct myself. The case has not been made by the Opposition in any substantive way; quite the contrary. This is why the Cultural Ministers Council meeting in May last year in New Zealand expressed unanimous support for the Australia Council.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two features of the Australia Council's operations which are of particular importance, in my view, despite some of the comments of Senator Baume. One is the arm's length principle and the second is the concept of peer group assessment. The arm's length principle is specifically designed to take decisions on arts funding away from political influence. Senator Baume seemed to be arguing exactly contrary to that, which I found bemusing.

Professor David Throsby, who is an economist, who has studied arts funding and who, as Senator Baume has already pointed out, is one of the people, I understand, being considered as a potential chairman, put the case for arm's length funding very clearly when he said:

A balance is struck between implementing government policy on the one hand, and artistic freedom on the other. Thus the arm's length principle adds a liberal element to the democratic element by placing individual decisions beyond the reach of party-political patronage, general pressure group tactics and outright censorship.
It is an extremely important principle, which balances the necessary freedom needed for the arts to flourish and the public funding necessary to maintain it. To quote Professor Throsby once again:

It is acknowledged that the arts right across the spectrum can be and should be critical, subversive, innovative, uncomfortable. If politicians or government departments have too direct a hand in allocating funds, it is argued we will tend to get arts that are safe, conservative and unquestioning.
Those are not the sorts of arts that I am interested in.

Peer group assessment is an equally important principle. It is based on the belief that the best people to make judgments about the merits of a particular proposal seeking arts funding are those with direct experience in the field. I simply reject the proposition, which was put in the newspaper quote referred to by Senator Baume, that somehow this leads to cronyism. If I were an artist, I would far prefer my peers in the field to be making decisions about a funding proposal of mine than the prospect of a Minister or a department deciding the matter. Governments of all persuasions tend to be conservative in areas such as the arts where they may be laid open to criticism. There is a tendency towards conformity and safety whenever governments are directly involved in the funding of such activities. Peer group assessment is more likely, in my view, to lead to lively, innovative arts activities, and to keep the arts where they should be-at the cutting edge of change. That is often an uncomfortable position, but it is a very important one in society.

This is the best way to achieve the rich diversity which should characterise the arts, in contrast to the inevitable safe conformity of a system based on ministerial decision making. It is also an important way, I think, to enhance and maintain the multicultural nature of arts in Australia, and to address all those groups which otherwise would not be addressed and which certainly were not addressed before the advent of the Australia Council. I refer here not only to the many ethnic and cultural groups in Australia, but also to women, Aborigines, the working class movements in the country and so forth.

Other areas of constant criticism by the Opposition are also of concern because they demonstrate the same willingness to inject politics into arts funding, which its decision to interfere with the Australia Council shows. The first is its attitude, as frequently expressed, to community arts. The second is its more frequently expressed attitude to art in working life. The community arts, as administered first of all by the old Community Arts Board and now by the Community Cultural Development Unit (CCDU)-which is an awful mouthful but it does much the same thing; that is a change of name which I never did agree with-is an area in which some of the most innovative and essentially Australian creative work is being done.

I received just yesterday a letter from the Flying Fruit Fly Circus, which informs me-and all honourable senators, presumably-that it proposes to tour India and that it will be performing in Delhi, Bangalore, Calcutta and Bombay. The tour has a potential live audience of 300,000 people and a television audience of 100 million people. The Flying Fruit Fly Circus was developed, encouraged and maintained by the Community Arts Board initially and by the Community Cultural Development Unit since then. It is a classic example of the success of community arts. A second classical national example is the access poster workshops, entitled Another Planet and Redback, which I think everybody-including people in the Opposition at the time-roundly applauded.

In my area, in the hills of a suburb of Perth called Kalamunda, there are two very interesting community arts projects which have really impressed me. One is the stained glass window at the library. Two professional stained glass artists, Cedar Prest from Adelaide and Judy Kotai from Perth, worked with the community in a collaborative effort to build a most magnificent stained glass window at the local library. The is a permanent monument to community arts in that community.

The second one in that same area is a project called Then and Now, which was a collaborative effort by two professionals, artist Truda Austen and writer Andrew Landsdowne, and the elderly people from the Jack Healy centre, an aged people's centre in the community. These people used their memories of what life used to be like in Perth and its surrounds to collaborate with the artist and writer in producing murals and other artworks. They also eventually produced a book called The Bogoda Birds, which included references to their stories. These are lasting, tangible things which these people have got from a collaborative effort by professional artists and a local community. I think they are excellent examples of the valuable work that community arts does.

The Opposition's earlier decision to abolish the CCDU-I am not sure what the Opposition's position is on that now, but having just listened to Senator Baume I imagine it is about the same- would destroy some of the truly indigenous work of the Australia Council. I am glad it appears to be rethinking some of its attitudes towards its earlier position of total opposition, and I hope it also has a rethink on the work of community arts.

As for art in working life, it is also a frequent target of attack for alleged waste. This seems to be based on a prejudiced belief that the trade union movement is somehow not a legitimate institution. Yet the trade union movement is a major and respected institution in this country. It represents about half of the work force-about three million people. It has a rich and proud history, and a tradition of involvement in the arts. If government funding of arts is about reaching out to all segments of the population, it is crass not to employ the reach and resources of the union movement.

It is worth remembering that the art in working life program was introduced in the 1982-83 Budget under Malcolm Fraser, and that it represents only about 2 per cent of the Australia Council's annual budget. Yet, because of the prejudice of the Opposition, it gets a disproportionate amount of attention in arts funding questions.

It is also worth noting the quality of much of the work being done under the art in working life program, from tangible things such as union banners-which provide a rich source of history and colour on the struggles of working people-to the writing and production of work-related poetry, music and plays. All of this is for working people whose opportunities for exposure to the arts and ability to express themselves in artistic ways are very limited by the nature of their working life.

In terms of Australia's identity, some of the greatest achievements have been made in areas of community arts and art in working life. Yet these are areas which appear to be targeted by the Opposition. I hope it will look at these areas again. As I have said, I am pleased to note that arts policy is undergoing a rethink within the Opposition. I have a grudging-and, I hope, realistic-view of Senator Baume that beneath that external image of a philistine, which I think has attached to him since his participation in the Waste Watch Committee and some of the things he was forced to say there, lies a sensitive, cultured and artistic person who will look at this whole question in a much more supportive way--

TALK.START.PARA: —A self-evident truth!

— I agree with the honourable senator. I hope he will reappraise some of the things that he said about these two important areas-community arts and art in working life. I support the Bill. I hope that the Opposition will see fit to reappraise its total position in regard to the Australia Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating an amendment Bill to the Australia Council Act. It is a Bill that springs from a comprehensive review of arts and, in particular, the Australia Council.
—It took four years.
—I thought that Senator Baume had already made his speech, and I was simply to reply to it. But if he wishes to interject I guess I can take the interjections.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill springs from a report into arts funding titled Patronage, Power and the Muse-Inquiry into Commonwealth assistance to the arts by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. The report was provided in September 1986. Of course, being a committee of the House, it comprised Government and Opposition members. The findings of this report were unanimous; that is to say, both the Opposition and the Government, in a display of unity, came to the same conclusions about what should be done. In 1987 the Government responded to that report by putting down a paper and this Bill now arises in order to give effect to that response. With respect to the recommendations of this Committee dealing with the Australia Council, substantially the Bill before the Senate picks up and gives effect to those recommendations.

So what we had in the sequence of policy formation and legislation was an inquiry described in the foreword of the report as one of the most complex and comprehensive inquiries conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. A subcommittee of that Committee considered more than 4,500 pages of evidence from almost 100 witnesses at formal hearings all around Australia. It was a comprehensive examination and the Committee came to a unanimous conclusion. The Government responded and now we have a reflection of that in legislation. Yet we find that now, when this Bill is before the Senate, the Opposition chooses to oppose it-and it chooses to oppose it for a number of, I believe, spurious and ill-informed reasons which I will divert to in a moment. But, in replying to what has been put, it is important that the facts of how this legislation arose be understood.

I must say, before I turn to some of the more specific comments of the Opposition, that the first thing that ought to be observed, in all fairness, is that it seems now that Senator Baume, speaking for the Opposition, recognises the role that the Australia Council plays and its purpose, and gives some credence to that; that is to say, unlike in the past, Senator Baume is not calling for its removal or its abolition but recognises that it does have a distinct role, purpose and use. One should be grateful, I suppose, that therefore Senator Baume and, hopefully, the rest of the Opposition have embarked on a learning curve and that they do not now have-if I may use this term-a troglodyte mentality of opposing this body but recognise the utility, virtue and the good value of it. I should pay that compliment of recognition up front.

However, as I have said, a number of criticisms have been raised in the debate. Before I turn again to them I should say in reply on behalf of the Government that I thank all of the three senators who have participated in this debate. While I disagree with what Senator Baume has said, nonetheless his remarks have been useful. Certainly I have valued the observations and views of the Australian Democrats in this. Thirdly, my colleague Senator Michael Beahan has provided useful background to the Government's view of this legislation.

With those remarks, let me turn to some of the specific criticisms that have been made. What I think is the most substantial of those criticisms is one by Senator Baume, on behalf of the Opposition, that there is a need to cut out duplication in funding for the arts in Australia-duplication occasioned by the ability of arts bodies to traffic between the Commonwealth and the States or other sources of funds. Quite clearly, that is a serious and important question. We too have the view that duplication should be removed, and we are working as a government and have been working as a government to do exactly that.

In some cases it is fair, I think, for there to be a range of funding sources that arts bodies can go to in order to test their case, and not in all cases is that unreasonable. But the forum in which we have been working to cut out that duplication where it is unnecessary is the Cultural Ministers Council, a council of Ministers responsible for the arts in the various States and in the Commonwealth. That is obviously the forum. That Council has laboured on this subject and produced what it calls `the framework'-a framework which, if I were to speak from my experiences as the Industrial Relations Minister, I might describe as demarcating the various areas in which the States and the Commonwealth should have prime responsibility, so that there is not a duplication of responsibility by both.

While that broadly answers the demarcation question, there is still further work to be done, and that has to be admitted. The Cultural Ministers Council is still putting further detail onto the framework and I think that is the forum of Federal-State cooperation best equipped to eliminate the unnecessary duplication that occurs. I noticed that Senator Baume, in the remarks he made on duplication, while raising the subject and canvassing it at some length-he is right to do so, in my view-did not introduce any proposals of his own as to how the duplicative processes should be eliminated. That may be because he is not familiar with what I regard as the landmark achievement of the work of the Cultural Ministers Council.

The second area of criticism that has been made has been answered to some extent-I think adequately-by my colleague Senator Michael Beahan. I will categorise it, if I may, in this sense: the criticism has been made by the Opposition that arts funding has been used for political purposes. That is a judgment that the Opposition may choose to make. The truth is that arts funding in this country-with the exception of funding of the Australian Opera, which is a specific exception-is made and allocated by the Australia Council, not by the government. This is a body of people appointed because of their expertise in the field, their ability--

TALK.START.PARA: —By the Government.

—Yes, but it is because of their expertise in the field, and I do not think that the quality of people on the Council is a question for contention in the arts community. They are respected individuals and regarded as people capable of fulfilling the duties that pertain to them. They make those allocations. This Government does not; we are at arm's length from it and I think that is the appropriate format. But because we are at arm's length from it we are bound, when we appoint a committee of experts, to accept its judgment on these matters and not interfere. If we were to interfere we would be guilty of, in fact, bringing political values into play when these allocations are made.

SPEECH.PARA: So the structure-government standing at arm's length, having a committee of experts who are recognised and respected in their field to make these decisions-is the appropriate structure. But it seems that it is not that which irks members of the Opposition. What gets under their skin is the fact that some trade unions have qualified for grants-and that, because they are trade unions, is political. I must say that that is a fairly warped view of the world. Trade unions, as Senator Beahan said, are recognised institutions in this country. They are recognised at law, are respected, sit on major bodies, advise governments and--

TALK.START.PARA: —On capital gains tax?
—In this case Senator Kemp is picking up a specific matter of policy on which they hold a view which is similar to that of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Shall we debate the capital gains tax? I would be delighted to dilate at great length on why I think the capital gains tax is inappropriate and why it shifts the burden of taxation onto the back of ordinary Australians and the battlers in this community. However, let me stick with my text on the Arts Council, which is a different text today.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that, if the Opposition simply wishes to smear arts funding because some trade unions attract funds to carry on activities assessed by the Council as proper activities, in fact--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Minister, would you like to hasten to a full stop?
—I would like to hasten to a stop by saying that I appreciate very much the remarks of Senator Bourne as well in this and I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Coverage of Gulf War

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some brief remarks about the accusations of bias over the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) coverage of the Gulf war and to give some support to the comments which have been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Honourable senators will recall that the Prime Minister said on 24 January that he believed the ABC's coverage of the Gulf war was biased. This is what the Prime Minister said about the ABC's coverage:

SPEECH.PARA: I find it difficult to summon the language to describe my contempt for their analysis by their so-called experts. They are loaded, biased and disgraceful.
Dame Leonie Kramer, one of Australia's leading academics and a former Chairman of the ABC, said:

Much of what has been put to air in recent weeks at prime time is, indeed, as Mr Hawke has said, ``disgraceful''. But it is also depressing because in the end it's a betrayal of trust, and an insult to the Australian public.

Other well-known commentators, such as Paddy McGuinness, Frank Devine, Gerard Henderson and Michael Barnard, in various ways have all effectively endorsed the comments made by the Prime Minister. The ABC itself has indicated that it received more than 1,200 telephone complaints about the ABC's Gulf report during the first week.

In response to the Prime Minister's serious charge, the ABC announced on 8 February that it would launch an investigation into what was described as the `alleged bias and aggressive demeanour of its television and radio coverage of the Gulf war'. The ABC's Managing Director, David Hill, despite reports of some staff resistance, insisted that the ABC had to respond to the many complaints. David Hill was right. In my view he had no choice but to investigate the Prime Minister's charge. The problem, however, that a number of people foresaw was that the ABC was investigating itself. There was a fear that the inquiry would not be as extensive or as rigorous as originally promised.

According to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald, the original terms of reference of the inquiry were, among other things, to examine specifically the alleged bias of Dr Springborg and the performance of two of the ABC's leading presenters, Doogue and Olle. However, the terms of reference were, we understand, almost immediately watered down and the specific reference to these three individuals was deleted.
We read in today's Sydney Morning Herald that the investigation into alleged bias in the ABC's Gulf war coverage has been further watered down. The Sydney Morning Herald reports today:

The ``fair and thorough investigation'' promised last week by the ABC's managing director, Mr David Hill, appears now to have been so restricted that it has been dismissed by the journalists' union as a ``pretty useless exercise''.

I note that David Hill argues that the inquiry has not been watered down, but the Sydney Morning Herald writers have learnt that no staff will be interviewed for the inquiry nor will videotape or strips be reviewed. Further, there will apparently be no written report.

The investigator, Mr Derek White, the ABC's Manager of Corporate Relations, would give only an oral and not a written report to Mr Hill, who would then discuss the matter with senior staff. Paddy McGuinness's article in the Australian of 29 January this year seems, in retrospect, prophetic. Mr McGuinness wrote:

The very manner in which the ABC replies to criticism really only serves to underline the original criticisms. Always it is judge and jury in its own cause, closing ranks and presenting the results of its own internal investigations (like internal police inquiries), which usually seem to consist only of asking the original authors of a biased item to explain why it was not biased, on the presumption that they are in the right.
If the Sydney Morning Herald article this morning is correct, it seems that the journalists involved themselves will not even be asked.

I hope that the report in today's Sydney Morning Herald is not accurate because, if the Sydney Morning Herald journalists are correct, the ABC is treating the Prime Minister of this country, this Parliament and the Australian public with contempt. What will the public and this Parliament learn from such an investigation as described today by the journalists in the Sydney Morning Herald? Are we finally to expect a brief press comment or statement from David Hill indicating that all is well at the ABC? Whom are the journalists of the ABC responsible to? Has the Managing Director no control, indeed no right, to investigate serious allegations made by the Prime Minister?

Some time ago the distinguished journalist Sam Lipski advocated that the ABC needs an independent ombudsman. In other words, there would be an independent person who would have the right to investigate and adjudicate on complaints from the public. People who are unhappy with a newspaper article or newspaper coverage they have received at least have the opportunity to write and have their complaints published. If today's Sydney Morning Herald accurately represents the state of play at the ABC, not even the Prime Minister of this country apparently has the right to have his complaints properly considered. What chance has the ordinary citizen to have any complaints against the ABC properly considered if the Prime Minister does not have that right?
The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) has floated the idea of an improved and independent complaints procedure at the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asking for that for years.
—As Senator Harradine says, he has been saying that for years, and I am sure he has too.
—And I got an undertaking about it in the Hansard.

—Thank you for those comments, Senator Harradine. They will be recorded in the Hansard. I believe this Parliament, and certainly Senator Harradine, would welcome a proposal by the Government along these lines. The appointment of an ombudsman would certainly help restore public confidence in the ABC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief because the subject matter to which I am going to refer will be an ongoing matter of concern to this Parliament. On 12 February Senator Baden Teague made a speech on the adjournment about China. He commenced his speech by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The time has now come, I believe, for Australia to normalise its relations with China.

All I want to do today is to say that that speech was made only hours after two Chinese academics and intellectuals named Wang and Chen were condemned to a penal servitude period of 13 years-one on the same day as his first appearance in court and the other the day after he had first appeared. Such is the nature of the judicial system in China. Such is its contempt for the due process of the law.

I do not wish to analyse much of Senator Teague's speech at this stage because he made it perfectly clear in his speech that he had been told about this or that or the other-using his words. I know Senator Teague is very sincere in his desire to see improvement in the lot of the ordinary people in China. That is a desire that is shared by all members of this Parliament and is shared, I am sure, by the majority of Australians outside of the Parliament. It is shared amongst a number of China experts with whom I have close contact. But I do believe that it is premature at this stage and inappropriate to be calling for the removal of sanctions and the normalisation of relations, particularly on the very day that these two academics were given such severe penal servitude sentences.

Senator Teague and others who are aware of what happens in China will know that the manner in which Chinese law is applied varies enormously between provinces and within provinces. I quote from Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 1990, published by the US State Department, a copy of which has only recently arrived on my desk:

The People's Republic of China is ruled by an authoritarian government in which the Chinese Communist Party, backed by the People's Liberation Army, retains dominant decisionmaking authority. A close inner circle of a few senior leaders exercises ultimate power. Some of these party elders hold positions within the Politburo, the Central Military Commission and other organs. Others hold no formal positions of authority, but still wield decisive influence by virtue of their seniority in the Communist movement.

The Government seeks to maintain control through a nationwide security network-which includes the Ministry of State Security; the Ministry of Public Security; the People's Armed Police; the People's Liberation Army; and state judicial, procuratorial and penal systems-and through the ubiquitous party apparatus and traditional societal pressure. In 1990 security forces were responsible for human rights abuses, including torture and arbitrary arrests, as part of a heightened emphasis on the role of security forces in maintaining political control and social order.
That needs to be considered when we are deciding what attitudes we should now adopt to the People's Republic of China (PRC).

I am sure that the reactions that have taken place, both within and outside China, to the events leading up to and including the Tiananmen Square incident have affected the manner in which China is dealing with its internal situation. It does seem that, in some areas of China at all events, there has been a lessening of the stringency with which certain rules and laws have been applied. But, as is indicated by the US State Department's report Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 1990, there still remain consistent gross violations of human rights in a number of areas.

Not least of these is the area of freedom of religion. I notice that in Senator Teague's statement to the Senate on 12 February he mentioned the recent visit to Australia of Bishop K.H. Ting, China's leading churchman. Because Senator Teague is a man of integrity and also of knowledge, he indicated that this man holds a very senior position in China's parliamentary body-the National People's Congress and the People's Consultative Congress. It is clear that he follows the China line.

But the issue of freedom of religion is a deeper thing than the views of an authoritative state. Let us not forget that there are people in China in penal servitude, in re-education camps, who are there solely and precisely because they wish to practise their religion and the state attempts to interfere with their relationship with God. I am sure Senator Teague, being a man of integrity and a Christian person, would be very concerned about that. I believe he has expressed his concern on a number of occasions, and no doubt he expressed it once more to the visitor from China.

Another area, of course, is the question of workers' rights. There are a large number of workers who have been incarcerated as a result of their taking action to uphold principles which are regarded as totally acceptable by the world trade union movement and by the International Labour Organisation (ILO). The ILO undertook an investigation recently and said that it was of interest that the Chinese authorities had come across with more information than they had previously. That was a very interesting statement because in a number of other areas it has been more difficult recently to get information about violations of human rights. But the ILO indicated that at least in that area the Chinese authorities seemed to be more willing to come forward with information.

The Chinese population control program is another area where there are serious and continuing gross violations of human rights, and I would like to have responses from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to the points I raised in my adjournment speech on 20 December 1990.

I acknowledge that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has expressed concern about violations of human rights in this and other areas. I think the cautionary note that he took in his response, as I read it, to Senator Teague's comments is commendable. I read his response, I must say, only through the Australian Associated Press report and did not read it in Hansard, as I must do.

I would also like to know the response that has been given by the Chinese authorities or by those international organisations with whom Senator Evans was going to raise his concerns about violations of human rights in the population control area. I would like to hear from Senator Evans at some stage as to what response he has received. We should keep this question in mind.

All I do today, whilst commending Senator Teague for giving us the benefit of the information he gained from a recent visit to China, is to sound a cautionary note. The Chinese authorities had directed that these trials be wrapped up before the Chinese new year. I do not think it is appropriate that we should be called upon to normalise relations with the PRC at this time. I again point out that the 13-year sentences for Wang Juntao who, as we know, was a 33-year-old newspaper editor, and Chen Ziming, a 38-year-old head of a private social science research institute, are believed to be the most severe terms given to any intellectuals in connection with the protests leading up to the Tiananmen Square incident. I again point out that Wang was put on trial on the day that he was condemned and Chen appeared in court only the day before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to the remarks of Senator Harradine. I thank him for his kind references to the seriousness with which I reported my own views to the Senate and my recommendation that Australia move to normal relations with China. I note that the timing of my speech, 12 February, was because that was the first sitting day of this session, and it was the first opportunity that I had to report upon my most recent visit to China in December and January. It happens to be a coincidence that 12 February was reported by the Chinese media as the day that the trials arising from the June 1989 events may have been concluded. Certainly, I hope that the trials are concluded. Certainly, I regret not being in any position at all to know what the basis was of the sentences that were given, including the very large sentences of 13 years; nor do I know of the outcome of earlier trials where some of those accused were acquitted on 5 January but others were given sentences of two years and four years. The reason why we do not know is that the trials, whilst open to the family members of those accused-and, it would appear, to some selected persons to make up a public-were not open to the public. They were certainly not observed by journalists or diplomats. It is this regrettable lapse in international standards of human rights and in the procedure of justice that I directly referred to in my speech on 12 February. In particular, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, these trials do `fall far short of international standards', as Amnesty International stated last week. The trials are not fully open to the public, nor are they able to be observed by journalists or diplomats.
Further, my reference to the trials, which were in general terms known to me only a matter of minutes before I began my speech, led me to say this:

. . . it is now my understanding this evening that some radio reports from China today appear to have announced that all the outstanding trials are now completed, with the sentences in these last trials being six years up to 13 years. I certainly hope that the trials are in fact concluded.

I have, for more than half of my speech, referred to Australian concerns about human rights in China and my own direct concerns about human rights in China. It is in fact one of the driving motivations of my speech, and of my recommendation that Australia-China relations be normalised, that I have the judgment, which others can all weigh, that I believe that our concerns will be better understood, and remedies better given in response to our concerns, by our directly taking our concerns to the Chinese people on the basis of normal relations. I certainly argued in my speech against any sense of congratulation of Chinese behaviour. I refer to my summary in the speech in these words-

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't suggest that.
—I thank Senator Harradine for his comment. I said in the conclusion of my speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . those remaining matters in China which raise objections for Australians-and there are significant remaining objections, such as the failure, to date, to allow journalists and diplomats to attend the trials will be much more effectively pursued by our direct dialogue with China on the basis of resuming normal relations.
I also said a little after that:

. . . the resumption of normal relations does not mean that we have forgotten the horror of the Beijing massacre any more than our building normal relations after 1976 meant that we had forgotten the fear, the abuses and the wasted opportunities of the cultural revolution.

I wish to refer to the remarks of Senator Evans as they appear in Hansard. He gave them following my speech. I was very glad that he was present in the chamber and listened to my speech. Senator Evans said:
. . . I can assure Senator Teague that all these things are being very closely considered at the moment.

One of the matters that is always relevant in considering these kinds of issues is the question of timing. It is the case, as Senator Teague himself acknowledged in his speech, that that is a particularly sensitive matter at the moment with a number of remaining trials either taking place or just concluded in Beijing. That is something that the Government, again, will need to bring into account in its deliberations on these matters.

Finally, I note Senator Harradine's references to our concern, as we are both Christians, for all minorities in China, in particular the Christian churches in China. I give notice that I may, in the coming weeks, give an equally lengthy speech about religion in China, or about the state of the churches in China.

But in the time that was available to me to address the main issue that I was wanting to put to the Senate I did not have time to discuss religion at all except to refer to a number of visitors of standing to this country, including Bishop Ting, whom I very much respect and whom I have come to know very closely over the last seven years, in that we have met on a number of occasions. I know that he and many in China share my view and the view of Senator Harradine that it is entirely regrettable that there are outspoken churchmen who have limited freedoms and even are detained because of their conscientious beliefs, especially the belief within the Roman Catholic Church of a direct loyalty to the Pope.

This loyalty is objectionable to some elements of the Chinese Government who are critical of any Chinese citizen expressing loyalty to a foreigner. That is why the great majority of the Catholic Church in China, including the great majority of the bishops, have structured the Catholic Church in China to be short of the normal relationship to the Pope that exists, for example, in this country. The great majority of the Catholic Church in China recognise the sensitivity of their own people in government in regard to not having an allegiance to a foreigner. Whilst Senator Harradine and I and many Australians will regard this as unnecessary and regrettable, that is the state of things at the moment in China. It is therefore with enormous regret that we see the conscientiousness of the few leading to their lack of freedom within China.
