As is very evident in the annual report of the Catholic Church of China and of the Protestant Church of China, enormous growth is taking place in the numbers of churches and in the numbers of persons attending churches. In fact, the Christian church in China can hardly keep up with the enormous popularity that has come to it over the last decade. This is the case, for example, in Shanghai, Nanjing, Kunming, Chengdu and Beijing. Recently I visited churches in all those cities and had most careful discussions about religion in China and the state of the church. But that is for another speech. Those matters in my speech that Senator Harradine directly referred to I have now responded to briefly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have been misrepresented and wish to make a very short personal explanation. Senator Teague indicated to the chamber that I was concerned, as he was as a Christian, about the problem of denial of freedom of religion in China. He then discussed the Catholic Church, seeming to indicate that I was interested only in that religion. There is a large body of evidence about the closure of many Protestant churches, and I am equally concerned about that as I am about the denial of freedom of religion to Catholics in China.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.20 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Is the Government satisfied that the overnight allied air attack on Baghdad, which resulted in heavy civilian casualties, was one properly directed on targets of military value?
—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The loss of civilian life in Baghdad in a bunker or shelter hit during an allied air raid is deeply regretted by all members of the Government. In saying this, I am sure I do speak for all honourable senators. Such sentiments are, I know, shared by all United States (US) spokesmen, who have acknowledged the loss of civilian life as being truly tragic. At this time, the exact number of casualties is not known, but it is clear that a significant number, certainly scores, possibly hundreds, have died. When tragedies such as this occur, it is essential to recall that the coalition has affirmed on many occasions that its forces are not targeting civilians and that the war is not against the Iraqi people. Regrettably, though, during war there will always be, and have already been, civilian casualties on both sides.

ANSWER.PARA: This was not, however, a case of so-called collateral damage involving a bomb targeted elsewhere going astray and causing civilian casualties. On the basis of clear intelligence, the building here was a command and control facility and therefore a legitimate military target in its own right. United States military sources have made the point that the bunker was painted and camouflaged to avoid detection. It contained the telecommunications and other features necessary for such a military facility, and it has been the site for the movement to and fro of military vehicles. I further understand that there has been some signals interception of a kind that confirms that diagnosis.

While the building was earlier on in the bombing campaign a secondary target only, which explains why it had not been hit before this, it has assumed more importance recently, along with other buildings of its type, as other more central command centres have been damaged by earlier bombing and resources have been redeployed, thus making the facility a legitimate military target from the coalition point of view.

I am advised that the US military did not know that this facility was also currently being used to shelter civilians. I think we can be confident, on the basis of the assurances given today by US spokesmen that, despite its military nature, had this additional knowledge existed, the building would not have been attacked.

More generally on the subject of civilian casualties, in responding to a question on that issue on 12 February I made it clear that the Government shares the profound global concern which does exist about casualties on both sides of the current armed conflict in the Gulf, including concern about Kuwaitis and third country nationals who have lost their lives or suffered in other ways as a result of Iraq's brutal invasion and occupation of Kuwait, and of course its use of missiles aimed at civilian areas directly and deliberately as instruments of terror. I referred then to the casualty figures we had had from the Iraqi side, namely, 467 deaths and some 400 injuries. Since then, the Iraqis have been claiming, through US former Attorney-General, Ramsey Clark, that the true figure is something like 6,000 to 7,000 dead-that is, before last night's tragic event.

There is every reason to believe that the much higher Iraqi civilian figures we are now hearing about have been grossly exaggerated for propaganda purposes. It is reasonable to believe that Iraq has now judged that there is more to gain by publicising high figures, in terms of stirring anti-war sentiment in the West and Islamic countries, than it has to lose from such high figures in terms of domestic morale. This is particularly the case since the means of internal media dissemination are now so limited, making it less likely that these high figures would be widely reported in-country.

Finally, I notice that one journalist has called the latest civilian deaths which have occurred `the story of the war'. I think we all agree that this event is horrifying and certainly profoundly regrettable, but the kind of hyperbole that is involved in calling it `the story of the war' is simply not justifiable, even in these circumstances. The truth of the matter is that `the story of the war' remains the calculated, brutal invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq and Saddam Hussein's despotic, cold-hearted refusal to get out of Kuwait despite the requests of the entire global community. The onus remains on Saddam Hussein to end the hostilities and thus prevent all further casualties by withdrawing from Kuwait immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen an article in yesterday's Australian headed `Austrade ``lacks focus, ineffective'' ' which exposes what the consultant's report on Austrade claims to be the enormous failings of the organisation? Does the Minister accept the findings of the review into Austrade? If so, what does he plan to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been further more balanced press reporting of the McKinsey report on Austrade in today's papers, but let me say that the article which was published yesterday, and indeed some other articles, take a very negative perspective of the findings of the McKinsey review. I remind honourable senators that Austrade was set up by the Government in 1986. It is not, as a government institution, an old organisation; it was quite a young organisation. Its charter was to help Australian exporters access offshore markets. Of course, in its activities there is a particular concentration on manufacturing and service sector exports because many of the arrangements for supporting exports in the resources sector are made by other bodies such as, dare I say it, the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wheat Board and other organisations of that kind. I think that in the period since Austrade was established that task has been carried out satisfactorily. It is a very important task for any institution like this to face up to the challenges of the 1990s, to look at the question of the directions in which Australian trade flows are increasingly developing and to have regard for those sort of factors.

ANSWER.PARA: The concentration of the McKinsey report is very much directed towards looking at providing better facilities, better delivery mechanisms, for Australia in those markets, which are more difficult markets because of different business culture, different language, greater intervention by government in the marketplace and those sort of things than, for example, the United States market or the United Kingdom market, where there is much the same sort of business culture and certainly the same language. So, for those reasons, early last year, I with the Board of Austrade initiated a comprehensive review to determine how the organisation might be made more effective. In a very frank review, a lot of faults were found. I venture to suggest that if McKinsey provided a frank review of many other institutions in Australia, including many businesses, many of the same sorts of words would be used. More importantly, new directions and priorities have been identified and recommended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to table a copy of the report?
—The report will be made available. The Board of Austrade is generally acceptive of the findings of the McKinsey review and is keen to get on with implementing those findings.

ANSWER.PARA: I assure the honourable senator that I will be insisting that that process happens because I believe the report signals the right changes to ensure that exporters get the help they need. I will not go into the detail of the recommendations because, as I just said by way of answer to an interjection, that report will be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will it be made available?
—As soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister confirm that the latest fall out from the Treasurer's scorched earth policies is that the number of unemployment beneficiaries and Job Search allowees has risen by more than 1,000 a day over the last month and by more than 163,000 over the last year? What is the likely cost to revenue of this latest surge in human misery now that the figures are almost 90,000 more than the Budget estimate? In view of the fact that a substantial slice of the more than 200,000 school leavers will shortly be joining the dole queues, how much worse does the Minister expect the situation to get? Will the Minister also confirm that his decision to stop releasing these figures on a weekly basis in order to coincide with the monthly release of the unemployment figures is yet another desperate attempt to censure the recent avalanche of bad news?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I can answer some parts of this, at least those parts which are my responsibility. I did indicate last year that those who are receiving unemployment benefit were rocketing up-I think that was the phrase I used-in numbers. Quite clearly, that has occurred and has continued to occur since I made the remark. I think the Government on many occasions has made it clear that it believes that that will to some extent ameliorate the situation during the second half of this calendar year and beyond. I am one who also holds to that view. The unemployment benefit (UB) numbers rose very heavily in December and not quite so heavily in January. Nonetheless, with every person who is unemployed it is another one too many. None of us would like to see that situation continue.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of how much worse will it get, it is, of course, the Treasurer's responsibility to make that determination, not mine. So Senator Alston ought to address his questions on those numbers and on the cost of those numbers to the respective Minister.

As far as the release of figures is concerned, we would not seek as a government to dodge the release of unemployment benefit or Job Search allowance (JSA) statistics. The monthly average figures for January have been released today and they coincide with the release of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) labour force figures. Those labour force figures are the official estimate of unemployment, not statistics on unemployment benefit. In regard to the release of the weekly figures, the Department has never published such a series. That is because UB figures are subject to significant fluctuations due to non-economic factors, such as public holidays, and are not reliable indicators of trends in UB numbers.

However, the Department has provided information on request about the current number of UB recipients. Until recently there was only a very small number of requests for those figures. Therefore, despite the fact that they were not reliable indicators, because those who were receiving them were not racing out and using them publicly, they were not going to be used to create any sort of distorted position. The Department's practice, however, has been to release average monthly UB statistics in its four-weekly digest of statistics. These provide a much more reliable guide to UB trends than weekly numbers.

Because of the interest in UB numbers, the new publication being released today is more detailed. It includes an average monthly UB figure as well as some regional information. It should be noted that the monthly labour force figures from the ABS are also available on a seasonally adjusted basis and provide a more accurate indication of trends in employment and unemployment than do UB numbers. Consideration is being given to publishing seasonally adjusted UB figures in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. How can the Minister predict an amelioration of the situation in the second half of this year if he has no idea about whether the situation is likely to get worse and, presumably, has not bothered to inquire from the Treasurer?

—I do not need to inquire from the Treasurer. The Treasurer, the Prime Minister and the Ministers with economic responsibility have made numerous statements to the effect that the economy will improve in the second half of this year.
—Did you believe them?
—I said yes, I did believe them, and I repeated the prediction they had made.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the Minister seen recent press reports about the costs to the economy of poor English language and literacy skills among workers? In view of this significant productivity loss and associated industrial safety problems, is the Government taking any steps to address this problem? If so, what approach is being used?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of recent reports, including one from the Bureau of Immigration Research, which estimated that migrants' poor language skills were costing Australian industry in the vicinity of $763m a year. Earlier studies have indicated that the loss to the Australian economy of poor English literary skills on the part of both English speaking workers and migrant workers rates at about $3.2 billion per annum.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has recognised this problem and, particularly in the last 12 months, we have upgraded our response to it. We have, of course, the adult migration education program catering for the English language settlement needs of migrants, and the budget in that area was increased to $82.3m for 1990-91. However, we recognise that there is a significant backlog in the migrant area. This is one of the issues that were addressed by the working party report on post-secondary English language training, released in December 1990.

We also recognise that this problem needs to be tackled in the workplace, particularly because of industry and award restructuring. Because of that, literacy and language development is now an issue for adults in the workplace as well as for children in schools. Because of restructuring, workers need upgraded communication skills, and to this effect in 1990, the International Year of Literacy, our commitment to adult literacy programs was $4.5m a year.

The Government, as I said, has increased and upgraded its commitment in this area in the last 12 months. In the Budget last August the Minister for Employment, Education and Training announced that he would conduct a review of all Commonwealth literacy and language programs. In December 1990 he released a Green Paper entitled The Language of Australia: Discussion Paper on Australian Literacy and Language Policy for the 1990s. Public submissions on this paper are being received at the moment and will be received until 31 March this year, and a policy White Paper will be produced in June. While we recognise that we have a commitment, we also recognise that the responsibility needs to be shared by all in the community, whether it be industry, State and Federal governments, employers, trade unions or individuals. To this effect, the Training Guarantee Act allows for employer contributions to both literacy and language training in the workplace.

In conclusion, I should mention that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training is currently also conducting an inquiry into literacy needs in the workplace. Its report is expected at the latest early in March. The Government does have a commitment in this area. It is one that we recognise implies a shared responsibility. We recognise its benefits not only for the Australian community in the social sense but also for Australian industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In reference to the appalling carnage caused by an allied bombing attack on a Baghdad bunker yesterday our time, and in light of his answer to a question asked earlier today by the Leader of the Opposition, I ask: is the Minister aware of Australian Associated Press reports that there were several large arrows with the words `Shelter' in Arabic and English near the bunker? Is he aware that a Jane's military analyst reports that the bunker was quite possibly one of 20 to 25 shelters built during the Iran-Iraq war by European firms, each with a lower level use to meet military purposes and an upper level to serve as a civilian shelter, thus making any attack much more likely to kill civilians than to impair military capability? Is the Minister aware that the Pentagon says that it has observed military personnel in and around the bunker, routinely and continuously, and yet apparently failed to see the hundreds of children and women, who, according to several independent reports, had been using it since the war began four weeks ago? I further ask the Minister: does he agree that Iraqi authorities could have been expected to use every available shelter to protect their citizens from the allied bombing of recent weeks, even those which cannot be used as military facilities? Does he agree that there are, therefore, only two possible conclusions to be drawn about the allied intelligence assessments used to plan this attack, namely, that if they failed to conclude that civilians could be present they were hopelessly inadequate, or, if they did so conclude, that they must have been callously disregarded? What implications--
—Order! Senator Powell, this is developing into a speech, not a question.

—Mr President, this is the crucial part of the question. What implications does all this information on the public record have for the reliability of the intelligence received by Australia under the United Kingdom (UK)-United States of America (USA) agreement with other Western nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The crucial question here is not what the building in question may have been built for or used for in the past, but what it is being used for now. I have indicated the nature, in general terms, of the evidence available to the coalition forces in drawing the conclusion that they did, that this was indeed a military target. I am not aware of any reference to military personnel being sighted moving backwards and forwards; I am aware of references by United States spokesmen, in the material I have seen, to military vehicles being seen moving backwards and forwards. I believe that is the nature of the relevant evidence so far as that is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: The possibility always exists that the Iraqis, quite deliberately, maintained the use of the building as a civilian shelter while using it simultaneously as a military command centre. A suggestion to that effect has I understand been made by the presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. The very least that can be said is that the Iraqi authorities would surely have known, when they allowed the building to be used by civilians seeking shelter, that it was in fact a legitimate military target. They must have known that in allowing the building to go on being used, as apparently it was.

Beyond that, I do not think there is anything I can usefully add to my earlier answer. I am not sure of the point of the last reference to the UK-USA agreement. I will follow that up. I am not sure what point was being made. I am very rarely sure of what point is being made by the Australian Democrats when they speak about these sorts of issues. I will take that aspect of the question on notice and see what further I can add in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It refers to the unemployment statistics released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics today which show that unemployment in my State is at 10.4 per cent with youth unemployment at 31.7 per cent. I ask the Minister: is it not a fact that a major reason for the unemployment rate is that there are now more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available at the same time that existing jobs are being slashed because of the recession? Would it not be prudent for the Government to examine the structure of the work force to ascertain how many people now in the paid work force have to be there in order to make ends meet and could be suitably occupied in other socially desirable occupations? Finally, will the Minister attempt to ascertain, through government sources, of the very large number of married women who have entered the work force in the last five years, how many have done so because the household could not be sustained on one income and do not wish to be in the paid work force but would rather undertake their mothering-
—Order! Senator Harradine, this is another question that is becoming a speech.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many parts to that question, and I can deal with only a few of them because I take it that Senator Harradine would want a comprehensive answer. Having drawn attention to the very bad unemployment situation-particularly in his home State of Tasmania, where the unemployment rates have now almost reached what they were when this Government came to power-he went on to raise a number of philosophical issues about whether or not people generally are voluntarily in the work force. I think there are an awful lot of people in the Australian work force, whether they be male or female, who are probably not in the work force voluntarily; and that is illustrated in numerous instances.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the participation rate in employment has been higher in the last six or seven years and, indeed, higher in the last decade, than it was in the previous decade. Sometimes people try to draw the conclusion from that that a large section of the female work force is, if I can use the term, conscripted into the labour force because of economic circumstances. There are numerous factors at work in relation to female participation in the work force and I think that would probably have been the least factor operating generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the surveys.

—Unpalatable as that may be to some people like Senator Walters, I believe that to be true. As far as the current employment figures are concerned-the ones released today-I just draw attention to one aspect of them, that is, the small but nonetheless significant decline in the participation rate. I make the point that, if we had had in this recent period the participation rates of earlier years, like the start of the last decade-
—That is the weakest excuse.

—I am not proffering it as an excuse; I am proffering it as a piece of information to somebody who is not a know-all, and I assume that there are few senators like that, apart from Senator Kemp. I am proffering it as a piece of information. Senator Harradine asked me a very serious question about female participation in the work force. I know that a number of Senator Kemp's colleagues are interested in that issue, including Senator Vanstone, who normally sits behind him and who, I think, has quite strong views on this issue. I am simply making the point that, if the participation rates in 1990 had been what they were at the start of the last decade, the total unemployment level would have been in the order of 3 per cent. That is not offered as an excuse for the effects of the recession, or anything like that.
—Just a total irrelevancy.

—No, it is not. It much less irrelevant than Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection. As I said, Senator Harradine asked me a serious question and, as I recall, Senator Crichton-Browne was dozing off when he asked the question and I am now answering it. He is interested in the answer, I am sure. I will also try to find further information about the other aspects of the question which he asked.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister confirm that he will still be meeting with the Australian Bankers Association in Melbourne on Friday to discuss his concerns about the multiplicity of complex and confusing conditions which the banks are imposing on pensioner accounts supposedly yielding 10 per cent? I ask him how he reconciles this meeting with his statement announcing the 10 per cent rate on 6 February, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The financial community has responded well to the new deeming rules . . . There are at least 29 accounts currently offering 10 per cent or more at call on amounts over $2000. Over a third of these are special accounts designed specifically for pensioners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by praising Senator Walters again.
—Oh, please!

—I think that this should be done when necessary. I have to help Senator Walters along. On Monday of this week the Commonwealth Bank put out a statement in which it announced that it was taking out the conditions it had imposed on its 10 per cent accounts so that pensioners no longer have to face a $500 minimum withdrawal or deposit-not that I regarded that as impossible, but nonetheless the Commonwealth has helped out greatly. Senator Walters has provided me with a copy of that release. Given that the Commonwealth Bank said that it had not sent it to me and as it had come to Senator Walters's attention first, I wish to thank her. Ever since, we have been attempting to let as many pensioner groups as we can know about it.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am having a bad day. This morning on the fifth green at Royal Canberra I gave the Prime Minister 2,000 to one on a 30-metre chip and he sank it. My dilemma is how to tell him I will not pay.

ANSWER.PARA: On the score of the announcement-in the first place I said that I believed that the financial community had responded well, and I repeat that assertion now. The financial community has responded well. Whereas there were not any accounts when we started talking about deeming, it was 29 in the first place and there are now 33. The numbers have gone up and I am delighted that those accounts are available. What I am doing with the Bankers Association on Friday is attempting to make the situation even better. The banks and the institutions have done well. I want to help them do better. I shall talk to them on Friday afternoon about some of the conditions they have placed on these accounts.

As I have pointed out here in the Senate and in many other places as well, the difficulty would be that even if I were to reduce the 10 per cent to some lower figure and the banks and institutions were to exclude in some cases the first $2,000 from any interest, then I would not be of benefit to anyone. The banks in their discussions with me thus far have indicated that that is exactly what they would do. I want to make sure that that is not what they do and that they do even better than they have done over the last few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support seen reports that toy Patriot missiles will be on the market in Australia? Further, will the Government allow the sale of these toys and do they pose a potential hazard to aircraft?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the reports. I was well aware, as most senators no doubt are, that the manufacturers of board and computer games had already capitalised on the tragedy in the Gulf by flooding the market with Scud Attack and various other games that are available. Frankly, when I became aware of the reports I thought that they had to be nonsense. Unfortunately, I regret to advise the Senate that the Civil Aviation Authority has advised me that the reports are not nonsense. These so-called toys went onto the market in Great Britain. A spokesman for the British Civil Aviation Authority has already stated publicly that there appear to be no regulations or laws in Great Britain to prevent either the sale or use of these toys and that they pose a hazard to aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: The toys are powered by a solid fuel rocket, are capable of reaching a speed of 500 kilometres an hour and a height of 400 metres above the ground. The CAA has advised me that CAA regulations-
Senator MacGibbon interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say in response to that interjection that I lost all hope for mankind some years ago so none of this came as any particular surprise to me; it is all pretty depressing stuff. Mr President, the CAA has advised me that existing regulations do prevent the use in Australia of--
—Of course it would. We prevent everything flying here.

—That is an astonishing interjection. Senator MacGibbon interjected, `We do prevent everything from flying'. I would hope that we would prevent toy rockets from flying in Australia if we are to maintain our safety record. CAA regulations, despite the disgust of Senator MacGibbon, do prevent the use of these toys in Australia. I am going to have immediate discussions with my colleague the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to either get his advice or seek his assurance that, if these toys are not prevented from coming into this country in the first place, they will be.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that the State Bank of South Australia reported monthly, quarterly and annually to the Reserve Bank of Australia, yet both the Treasurer and the Premier of South Australia claim not to have known of the Bank's billion dollar problem until the end of January this year, will the Minister now arrange, as Standing Orders can provide, to have laid before the Senate reports the State Bank delivered to the Reserve Bank during 1990 so an assessment can be made as to whether the Bank provided inaccurate figures or the Reserve Bank failed in its supervisory role?

—I am totally unaware about the confidentiality arrangements which the Reserve Bank has with other commercial and semi-commercial lending institutions. I am sure that those matters would be regarded as highly confidential. I understand-if I might do as Senator Richardson did a minute ago and reinterpret the honourable senator's question-that the real point of the question is what disclosures were made which might have led the Reserve Bank to take some action at an earlier stage. I will endeavour to obtain further information for Senator Olsen on that question and provide it as soon as possible.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether the matter, whereby conditions of employment within SPC Ltd in Victoria were altered, caused the Government to reconsider its approach to industrial relations and those structures pertinent to it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. We have not had any cause to reconsider our approach in issues such as this. Over the Christmas-New Year break, Commissioner Donaldson, of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, successfully conciliated the SPC wages trade-off.
—How is the meat industry going?

—I thank Senator Hill for making audible his interjections, which are usually audible only to me. If the honourable senator wishes to ask a question, I will deal with that in due course. Senator Cooney is entitled to his answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The outcome of the conciliation before Commissioner Donaldson was to the satisfaction of the SPC management, all the employees at SPC, and the unions that represent the interests of those employees and, of course, it met the terms of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The agreement was accepted by the employees on 3 January. It achieved savings of over $2m for the next 12 months. The workers' take-home pay will decline by between 2.5 and 2.8 per cent and the agreement will be periodically reviewed. Management has also indicated that, when the company turns into the black, it will introduce a profit sharing scheme.

The only award condition that was varied in the final outcome was that wages were agreed to be paid by electronic funds transfer rather than by wage packet. That was the only award condition that, in the event, needed to be varied. That is a common agreement in trade-offs in the award restructuring process.

It was possible, when all of these parties sat down, to reach an agreement. It was possible to do it, demonstrating again the flexibility of the industrial relations system, and it was possible to do it in a way in which the objectives of both the workers and the company were met. I believe the industrial relationship has been improved considerably because of the exercise that has now been gone through. SPC attracted public attention because, as we know, the shareholders of that enterprise dismissed the previous board for poor administration and for bringing the company into a non-profit situation.

The new management negotiated trade-offs on wages with employees in order to reduce their cost overheads so they could bring the company back into profit sharing. It was not a matter of a company being affected by the recession; it was a matter of a company thinking it was a junior high-flying tycoon of the sort we have seen across the financial firmament in this country. It was done through the system. Mr Howard is right; it is an example of enterprise bargaining, but it is an example in which the unions were involved and the system proved flexible to accommodate it. Dr Hewson is wrong when he slams it, as he did, as a case of union standover. That is a cheap shot. In the end, all agreed voluntarily and he and the other H.R. Nicholls Society freaks should look at what really happened.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Further to the Minister's answer earlier in Question Time regarding the independent examination of Austrade by McKinsey and Co., dated 20 December 1990, I refer to its report's finding that:

QUESTION.PARA: The absence of a clear government strategy that encourages the development of exports . . .

is one of the major reasons for the ineffectiveness of Austrade. How does the Minister answer the condemnation of lack of government leadership, and in particular his leadership as the responsible Minister, in this critical area? In view of the Minister's failure, will Austrade now be transferred to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to accommodate Senator Evans's widely publicised acquisitional ambitions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet had the opportunity to discuss with the McKinsey consultants that particular sentence in the report; I will do so shortly. As I said in answer to an earlier question, many of the marketing relationships and overseas trading relationships of particular strong export sectors of the Australian economy are not handled by full government instrumentalities at all; they are handled by a variety of marketing boards and corporations-things like the Australian Wheat Board and so on. The strategies for those industries which constitute, still, close to 80 per cent of Australian exports are really very much in the hands of those bodies. As we have seen in the wool industry recently, some of those bodies, manned as they are by representatives of industry, have not been particularly good at reading market signals.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, with his myopic view of history, put forward an interjection which is ridiculous, if we look at the history of this country. In terms of manufacturing exports, the 1980s has been a very successful period, relatively speaking, for Australian manufacturing industry and service sector exports. There has been consistent strong growth every year in manufacturing exports.
—What about relative to the rest of the Western world?

—Ahead of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). We start from a smaller base but at a considerably faster rate than the rest of the OECD, which is the question the honourable senator asked. In terms of manufacturing exports, the McKinsey suggestion that there has not been a strategy requires some close examination. It has certainly been a strategy which, in respect of a range of industries, has worked.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources who was, of course, the Minister for Resources not so long back. I ask: has the Minister visited the south-eastern forests of New South Wales, Fraser Island or the south-western forests of Western Australia and observed the high level of resource wastage, with perhaps 30 per cent of each felled tree being left unused on the forest floor? What action is he taking to improve the efficiency of timber resource use, given that it would boost productivity and spare substantial other areas of native forest from woodchipping and logging? Does he agree that measures to improve resource productivity, coupled with a concerted move to plantations as a resource base over the next 10 years, are a far superior path to genuine resource security than granting logging companies guaranteed access to native forests so as to simply continue their wasteful practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should say straight off that, of course, the management of forests is a matter that comes constitutionally under the powers of the States rather than the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth's role in this issue is when questions of export licensing arise, and the environmental issues can then be assessed against that. The primary management of forests is not something for the Commonwealth; it is for the State governments, and each State varies according to the views of that government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have visited the south-eastern forests of New South Wales several times as Minister and the south-western forests of Western Australia, although I have not been to Fraser Island. I must say immediately that there is a big disparity in the management regimes applied by the Western Australian Government on the jarrah forests in the south-west of that State compared to the regimes applied in New South Wales. On a scorecard, I would mark the Western Australian Government well ahead.

Senator Coulter asked me a series of other questions, most of which would take too long to answer fully and completely. Let me give, in synopsis form, as full an answer as I can in the time allowed during Question Time. In the south-eastern forests of New South Wales, when the licence review came up for Harris-Daishowa, the Commonwealth Government played a key role. An inquiry was undertaken by both the State of New South Wales and the Commonwealth to identify the areas of sensitive ecological concern and having them taken away from the cutting areas. Working parties were established through consultants to look at the following: how to best use the waste resources on the floors of the forest, the small and the round wood; how to introduce new cutting techniques to get the best value out of logs and introduce a flitch mill; and in that geographical region, with the soil properties and rainfall of that area, how to introduce hardwood native forests to supplement the timber resource in that State so that in future there would be less reliance on native forest resources.

I am advised now that with all of those studies being conducted it is possible to see that the environmental concerns of the forest are met, and that the issues raised in Senator Coulter's question about making sure that the resources are utilised to their maximum capacity are also met. I am advised that an industry development plan for the south-east Australian region is shortly to be brought out by the department.

In terms of plantations, the Government has established a National Plantations Advisory Committee charged with the task of producing a national plantation strategy for this country. The Committee has representations from the relevant interest groups and the best Australian experts on plantation technology. It is expected that it will report in the middle of this year in time to be considered for the Resource Assessment Commission and the Government's ecologically sustainable development working party on forestry. I recognise that that is not as full an answer as Senator Coulter's question suggests he might require, but I think it is a reasonable answer in the circumstances of Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer him to section 241 (1) of the Australian Securities Commission Act, which requires the establishment of a joint committee on corporations and securities and says specifically, `as soon as practicable after the first session of Parliament'. Bearing in mind what I see as an important and urgent need for scrutiny of the Australian Securities Commission, particularly during this period when there are some problems with its establishment, could he explain why this committee has yet to be established and also tell me when it will be established?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Campbell is referring to the intention of the Parliament, in setting up the structures of the Australian Securities Commission, that there should be a joint parliamentary committee to monitor and to supervise its operations. I believe that this is a very necessary part of this Parliament taking political responsibility for the shape and moulding of the laws regulating companies and securities nationwide, which is the new feature which gives such confidence in the future of companies and securities laws in this Commonwealth of Australia after a period of great fragmentation where the Federal system was quite unable to give the coherent political supervision and direction to these laws, such that we had the debacles occurring in the late 1980s, of which we are all too painfully aware and which led to a loss of investor confidence both domestically and on overseas capital raising markets.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the question of the setting up of a joint parliamentary committee is one for which both chambers should take responsibility. It is not just a question, for example, of the Government deciding on the timetable for the invoking of that particular provision of the legislation to which the honourable senator refers.

I suggest that a parliamentary process be undertaken whereby perhaps the managers of Government business and of Opposition business in the chambers, together with the Australian Democrats-I know that Senator Spindler has a real interest in this area-and the independents, be informed of the intention to take up the requirement that such a committee be established so that the expectation of this Parliament that it take political responsibility for these laws can be fulfilled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is he aware of a letter headed `An important message to all shooters' being circulated throughout shooting organisations by the New South Wales Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mr Ted Pickering? Does the letter claim that shooters who legitimately possess rifles legally imported, which now fall into a class of firearms prohibited from import, will be liable for prosecution under Federal law for that possession? Would the Minister inform the Senate of the true position of shooters in relation to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator West for her question. I know she takes a great interest in these matters because of her responsibilities in outback New South Wales and provincial centres in her home State. I believe it is very important to refute some of the scaremongering that has been undertaken by Mr Ted Pickering to mislead shooters in that State about the true state of the law regarding their possession of firearms which have now been prohibited from being imported.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the Australian Police Ministers Council decided that military style rifles, quasi-military semi-automatic rifles, Chinese militia style rifles, Soviet military look-alike rifles and semi-automatic rifles ought not to be imported into this country. That was the decision of all police Ministers, apart from Mr Pickering from New South Wales. That decision of the Police Ministers Council was conveyed to the Minister for Small Business and Customs, who has made regulations to carry that request of the Police Ministers Council into effect.

I believe the decision is totally in harmony with the finding of the National Committee on Violence, which has been trying to reduce the types of firearms in our society which can lead to the tragedies we are only too well aware of, both here and in New Zealand, where arsenals of these weapons can be available to those of disturbed mind to undertake shooting rampages with such terrible loss of life.

As far as the shooters who presently hold such firearms in their possession are concerned, there is no question of that possession being rendered illegal. They hold those particular rifles under State law of New South Wales, and they are entitled to do so lawfully. It means that, from the time that regulation was made, no such weapons could be imported into Australia legally. I am sure that when honourable senators come to look at the regulation they will be well aware that the Senate itself is extremely vigilant to ensure that there is no retrospective application of any such regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about shopkeepers?

—Senator Baume keeps talking about shopkeepers. If shopkeepers hold these firearms and they obtained them before the regulation prohibiting the import came into effect, they hold them quite lawfully and legally under State law. Their possession, distribution, sale, licensing and so on are regulated by the State law of New South Wales. There is no attempt by the Commonwealth to displace or override those particular State laws regulating their possession.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Pickering says that Senator Tate has even gone to the ludicrous lengths of banning a type of airgun used in the game Skirmish, in which small paint balls are fired in a simulated warfare situation. Once again Mr Pickering is wrong. The Skirmish guns, modelled on rifles, are exempt firearms and can be automatically imported. Those modelled on a hand gun would be importable if the importer has the permission of the Commissioner of the relevant police force authorising possession. There is no attempt by the Commonwealth to override State law in this regard. I believe that Mr Pickering has indulged in a scaremongering campaign which can mislead responsible shooters and their organisations, with whom I had extensive discussions and consultations leading up to the meeting with the Australian Police Ministers Council. It has led to a situation where they have played a very real part in evolving a list of those firearms which can be legally imported into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. In view of Mr Kerin's 11 statements that the floor price of 700c would be held for the 1991-92 season, using such words to describe this commitment as `rock solid', `immutable', `guaranteed', `reaffirmed' and `fixed' and in the light of the press release issued by Mr Kerin on 11 February that the Government will contribute $300m towards a supplementary payment scheme to woolgrowers who sell their wool during the remainder of the 1990-91 season to make up the difference between 700c and what wool brings at the open auction, is the Minister aware that, if wool sells for 300c clean, the Australian Wool Corporation will have to borrow $1.2 billion; at 400c, the AWC will have to borrow $880m; and at 500c, the AWC will have to borrow $592m? Can the Minister give a commitment to Australia's 650,000 woolgrowers, who previously put their faith and their trust in the Minister, that the Government will salvage some honour and integrity by making up payments to the 700c floor price?

—In respect of its detail, that question is appropriately directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It makes a number of allegations against Mr Kerin and asks for particular details about the $300m and the purpose of that expenditure. Of course, it is essentially for purposes of equity between growers who have sold their wool and those who have not. I suggest that Senator Boswell put that question on notice because it requires some very detailed answers. In respect of the suggestion that Mr Kerin has made apparently inconsistent statements over the last few months about retention of the wool floor price plan, yes, Mr Kerin has, and so have a number of other people, including leaders in Senator Boswell's party.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, refers to proposed changes to the structure of unions based on enterprise. Could the Minister outline some of the details in regard to this matter, in particular the details of any training package? Does the Minister believe that the changes will give more encouragement to women to join unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jones is referring to a press report. I was quoted in the media-accurately, I must say-today and yesterday. In remarking upon the gazettal of amendments to the Industrial Relations Act dealing with the amalgamation of unions, I said that now there was a device in place to encourage unions to amalgamate along industry lines and that I expected, therefore, to see a spate of amalgamations in that direction. I also said that I believed it desirable that unions seize this opportunity to re-examine their internal democratic workings and look at their structures.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the things that I have been consistent in doing, leading up to the debate in this chamber last year, during the debate and now, is asking that unions which take advantage of the amalgamation procedures to form a larger union re-examine their structures to form enterprise branches rather than concentrate on the old State branch arrangement; base their internal democracy in branches formed at that level; and flatten their structures so that the distance between the leadership and the rank and file is telescoped and made more accessible.

In that context, I believe that representatives in the enterprise should be encouraged much more to go into training procedures through the Trade Union Training Authority to equip them to deal with negotiations which will flow in the enterprise, so that those negotiations can be fairly dealt with between equal partners across a bargaining table and so that the outcomes can be respected by both sides as fair outcomes without one side taking advantage of the other side through superior knowledge or resources.

I think the Trade Union Training Authority is the right place for this. We have some training packages there now; we are going to review them to make them more relevant to this type of approach. I think this will help particular unions which are concerned about recruiting female members. Women now make up 40 per cent of the work force; they are a notoriously under-unionised area. Unions wishing to be relevant to the needs of female members should look at this sort of approach in order to encourage union membership in that sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the course of Question Time, Senator Short passed me a note about an answer to a question which he had asked me late last year in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. I apologise for not having that answer available at the present time but I have made some inquiries and I believe that I will be able to give that answer to Senator Short on Monday.

—On Tuesday, as Minister Assisting the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, I undertook to provide further information to Senator Panizza relating to the decision to nominate Shark Bay for World Heritage listing. For the information of Senator Panizza and other honourable senators, I am now able to provide the following information: no correspondence has been found from any Western Australian Premier in the last few years asking the Commonwealth Government not to proceed with nominating Shark Bay for World Heritage listing. It should be noted, however, that on 31 July 1985, the then Western Australian Minister for Environment advised the then Commonwealth Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment that Shark Bay appeared to warrant immediate consideration for nomination to the World Heritage list. Subsequently, on 21 February 1990, the current Western Australian Premier advised me, in my then role as Minister for the environment, that it `is my Government's wish to pursue the early implementation of the entire conservation strategy developed for this State and the identification and nomination of areas suitable for World Heritage listing.

—On 12 February Senator Crane asked me a question dealing with the Australian Wool Corporation. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided me with an answer which I now propose to present. On 1 February the Australian Wool Corporation announced that because of the continuous speculation in the market and media about the future of the reserve price scheme, it had asked the industry to agree to the suspension of sales for up to three weeks. The Corporation also announced that during the moratorium period the Government and the Corporation would continue to consult on the strategic plans submitted as a basis for discussion by the Corporation. Senator Crane should also be aware of the decisions announced by the Minister, Mr Kerin, on 11 February. The assumptions he has made in his question to me about the Government's state of knowledge and the finances of the Corporation are his own.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator MacGibbon asked me a question relating to sites for the radar installations for Cairns and Coolangatta and whether they have had to be altered because of protests from environmentalists. I did indeed know yesterday, and in fact I should have advised Senator MacGibbon yesterday, that there has been a delay in the commissioning of these radar installations caused by technical difficulties that have arisen. That, as Senator MacGibbon will be well aware, is hardly an unusual problem in the settling down period for very sophisticated equipment. That problem will be resolved shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has advised me in response to Senator MacGibbon's direct concerns about the installations themselves that it has paid due respect to environmental and community issues in its siting of the radar sensors but that site selections were not altered as a result of the environmental protests.

In relation to Cairns, originally Mount Formatine South was selected. However, as it is a World Heritage area and this would involve lengthy approval procedures, the CAA decided that more expedient alternative sitings would be examined. Cairns will be served by three radar sensor units located at two sites-a primary and secondary site at Redden Creek and a secondary site at Hann Tableland. This is necessary to obtain adequate coverage for the terminal area at Cairns.

In relation to Coolangatta, all potential sites in the Coolangatta vicinity were investigated by a CAA technical team as well as the successful and unsuccessful equipment tenderers during their evaluations. The Mount Somerville site was judged to be the only site which meets the technical and operational criteria required for radar. The site was subsequently acquired and the radar sensors and equipment building have been established there.

I can confirm that both Cairns and Coolangatta airports have hills and mountains to their west. Given the locations of the airports with respect to the mountainous terrain and also the ocean, the laws of physics applying to electromagnetic effects caused by these two phenomena dictate that radar coverage cannot be perfect at either airport. However, the combined use of primary and secondary sensors at both airports means that acceptable levels of coverage will be achieved. A small area of airspace north of Coolangatta Airport has been identified as not being adequately covered by the primary radar, but the secondary coverage of that area is acceptable.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 14 February 1991, from Senator McLean:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
`That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
``The need for the Government to establish a Royal Commission into bank practices in Australia.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to withdraw the urgency motion and to make a brief statement of explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise honourable senators that, in addition to seeking to move this urgency motion, I sought by letter a further consideration of or deliberation on the President's ruling on Tuesday evening concerning what has now become known as the Westpac letters. Mr President, would you have any objection to my reading my letter to you and your response to me?
—No, as long as you do not canvass the ruling.
—I wrote to the President as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr President,

In view of public reaction to your ruling on Tuesday 12 February concerning my request to table documents relating to Westpac Bank and in order that I may pursue today's motion of urgency effectively, I respectfully request that in the public interest you reconsider your ruling.
I received the following reply from the President:
Dear Senator McLean,

In response to your letter of today's date relating to my ruling that you may not disclose certain documents on the basis of the sub judice principle, I reiterate that I made my decision having regard to the prejudice likely to be caused to legal proceedings and, on balance, the danger of prejudice against the right of the Senate to debate matters of public interest. Nothing has occurred to cause me to alter my decision, and the ruling therefore stands.

It is a ruling which I respect, Mr President. Therefore, I offer the following explanation as to why I have withdrawn the urgency motion. It is my view that the Westpac documents are by far the most potent evidence for the urgency of what I would have been seeking-a royal commission or a deliberation of the Senate concerning those matters. Those documents are available to me but not to my colleagues, namely all honourable senators, even though they are very widely canvassed in the community. I therefore believe that it would probably have been impossible for my fellow senators to prepare themselves adequately to debate this very responsible matter. In withdrawing the motion, I advise them that I will provide them all with a copy of my submission to the bank inquiry, which submission indeed consists of the 30-odd speeches I have made in the Senate on this issue in the last two years, plus relevant press releases. That will refer them to the in excess of 100 documents I have tabled in this place over the last two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. As I understand it, leave was given for an explanation as to why the urgency motion, which was the need for the Government to establish a royal commission, should be withdrawn. This explanation does not seem to relate to that at all. The honourable senator is, therefore, going beyond the terms of the leave granted. What is now really happening, through this sham, is a debate on a different subject; that is, your ruling and the contents and importance in the eyes of Senator McLean of these so-called Westpac letters. That is not what leave was given for.

—Order! I do not think that Senator McLean was questioning the ruling that I made. But I must point out that he sought leave to give his reasons for withdrawing and that it should not really turn into a debate. I will allow him to continue at this stage, but I advise him that he does not have unlimited time.

—I was simply advising my colleagues that I will be providing them with a lot of information that will enable them to prepare themselves adequately for this urgency motion, which I will move quite soon.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators-We are ready.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being told that these honourable senators are ready to go on the debate. Frankly, I do not believe that they are because they do not have the information. By their own admission, some of them have come to me and asked for time because this is what they have to deliver.
—Order! There are too many interjections. Senator McLean, are you seeking to table the series of letters you have?
—No, I am not seeking to table them-they have already been tabled; they are already in Hansard.
—I am sorry; I misunderstood.

—I need to be quite clear. All I am saying is that I will be providing them with this information. It is already in the Hansard. I have been asked to do this by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) for starters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I simply say that this is an appalling abuse of the processes of the Senate. This morning, mid-morning, the Australian Democrats put in an urgency motion. We all know what that means: there is a two-hour time limit; speakers on either side are notified; and they have to prepare speeches for the debate due to take place-Senator Cooney is ready to go. It now seems that Senator McLean did not ever intend to move the urgency motion at all.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is going to happen on a regular basis then the whole process becomes a farce. I do not think there is anything more we can do at the moment, other than protest in the strongest possible terms against what seems to me to be a total abuse of the process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I endorse the remarks made by Senator Hill and say that to the best of my knowledge nobody on this side, and certainly nobody who has been called upon to speak in the debate, was other than enthusiastic about being ready, even though it does not take 20 minutes to say, `I don't agree'. I would be happy for Senator McLean to withdraw his attempt to withdraw the motion and go ahead now if he wants to because I am ready, as is the rest of the Senate. If it is urgent we should do it now, and if it is not urgent we should not do it at all. That remains my view and it only reinforces my impression of the original proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason a matter is called urgent rather than a matter of public importance is so that there can be a vote at the end: everybody is made to come in and have a division and it looks nice at the next election time because the numbers were trumped up. It debases the very important back bench and Opposition privilege about motions of urgency. It undermines the significance of this chamber. I think it is a great pity, but there is nothing that can be done to force someone who does not want to debate an issue to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, as many senators in this place will know, Senator McLean, over a very considerable period of time-several years-has been seeking to have an inquiry into these matters. He has been putting a great deal of information before the Senate. The most recent information, which was the subject of considerable acrimony the other evening in the Senate, was the documents which you ruled should not be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean quite legitimately sought this morning, contrary to what Senator Hill just said, to have an urgency debate this afternoon on this matter in anticipation that you may have been persuaded, in the light of further approaches to you, to change your ruling. It was in the light of that that he sought to have an urgency debate because, in his mind and in the minds of the Australian Democrats, this is an urgent matter.

These documents are very relevant to this particular debate. All Senator McLean is saying is that now, in the absence of these documents, despite what we have heard over here, it is not possible to properly debate this matter of urgency. It is still urgent, but it is not possible to properly debate it. Senator Mclean is merely saying that he will wait until these documents are in the public domain, until other senators have had a chance to look at them, and then the matter can be properly debated, as we believe it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate invite Senator McLean to proceed with the urgency motion
.If Senator McLean does not take up this invitation from the Senate, there can be no way in the foreseeable future that he can come to the Senate and say that it is a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am accepting the invitation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to ask again now: is the proposal supported?

INTERJECT.PARA: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to establish a Royal Commission into bank practices in Australia.

Honourable senators will be aware of the fact that on 8 December 1988 I opened for discussion in the Senate the question of serious allegations of bank malpractice and corrupt practice. Honourable senators are possibly not aware of the fact that, prior to doing that, on 30 November 1988 I wrote a confidential memorandum to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and advised him that I had been given certain documents which made very serious allegations about corrupt practice in the Commonwealth Bank. I advised him that I would rather not take the matter to the chamber until I had discussed it with him confidentially and sought a briefing from him.

I did not receive a reply to that confidential letter to Senator Tate. That left me no option but to take the matter to the chamber. I started to table some affidavits in relation to the serious allegations and on 15 December I tabled the first of a series of affidavits. I have tabled in excess of 80, and they are available to all senators. One would imagine that because senators say that they are prepared adequately for this debate this afternoon they have perused some, if not all, of those 80 affidavits tendered to me by constituents. It would be a part of preparing adequately to consider the urgency of this motion.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell) approached me earlier in the day and said he felt that he had not had sufficient time or the sufficient focus to be able seriously to address the matter that was now being so widely canvassed publicly as a result of these efforts over two years. I respected that observation and provided him with an analysis and summary of them. In fact, it was the same analysis and summary that I suggested a few moments ago that I would provide to all other senators before returning to this urgency motion perhaps next week. In other words, I was alerted to the fact that it was indeed a very real challenge for honourable senators adequately to prepare themselves. Despite the lead time, there was a question of focus involved. Therefore, I sought to withdraw the motion with a view to more thorough and responsible preparation for the debate on the motion. That will not now occur.

The other consideration of which you are well aware, Mr President, is the fact that the Westpac documents are now widely in circulation, portions of them have been printed in the press, they are being quoted in the media and there is some confusion as to whether or not they have been tabled in various legislatures around the country. People are very confused as to whether they are able or unable to use those documents with qualified privilege. It is unfortunate that these ordinary citizens find themselves in that position. Over the last two years I have tabled 80 affidavits, as I have said, out of approximately 400 cases that I have in my files.

I have twice sought a Senate inquiry into the serious allegations of malpractice and corrupt practice among banks. On both occasions that proposition has been defeated by the combined vote of Government and Opposition. Slowly but surely, the issue has built up in the public mind. One aspect of the issue, managed foreign exchange borrowings, has recently come into higher profile because of these Westpac documents arriving in this country from an unknown source in Belgium. In the interim there has been the formation of the Foreign Borrowers Association, a self-help group of people who have been disabled by the damage that they experienced as a result of having been enticed into the program of Swiss foreign loans by greedy banks between 1983 and 1987.

As I have said in previous debates, and in advancing the case of public interest the other evening in relation specifically to the matter of Swiss foreign loans, banks actually invented a flawed product but an attractive one which they marketed aggressively and convincingly and which was taken up by approximately 1,400 Australians. As Mr Will Bailey and Mr Don Argus attested before the banking inquiry last week, it was taken up not only by farmers and business people but also by local government authorities around Australia, by local government institutions and by charitable organisations. The product was attractive and it was taken up by many. In the words of Mr Will Bailey to the banking inquiry last week, it was vigorously promoted and enthusiastically received by the public. But it was a flawed product. As I said the other evening, Thalidomide was the flawed product that destroyed and devastated Australian lives. So also has this flawed product.

Worse than that, Mr President, the product was sold with all the risk in the hands of the clients and all the profit in the hands of the banks. En route, the banks avoided tax which by law was to be paid by them but which they passed on to the clients. I am convinced that the banks breached their statutory obligations to the Reserve Bank of Australia. I am convinced that at least one bank, Westpac, has actually lost the key documents which reveal that it breached those statutory obligations. I am also convinced that the key documents in fact have been destroyed by banks in relation to these transactions.

I am suggesting that, in relation to managed foreign loans alone, banks by their own admission have breached the most fundamental of their obligations-the fiduciary obligation; the obligation to represent the interests of their clients or to consider the interests of their clients as equal to their own.

I have advanced and argued these cases in the public interest. They have been put on the record not only in the Hansard of 12 February 1991 but in previous Hansards. In the Rigg case and the Rahme case I actually read into the Hansard detailed step by step analyses of the way in which such cases were carried out, as substantiated by the confidential documents of the Commonwealth Bank. I am saying that, in relation to foreign exchange loans, this abuse was delivered on innocent Australians not only by Westpac but also by the Commonwealth Bank. I have tabled evidence to that effect in this Senate over the past two years, evidence which I believe has not to date been addressed as seriously by senators as it should have been.

Beyond that I have tabled evidence in this place that a scam, known as asset stripping, has been quite common throughout the major banks. I have tabled in the vicinity of 60 such cases, including the supporting evidence. I have named names. I have called upon the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the Attorney-General of New South Wales and the Attorney-General of Tasmania to lay specific charges against specific people whom I have named and I have supported those charges in this place by tabled evidence.

In other words, I am saying that over a period of two years I have attempted to address and to draw to the attention of this Senate the abuse of the fiduciary relationship by banks. I have attempted to highlight the fact that there is a widespread scam in the Australian community in relation to banking. I have alleged that there is widespread malpractice and corrupt practices among bankers, and I have evidenced it. If that is not a matter of urgency, particularly in view of heightened intense public interest in this issue at the moment, I find it very difficult to imagine what is.

As you are well aware, Mr President, there is in train at the moment the House of Representatives inquiry into banking practice. The terms of reference of that inquiry are quite narrow and they focus on the effect on banking practice of deregulation. I will be appearing before the inquiry on 15 March and I have put before the inquiry the 30-odd speeches that I have made in the Senate and the hundreds of documents that I have tabled in the Senate in that process. I have had discussions with Mr Steve Martin and I am convinced that he is very much aware that the managed foreign exchange borrowings dimension of banking practice in this country is one to which that inquiry must now turn as a matter of urgency.

I draw attention to the fact that Mr Stuart Fowler, the Managing Director of Westpac, Australia's leading bank, has by four means sought to restrain public attention to the documents now known as the Westpac documents. First, he has done this by placing injunctions upon those whom he believes may publish those documents in three countries: Great Britain, Australia and New Zealand. The restraints of those injunctions are now in place and being challenged. Secondly, he appeared personally before the bank inquiry and in his opening statement pleaded to the Chairman of the banking inquiry to return the one copy that the inquiry has of those documents. Thankfully, the Chairman refused to return that document and, therefore, the Committee will direct its attention to it in due course-I hope with a greatly sharpened focus by virtue of what has happened in the public media in the last 72 hours.

Thirdly, Mr Stuart Fowler and his Westpac Bank attempted to get back all the copies from Australians who had them. Fourthly, he made major submissions to you, Mr President, to the Clerk of the Senate and to other senators in relation to the tabling of those documents.

The gravity of the allegations in those documents is reinforced profoundly by the actions of the Managing Director of Westpac in relation to the documents in a panicked attempt to get them back. Nowhere at any time has the authenticity of the documents been challenged. There is no public doubt whatsoever that the documents are authentic. There is no public doubt whatsoever that they are potent and they are, in the words of Mr Fowler himself, devastating.

I am suggesting to the Senate that in many respects that evidence is no more devastating than the evidence I have tabled in the Senate progressively over a period of two years. There were 80 sample cases of malpractice and corruption beyond foreign exchange loans. I emphasise in my submission to you, Mr President, that foreign exchange loans management-and the utter abuse that that was of the fiduciary relationship-was but one example of such abuses widespread within the banking institution.

I sat in on the bank inquiry last week and heard Mr Will Bailey and Mr Don Argus, two managing directors of Australian banks, argue that, certainly, the foreign exchange loans experience was unfortunate, but the people entered into them informed of the risk. I do not believe they were informed of the risk and I have tabled evidence to the contrary in previous debates but, as I have said, even if these people were-to use the expression used the other day- `punting', the banks were the bookies, the banks laid off their bets and by virtue of a technique called point taking, they actually changed the odds after the bets were taken. By virtue of a technique called deal swapping, they actually changed the accounts to which transactions had been directed. In other words, they changed the names on top of the tickets that had been written in that betting process, so to speak, and in so doing they reduced the ethics and the ethos of banking to that of the racetrack and the gambling parlour. They rendered a sham, through just that one exercise of foreign exchange loan management, the whole banking institution in Australia.

I have said in Hansard previously that, when I was in Zurich three months ago as a member of a parliamentary delegation, we sat before nine leading Swiss bankers. We were discussing why more Swiss bank money is not attracted to this country. Their message to us was quite simple: our corporate image stinks. Their words were not that blunt but their message was that blunt. The corporate dynasties have been propped up by pseudo banking investment and support, evidenced by the collapse of three State banks around this nation. The banking policies of those State banks had propped up corporate bodies which had no substance. They subsequently collapsed, which led these Swiss bankers to this conclusion. They said it would be a decade before the corporate image was rectified.

In the process of giving us this message, one of the corporate Swiss bankers, Dr Henry Stalder, made a totally unsolicited comment.
