He said that the senior bankers in Australia who enticed Australian farmers and business people into Swiss bank loans between 1983 and 1987 are nothing short of criminals, should be in gaol, and that he would come to Australia to testify to that effect. I think he encapsulated precisely the morality that has prevailed within banking in relation to the foreign Swiss loans fiasco.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the third State bank collapse?

—I am simply saying to my senatorial colleagues that for two years I have been tabling potent evidence. I have been pleading with them to direct their attention to it. Many of them have admitted doubts, including Senator Boswell today. He asked me for some assistance in beginning to seriously analyse the material I have been bringing before the Senate. I do not wish this to be a harsh judgment, but I do not believe that many senators have seriously addressed the evidence that I have been placing before them in the last two years.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not saying that it is not a matter of urgency that they do so; I believe that it is a matter of utter urgency that they do so. I am not saying that it is not a matter of urgency that a royal commission should be established; I am saying it is a matter of absolute urgency that it be established. I have pleaded to you, Mr President, that in the public interest it is a matter of absolute urgency that the resources be made available to us to be able to make that judgment. I accept your ruling and, therefore, I have to turn to providing my senatorial colleagues-and I have attempted to do that vigorously for two years-with evidence to the effect that we, in this country, desperately need a royal commission to reveal the travesty of banking in this nation. We have not had one since the 1930s. We particularly need it to reveal the disaster of deregulated banking, which is banking in the successful pursuit of profit. Mr Don Argus, the managing director of the National Australia Bank Ltd, in a confidential memo to his managers which I tabled in this place on 25 May 1989 described it as `super profits'. He said that in the climate of super profits what was in his confidential memo must not be revealed to his State managers.
I am saying that it is a matter of urgency that all be revealed to the Australian public through a royal commission into the malpractice and corruption which is rampant in Australian banking today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go to the subject matter of this debate specifically, there are two questions that Senator McLean referred to in his last couple of minutes which I think are important to correct on the public record. One is that he rather cavalierly talked about the collapse of three State banks. It is fundamental to say that people in public life have some responsibility to uphold the integrity of the Australian financial system. There is one State bank that collapsed, one that has had a substantial asset contribution to ensure that it continues to be viable, and no other that is, by any report that I have heard, under any danger at all. That was careless and irresponsible.
—What was the third bank?

—There is not even a second bank. That is the significant point. That does not affect the issue of whether there ought to be a royal commission or not, but it is important that we get it on the record correctly. Secondly, in the last minute or two, he threw in that these problems to which he is alluding-and I am not denigrating the significance of some of them-relate to the deregulation of the banks. Nothing could be further from the truth. Senator McLean said that the shocking thing is that since deregulation we have got profit driven banking. Westpac, NAB and the ANZ have been driven by profits, in some instances for 150 years. That may or may not be a good thing. Both deregulation and the role of private enterprise in banks are legitimate matters of public debate; they have nothing to do with the issue before us today. I really want to knock those furphies, first of all.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us now get down to the subject matter of this debate. It is important to distinguish between talking about something important like corruption in the banks or maladministration or abuse of the rights of consumers, and doing something important. Doing something important is not getting up in this chamber and pretending that there ought to be a royal commission. If honourable senators think there are problems so well identified, act against them; do not run around being, as the Australian Democrats always are, the party of mirrors. They always want to look into everything but they do not want to actually do anything about anything.

Opposing a royal commission in this instance is not the same as supporting or defending everything which the banks have done; that is not the case. There are many reasonable areas for concern about and criticism of the activities of the Australian banks over the last 10, 20, 30 or 100 years-whichever timetable we wish to put. I am happy if I get time today to articulate some of those concerns. But none of them relates to the question of whether there ought to be a royal commission. Royal commissions require more than that there is a reasonable cause for concern about the matters under consideration. That is necessarily one; that is a precondition; I accept that, obviously. The matter must be of profound national importance. And let us not bother to debate whether that is so or not in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go out into the street and test it.

—Once again, the honourable senator fails to understand the point that I am making in simple English. That is not why I am opposed to a royal commission-the argument about whether it is important or not. We do not scatter royal commissions around like confetti. To do so devalues the currency of a very important mechanism of public administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Democrats senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator McMullan has the floor.

—I am delighted to give the Democrats the opportunity to compound their ignorance and make it more apparent. Royal commissions are things which ought to be used under rigorous criteria. Firstly, as I was trying to say before, it is important that the issue be of profound national importance. I put that to one side for this debate because that is not the ground of my criticism that this is not the appropriate subject matter for a royal commission.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two other essential criteria-and we could create a more complex structure. Those criteria are: there is no alternative forum under which the matter can be properly inquired into and, related to that, were it not for the powers of a royal commission, information that is necessary may not otherwise be available to the public or to those conducting the inquiry. My point is that this matter passes only one of those tests; it passes the test that it is a matter of importance. It does not pass the others. We go from saying that this is important to saying that this is something we should have a royal commission about. There are 100 or 200 important issues at the moment, many of which have been the subject of questions today and of debates regularly in this chamber-we had an urgency motion yesterday about one. But we are not having royal commissions into them. There are other public forums where they can be dealt with, and that is appropriate. As I said, we do not scatter them around like confetti.

Australia has a fascination with saying that every problem that arises can be resolved somehow by a judge. So we set up a judicial inquiry or a royal commission, and suddenly it will all be resolved. Many of the matters are much better dealt with here. Others are much better dealt with in the courts or by parliamentary committees. In the end, the decisions on most of them, including matters that are inquired into by commissions, are made by governments and debated here. That is as it should be; it is a democracy.
Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we are bound to take their answers. When we are, then we have government by royal commission, not government by elected representatives. That is not what I seek. Everyone seems to think that royal commissions are costless; they cost quite a lot of money. Those which have been under way in the last few years-I have just had a quick rule of thumb check of costs-have cost between $3m and $40m, some of them worth every cent. I am not saying that just because they are expensive they should not be held, but it is not something one does at whim. It is $3m of somebody else's money-the taxpayers' money. It is not to be thrown around at whim, and it becomes a lawyer's benefit. Very few other people benefit, but a lot of lawyers do, and some of them make a very handsome living at it. It also becomes an excuse for inactivity: `We will have an inquiry into this instead of doing something about it'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly the issue I want to turn to. How does this issue meet those criteria? Are there other forums in which this matter can be addressed? Firstly, there is the Parliament, and no-one could suggest that there has not been ample discussion and ample opportunity for all these concerns to be put on the public record here. It has been going on interminably, and Senator McLean has outlined quite articulately today, and on other occasions, the volume of material he has put before the Parliament.

There is the Martin Committee, which has very broad terms of reference. The terms of this urgency motion could never be the terms of reference of a royal commission, which would have to be drawn up in some detail, but any reasonable royal commission into bank practices would have terms of reference very similar in areas of inquiry and responsibility to those of the Martin Committee, which talk about choice and quality of financial services, product information, innovation, information to users, access to financial services, the effectiveness of competition, et cetera. Are consumers getting a fair deal? That is the subject of the inquiry. It is perfectly appropriate that Senator McLean should be going before it and putting his material there and that the people on whose behalf he has been making many of these submissions should be making submissions to it and appearing before it. And the Committee is making special arrangements to ensure those people do have the opportunity to appear.

The Martin Committee is specifically addressing these issues-as it should. One of the reasons it was set up was so that it could. Senator McLean last night, and again this afternoon, made it perfectly clear that he is aware that the Martin Committee is dealing with these matters because he sat in on it while it was doing so. He knows that this matter is under inquiry; that the specific matters of last night's debate have been brought before the Committee; and that the Committee has declined to return the relevant papers to Westpac and has indicated that, at the appropriate time, it intends to pursue the matter further, as I am sure it should.

There are also many other relevant forums but, particularly in this matter, there are the courts. There is the question of people's contractual relationships with their banks. When people have not received proper treatment in the implementation of a contract between themselves and their bank-in this case the bank not discharging its fiduciary duty, exercising the proper duty of care-the first and appropriate recourse is to the courts; that is exactly what is happening. I am advised that in a number of cases banks have already reached out of court settlements with clients. In some other cases people have been awarded damages by the courts in matters of the sort that are referred to here. It is not for me to comment on the appropriateness of those decisions; none of us can. I understand that they are under appeal, and that is appropriate too. Let us get the higher courts to determine the matter.

It seems an odd time to be talking about a royal commission in the middle of the courts' proposal to deal with appeals about decisions on the very matters under discussion, and where it is quite evident that the courts do have the capacity to deal with it because they are in the process of dealing with it. I do not think that royal commissions are something to be set up every time those on the other side are concerned that there is something important, and they are frustrated that they are not the government and therefore cannot deal with it in the way that they would wish. There are particular and specific circumstances that ought to apply before a royal commission becomes the appropriate vehicle of response, however important the matter in question, and these do not apply.

Let me go back to the question of the Martin Committee. The Chairman of that Committee, Mr Martin, has confirmed to me today that he feels in no way constrained or limited in his capacity to deal with the matters that have been raised here; nor should he, because they seem to me to fit the terms of reference. He has received submissions from the Foreign Borrowers Association and many of the individuals concerned. The Committee has determined to examine it as one of the major issues before the inquiry. As I said before, the Chairman of the Committee has the letter. He is currently keeping it private, but he has indicated that it is a matter the Committee will pursue.

As Mr Martin has said, Senator McLean and the Foreign Borrowers Association have been scheduled to appear before the Committee to raise exactly these matters, as they should. That is why the Committee has been established. I understand that special arrangements have been made in terms of hearings to facilitate people being able to appear.

I suppose that there are some limitations on the powers of any inquiry. It cannot rewrite history. There have been a lot of mistakes made that nobody can correct. That does not mean that they should not be inquired into, but the capacity of inquiries to redress past grievances is limited. That does not change because we turn it into a royal commission. Exactly the same limitation exists in the capacity to redress past grievances. An inquiry is appropriate but the appropriate forum for it at the moment is clearly, in the first instance, the Martin Committee; in the second instance, the courts; and, in the more general instance, the Parliament.

I think that it is fair to criticise the activities of banks during the last decade. It is my view that they failed many small and large customers by, for example, failing to discharge their responsibilities to be the second line of defence for business. When people make a borrowing decision within their corporation or their domestic situation, which is something that is beyond their capacity to service, they think that they have got it right but they expect their bank to check. Most of us around here know that if we went to borrow some money the bank would probably fairly promptly say to us, `On the salary you get, you cannot repay that loan, Senator'. Fair enough, but a lot of small and large corporations went to borrow money for projects which would never generate and have never generated the revenue to service the loan. They got money from the banks without the normal rigorous scrutiny that we are entitled to receive from our banks.

The banks are seeing that loss on the balance sheet, but perhaps not as much as they should because, when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) criticised them a year or so ago, there was some evidence that they were trying to keep up the margins on the customers who had survived to try to cream back some of the profits that they had lost by bad lending decisions. I think that that is a valid criticism of the banks. We do not need a royal commission to make it. We have already made it. The Martin Committee will be looking at that matter again, but the Treasurer has already made those comments in public. They are on the record. They are a proper matter of public debate. The banks have endeavoured to defend themselves.

I think that the banks could also be found guilty of stupidity in some of the decisions they made in what seemed to me to be a panic reaction to retain their market share when the foreign banks were allowed in. To rebuff the attempts by the new banks to move into the corporate sector and to retain their large clients, they made a lot of bad decisions to provide loans to those clients. We do not need a royal commission to find that out. A lot of liquidators around Australia are finding that out already, to the great chagrin of many and to the great damage to Australia's business reputation, as Senator McLean stated. I think that he is correct about that point. A lot of other people are to blame for that, not just the banks, but they must take their share. We do not need a royal commission to find that out. We know it all too well. I think that it is a cause of some concern that at the moment the banks are blaming everybody but themselves. They appeared before the Martin Committee and they laid the blame for the poor image of the banks and the economic consequences of their decisions at the feet of the Government, the dishonest entrepreneurs, the foreign banks, the decline of the Australian market, and even the media; everybody but the banks was to blame.

There were a lot of players in the game who need to share some of the blame, but there is not the slightest doubt that the banks are among them. We do not need a royal commission to find that out. We do not need a royal commission to tell us that the banks assumed that the asset boom was going to go on forever, that they could lend on the inflated asset values that people were placing before them and that somehow or other those projects were going to generate revenue to repay that loan.

There are quite a lot of grounds for criticism. In whatever time scale one likes, Australia's banks have done a lot of good things and a lot of bad things. A lot of people have thrived. A lot of businesses have been well served by their banks over many years. A lot of householders and depositors have been well served. A lot of others have been very poorly served. They are institutions made of human beings. They make mistakes and miscalculations and they do things they should not do.

In Australia at the moment we are in a situation where the Martin Committee, with broad terms of reference, is looking into the matter. What is it that the Martin Committee cannot inquire into or that the courts cannot deal with that a royal commission would? We have not heard anything about what the terms of reference of that royal commission would be, but by any reasonable stretch of the imagination, based on the urgency motion and the speeches of Senator McLean last night and today, it is hard to imagine what are the terms of reference of the royal commission that the Martin Committee, the courts and this Parliament, in terms of general debate, do not have the capacity to deal with.

I think that we need to be prepared to make criticism of institutions in Australia when they fail in their responsibility to the public, to their shareholders and to Australia as a whole. I do not think that the banks or other institutions have been exempt from that criticism. I think that at the moment they are feeling somewhat shellshocked. They appeared before the Martin Committee as if they felt that the world was picking on them. I do not believe that they are entitled to that view. Much of the criticism has been valid and the rest of it is certainly only that robust debate that goes with a democratic society and free speech in a democratic society. I value that and they should value it as well, even though we do not enjoy every particular piece of it.

We have an obligation in this Senate in public debate to apply some rigour to the demands that we make for the actions that need to be taken. In the demands for royal commissions that are made lightly and spread thinly around this country-as I say, distributed like confetti-we need to say, `Does this matter meet the tests that there are no other forums in which it can be debated and no other manner in which the necessary information can be made public?' Notwithstanding the importance of the issue, it manifestly fails that test and, therefore, there is no case for a royal commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an embarrassing situation we have today. I see there are not many people in the gallery and through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I welcome them here. I feel obliged to apologise to them for the embarrassing performance that they have had to witness. They have seen a senator invite two members of the Government-one a Parliamentary Secretary-and two members of the Opposition to prepare themselves for a debate on what he says is a matter of urgency, knowing that certain documents that he wants to rely on are not available although he said that he would make some extra effort to get them. The senator came in here, after everyone else had been wasting their time preparing for the debate, and said, `Oh, I think I will call this off. I cannot get the documents I want. There are some Westpac documents that I want and without them I cannot possibly debate this matter.'

SPEECH.PARA: This is an embarrassment for two reasons. Firstly, by his own admission Senator McLean admits his advocacy skills are so low that there is a matter of national importance which he cannot advocate be investigated without having a couple of extra bits of paper in front of him. It should be an embarrassment in itself that someone with advocacy skills so low has managed to slip himself into the Federal Parliament.

But the second embarrassment is that the senator has shown a gross discourtesy to other senators. He has basically said, `You can waste your time getting ready for this debate but I know in my heart of hearts that if I do not get my way and get these few extra documents, I will call the debate off at the last minute without letting any of you know'. What a monumental embarrassment and insult to this Parliament this exercise has been. Fortunately the situation has been saved by Senator Hill moving a motion to invite the senator to proceed with his case, whereupon the earlier suggestion that his advocacy skills might not be up to it was put to the test and quite rightly, as I estimated, failed.

Senator McMullan took up the point very well when he asked what case had been made for saying that the existing structures already in place in relation to these matters which the good, honourable senator-perhaps a bit less so today than yesterday-wanted to have investigated were not suitable. That is what I wanted to hear. Why is the Martin inquiry not satisfactory? I have some problems with that inquiry and I will deal with them in this debate. But why would other forums be unavailable to address the problem that the senator sees? Why are the courts inadequately addressing this matter? Let us have some evidence put before the Senate as to why the existing structures are inadequate.

Apart from this embarrassing start, we basically had no criteria in the motion at all. It was a case of, `Let's just have an inquiry into banking practices in general'. We were given no particular definition of what banking practices we should inquire into. Really, that was a bit substandard; one would fail a matriculation essay on the basis of, `Oh, you should have an inquiry into the banks'.

Senator McLean is required at least to spell out, as was not done in the motion, exactly what it is he wants to get to. I suppose we should have guessed that he wanted to get to banking practices as they relate to foreign exchange loans. That would have been a much more substantial motion to put before the Senate because we would all have known exactly what it was he wanted to talk about. In that case he might have got a debate he would have been more happy with. He was either not capable of doing that or he simply decided on a `This will do; she'll be right, mate' attitude, which should not be acceptable in this chamber. As I said, it is a monumental embarrassment.

We need to understand that this has just been a political exercise today by the Australian Democrats to create another opportunity to draw attention to the fact that the President has not allowed the tabling of what Senator McLean refers to as `these Westpac papers'. It is fair enough for the senator to want to go on television again tonight, wear his heart on his sleeve and say, `I tried yet again to get this information before the public and yet again I was refused, bleat, bleat, bleat'. As Senator McMullan pointed out, the bottom line is: in the two years that Senator McLean has been coming in here, pouring stuff onto the record, when has he come up with a substantive suggestion about what to do about these problems?

I do not see any articles from Senator McLean on how to deal with foreign exchange practices in the banks. I certainly do not see any articles from him in the things I read; I certainly have not seen any private member's Bills on how to handle it. As Peter Ward pointed out in the Australian, the crows are running round under the clothesline of politics, picking up the cake bits that are left, spitting a few out into the chamber and marching on, hoping to look after some narrow little interest. And they are not even looking after that properly. It is a disgrace.

What we wanted to hear, and what we did not hear, was anything about why only a royal commission could get to the bottom of this matter. Not only did we have this general motion-just assume for a minute that we had a specific motion on the practices of banks as they relate to foreign exchange loans-but we were not told why only a royal commission could deal with this. Senator McLean did not tell us where the Martin inquiry criteria are inadequate; he did not tell us why the courts would not be able to handle the problems that he sees; he did not tell us why the court system is inadequate.

It is not as if there is a lack of information on this material. I have turned my mind to an article by T. J. Valentine-thank heavens the days have gone when one would have assumed that it was `Mr' Valentine; it may well be `Ms'-entitled Critical Issues Arising out of the Martin Inquiry. T. J. Valentine works at the Sydney University of Technology and makes a number of very substantive points in relation to that inquiry and its inadequacies. These are summarised on page 12 of the article and I will briefly refer honourable senators to some of them. The point is made that there are important questions arising out of the terms of reference given to the Martin inquiry. As the author sees them, these are:
the Inquiry should look at the effect of deregulation rather than competition;
this examination should focus on all the effects of deregulation and not only on the direct effects on retail customers;
the Inquiry should consider the basic question of whether social reforms and redistributive policies should be implemented through controls on banks;
That seems to be the view of the Democrats. The author goes on to say:
the profitability of banking is a fundamental question for the Inquiry;
The author also says that specific interest rate margins are not in themselves very meaningful and makes the point that:
there are many influences on aggregate interest rate margins and it is unlikely to be profitable for the Inquiry to devote a lot of time to them;
Finally the author says:
the discussion of competitiveness is likely to be restricted to the retail sector and in the end will resolve itself into a discussion of the efficiency of current retail financiers.

That is just one person's view. But we had no evidence from Senator McLean that he had turned his mind to what could be done to improve the terms of reference of the Martin inquiry. We heard no reference to a recent conference on Australasian finance and banking in November 1990 where one of the keynote speakers, Professor Edward Kane of the Ohio State University, made such a substantive suggestion about what could be done. He suggested criminal liability for public officials who create the impression that a particular investment body is safe when it is not. That may be an unfair paraphrasing of what the good Professor suggested.

But I am trying to point out to the chamber that there are many articles around and plenty of informed views as to what could be done to improve banking practices in Australia. And yet we hear zilch from the Democrats in relation to this matter. There is no indication that they have read anybody else's views; they are just pushing their own barrow.

I have heard no indication from the senator who proposed this motion-and in fact no reference from Senator McMullan-to the Industry Commission inquiry, which put out an issues paper in February this year entitled Availability of Capital Inquiry. Under the Industry Commission Act, without limiting the scope of the inquiry, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has specified that the Commission should give regard to a number of things, one of which is the lending practices of the banking and finance sector. So one of the terms of reference of the Industry Commission inquiry specifies that, without limiting the scope of the inquiry, the Commission look at the lending practices of the banking and finance sector.

We have heard nothing from Senator McLean, who says we must have a royal commission into this, about why he is dissatisfied with what the Industry Commission will find out. That tells us that Senator McLean is pushing his own barrow. He has drummed up a broad term of reference for a matter of urgency to put forward today; he has not put the work into seeing what everyone else is doing; he potentially wastes the time of other senators getting ready for a debate; he marches in here and says, `I am not ready to go forward. I haven't got the material I need. My advocacy skills are not up to scratch. I cannot do it without that'; and tries to pull off the whole debate. It is a monumental disgrace.

Let me commence my conclusion by agreeing with Senator McMullan. When we call for a royal commission, not only should we have a very clear idea about what we want to have investigated but, once we have a very clear idea about that rather than some general ballpark idea such as that put forward by Senator McLean, there are three tests that need to be satisfied. One is that our area of interest is a matter of national interest. Obviously, the banking sector and its practices are a matter of national interest. They are of concern to all of us.

I wish the Australian Democrats, who by the direction of their preferences put not only this Government but also the Victorian Government in office, had had the courage to say in this debate that they are responsible for putting in office the Government some of whose spokesman told people in Victoria that their money was safe in Farrow and denied that there was any problem with Tricontinental and the State Bank of Victoria. These are the people that the Australian Democrats put in power in Victoria, and I do not notice them standing too closely behind them now. I do not blame them for running 100 miles from that decision. It was a very bad one and I hope they do not make it again next time. But no doubt they will be like bamboo in the wind seeking the greatest short term opportunity and probably make the same mistakes again.

I would like to hear the next speaker talk about Victoria and why the Democrats backed the State Government in Victoria, which they clearly did. In fact, they announced after the election that, but for them, the Labor Government would not have been elected. I can imagine how Victorians must feel about them now.

Everyone in here agrees that banking practices are a matter of national interest, but the second two criteria have not been met by this speaker and cannot be met by the next one. They have to show that there is no other suitable forum. Senator McLean is prepared to go before the Martin inquiry. I do not know whether he even knows about the Industry Commission one, because he has not mentioned it. I suspect that he does not. The next speaker might like to make some reference to that matter. The honourable senator may be able to peddle off his bundle of papers there and see how well he gets on.

Senator McLean has not made a case for there being no other forum for these matters to be addressed. He has not made a case for saying that information would not be available to anybody other than a royal commission. He has not made a case to say that the Parliament is ineffective in this matter and cannot get the information. Quite the opposite; he has told us that he has gone along and provided the information. He has given the Martin inquiry all this information. He is not prepared to wait and see what it says.

Senator McLean has not told us why the courts will be inadequate in this area. We know that what he has tried to do is get some information that the courts have onto the record here. He has actually made a case for us that the Martin inquiry has this information and the courts have this information. He has blown the third criterion right out of the water. He simply has not made his case.

This has been an embarrassing debate to participate in. For someone to put forward a motion so badly prepared and try to pull it off, then, under pressure from both sides, which have done the work and have prepared for this debate, put forward a limp wristed effort to say that there should be a general inquiry, a general royal commission, into banking practices without satisfying those three criteria is a monumental embarrassment, a disgrace and a waste of taxpayers' money. I hope the electors who cast their votes in favour of the Democrats think more carefully next time than they obviously did last time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a demonstration from Senator Vanstone justifying Senator McLean's suggestion that honourable senators need a little more information before they participate in this debate. Although the information was available, having been tabled and introduced by Senator McLean over a period of two years, Senator Vanstone asked a series of questions, and when she ran out of questions she resorted to political invective. She did not provide any matters of substance; she did not advert to the practices of the banks, which are the subject of Senator McLean's complaints. She did not have at her fingertips any of the details which have been tabled. She was not able to refer to any of the matters of substance which do, indeed, deserve a royal commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The integrity of our financial system is surely a matter of national importance, and Senator Vanstone has admitted that. She should have gone a little further and admitted that the banks are an integral part of our financial system. If the community cannot rely on the integrity of our banks, then clearly the financial system as a whole will collapse. The level of supervision of these banks by the Reserve Bank of Australia, by the Government, and by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in particular, is very much in question.

The collapse of the State Bank of Victoria, the collapse of the State Bank of South Australia, and the level of bad debts that the banks are now using as an excuse to continue to widen their margins to try to retrieve their profits from people who are placing their savings deposits with them are all matters that were always on the public record. The banks have certainly shown that they are inept and immoral, that they have contributed to the disaster of deregulation, to the boom and bust of our economy. We now know that it goes further than that. We now know that the foreign exchange speculation scheme was actually breaking down in the fiduciary aspect of banks, which they should observe. We know that the scheme was giving bank customers all the risk and the banks all the profits, and that the community was losing in addition because this was coupled with a tax avoidance system.

I now turn to the options we have as parliamentarians to take action on an issue of such national interest and importance. It was put to us that we could do it in Parliament-that we could pass motions, pass private member's Bills and do all sorts of things. Let us have a look at that proposition. We know that these measures have been on the table of Parliament for two years. We also know-and if Senator Vanstone had waited for the documents to be provided to her she would have been reminded of it-that Senator McLean actually wrote to the Minister for Finance quite early in this period of parliamentary action and that no action came forward in response from the Government, either from the Minister for Finance or from the Treasurer. Yet Senator Vanstone continues to claim that that is the proper action. Is she prepared to let her constituents wait for two years while the financial system falls about our ears? I do not believe that that is the right course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe she is.

—Maybe she is. Let us take a further step. Let us look at what Senator McLean is trying to do now. He is met by the claim of legal professional privilege when it is quite clear that it does not extend to statements in parliament, particularly not when they are made in the public interest. We are told that court proceedings have been instituted by the Westpac Banking Corporation to suppress the Government. Even if those proceedings were successful and the ruling went in Westpac's favour, it would not prevent these documents from being tabled in this Parliament under professional privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that the sub judice rule is in place to prevent Senator McLean from adverting to the documents that he wishes to introduce into this Parliament to ensure that action is taken. Yet this damage to any of the participants in an action must surely be weighed against the much larger issue of public interest, security and particularly the fiduciary aspects of our banking system. I believe that in this case it is quite clear that our parliamentary system is failing us.

I turn to the next possibility. We are told that we can go to the courts. Who should go to the courts? A parliamentarian? A senator? Why should we go to the courts when we have the forum here, which we should use in the public interest to get action on this particular issue? Should the people who have been swindled of their savings go to the courts? Will they get legal aid?

Senator Vanstone, as I am, is a member of the cost of justice inquiry. We have been looking at the fact that most people in the middle income bracket simply cannot afford to achieve justice in this country's courts. Maybe the people who have been swindled to the extent that they are very poor and have gone bankrupt can get legal aid and start legal action.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't. There is no access under commercial litigation.

—Senator McLean tells me that in this matter there is no access under commercial litigation. So the courts are basically closed. What do we do? We are told to go to the Martin inquiry, which has limited resources and a limited time frame and, I submit, does not address the terms of reference that need to be stated for this problem to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I will read some of the terms of reference under consideration for this royal commission which, on the basis of the facts and on the basis that no other action is possible, should be established forthwith: the nature of the fiduciary relationship that exists at law between a bank and its clients; the avenues of redress that may be open to a client who considers that a bank is in breach of its fiduciary obligations. We have just canvassed the possibility of doing it another way. Let these people use an avenue which we can provide. This Parliament can open the door. It can institute a royal commission into this problem of the fiduciary obligations of the bank, which so clearly have been broken.

Another term of reference is: whether any current or recent practices by banks may be viewed as contravening the fiduciary duties to clients; and the extent of any such practices and the action that should be taken by the Government to prevent them and to compensate those adversely affected by them. These are fairly general questions. No doubt, the Martin committee could address some of them.

Let us look at some of the specifics. To what extent have clients of Partnership Pacific Ltd or Westpac Banking Corporation suffered losses in respect of their foreign currency transactions as a result of the dishonest activities of Partnership Pacific or Westpac Banking Corporation? This is going fairly close to the bone, but these are the issues before us. They affect people who have been swindled of their savings. More than that, they affect the integrity of our banking system as a whole. What we, as parliamentarians, need to ask ourselves is: are we prepared to take effective action not only to assist those individuals who have suffered but also, perhaps even more importantly, to ensure that in future the Government, whichever government is in power, will take the necessary action to supervise banks and the financial system as a whole. This includes non-bank financial institutions, which the Government, at this stage, still refuses to acknowledge as its responsibility.

Through a private member's Bill I am trying to ensure that the Treasurer and the Reserve Bank of Australia accept responsibility for non-bank financial institutions. It is in the hands of parliamentarians to ensure that in future our banking system is run for the benefit of customers, the community as a whole, and that our financial system retains-I should say rebuilds-its integrity for the benefit of the community.

On this basis, I strongly support Senator McLean's call for a royal commission into these banking practices. He will submit to honourable senators further information which will enable them in due course to address the questions of substance which Senator McLean is raising rather than their descending into the sort of name calling that we witnessed before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

Senator McLean suggesting that this is a matter of urgency and then withdrawing it, clearly makes a farce of the word urgency. It is clearly not a matter of urgency at all; it is another Democrat political point scoring exercise.

As pointed out by Senator Vanstone, Senator McMullan is a parliamentary secretary. Senator Vanstone is the deputy chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. A lot of very valuable work is done there. Senator Cooney is the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

So indeed it is not a matter of urgency; it is just a part of Senator McLean's preoccupation with bank bashing, which is all that one can describe it as.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't listen to Senator Spindler.

This is the piece of paper I devoted to Senator Spindler-I got hardly one word out, and I think it was really nothing more than a doodle, which is how one could describe Senator Spindler's contribution to this debate. SPEECH.PARA: The problem with this motion is that it places all of the blame on the banks. It focuses attention for the ills of the Hawke-Keating Government on the banks. It has done so in a way that is not conducive to the public debate and to the very public interests that Senator McLean would have the people believe he so much protects. He is like Don Quixote, going around tilting at windmills.

As I have said, the problem is that Australia is in a deep recession. Farmers-the sorts of people Senator McLean refers to, who have had a problem with these foreign currency loans-receive letters every day telling them that their farms will be sold up and auctioned. Every day small businesses are closed down at enormous rates. Thousands of people are going on to dole queues. More often than not, they are receiving the bad news in an envelope--

TALK.START.PARA: —From banks?

—Exactly. Senator McLean should get up and give the speech for me; it would save me a lot of work. They receive them in window faced envelopes from banks. Thousands of people are going to their post offices every day dreading to get the bill from the energy commission or the water authority because those rates and charges have gone up and dreading to get the window faced envelopes from the banks. Thousands of people out there are getting bad news from the banks.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it is good politics to blame the banks because that is where they are getting the bad news from. That is the politics of it. Whether Senator McLean will admit it or not, he knows that that is the politics of it-and bank bashing is good politics. But it is not good for Australia. In his speech Senator McLean referred to the fact that these people who took out these foreign currency loans were not warned of the risks. That may or may not be the case; it is not central to this matter of the royal commission.
Senator Spindler, as the State President of the Victorian division of the Australian Democrats, claimed that he had been instrumental in getting the Labor Party elected in Victoria. That is great.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is matter of substance.

—That is a matter of substance. If the Trade Practices Commission looked into those sorts of warnings for the Australian electorate, there would be more than a royal commission: they would all be in gaol.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now been promised, and it was repeated in Question Time today by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, that we are going to have a recovery in the second half of this year-a recovery in spring. I guess the Democrats will probably believe that, too, and claim victory if they can help get this Labor Government re-elected again. The problem, of course, is that the deregulation of the banking system, which the Democrats cannot and do not want to understand and cannot support, was the right thing to do. It implemented the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, headed by Sir Keith Campbell. Treasurer Keating's trying to push the micro-economic reform agenda harder now and trying to put a bomb under the Government to get micro-economic reform up and running-obviously something he failed to do in the last three years-is so crucial because there cannot be one section of the financial markets and the economy deregulated when the rest is just tied up in regulation and red tape which do not allow this great country of ours to get moving and get our economy growing.

The coalition's solution is to have privatisation and deregulation and to allow Australia's enterprise and individuals to get working in synchronisation with a deregulated financial system. The Democrats' solution, if they can possibly come up with one-all they seem to be doing again is dribbling away with their ceaseless interjections, flouting the Chair--

TALK.START.PARA: —With urgency motions that they don't intend to put.

—That is right. It is good to have Senator Macdonald back here, exposing the Democrats for what they are. What is the Democrats' solution? Senator Powell is the new Leader of the Democrats: what a word to apply to this lady, Senator Powell-a leader. Don Chipp, the former leader, must weep to see what has happened to this party that he founded so many years ago, with all of the--

As Senator Powell, this failed Leader of the Australian Democrats, has said, her solution is to re-regulate-when the whole of the Australian political movement is towards deregulation. They are the only people who want to go the other way. They want to go back to the sixteenth century. They want to go back to Eastern European solutions and to Soviet solutions. They want to re-regulate. They can keep pushing that if they want to.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that there is no need for this royal commission. There is the Martin inquiry, which will do good work. As the Chairman of that inquiry said recently, and I am sure Senator McLean knows, it is an inquiry that will not bank bash. He said he was not in the business of bank bashing, but that is what Senator McLean wants. He wants a royal commission to go on his crusade of bank bashing.

Let us analyse Senator McLean's motives. For those of us who are here late at night during the adjournment debate, seeing Senator McLean's crusade by trying to table these documents night after night, year after year, he has had--

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have read them.
—You haven't read one.

—I will read what I choose to read and I certainly will not be told what to read by Senator Coulter or anyone of his ilk. I certainly would not read some of the diatribe that is produced by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: To get back to Senator McLean's motivation, he has had this two-year crusade. He has become a crusader. He sees himself as a crusader. He loves it. He likes the idea. He wants to make his mark on Australian politics by this crusade against the banks, and good on him. All of us have some issues that are close to our hearts and that we crusade upon. I have crusaded on a few myself. I am crusading to have some propriety in our appointment of ambassadors to foreign postings. I am crusading to make sure that the Australian Securities Commission works. I have got my own little crusades.

But I do not do what Senator McLean has done-and it is unfortunate that he probably does not realise it has happened to him, but it has. He has let it affect him personally. It has become part of him. He is no longer objective about this issue. It is now crucial to his performance in politics and to his political survival for this crusade to keep going and rolling and gaining momentum. It is like a train that is out of control. It has overtaken him. He has lost his objectivity and this bank bashing, which is gaining him cheap political points, no longer is serving the public interest that he says he seeks to serve. He has again shown the Senate and the people of Australia an example of that, because it has affected his integrity. He does not know it, but it has. When he said, in a throwaway line, that three State banks--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am prepared to listen to the psychoanalysis--
—What is the point of order, please, Senator McLean?
—The point is that Senator Campbell has just said that my integrity has been affected.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak on the same point of order. Senator McLean's integrity, or his lack of it, has nothing to do with a point of order. The issue is whether Senator McLean is making a proper point of order or a phoney one simply to inject a bit of debate. I ask him to come to whatever point of order he appears to be trying to make.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order, I understand that it is quite unconscionable for one senator to impugn the integrity of another, and Senator Campbell quite clearly impugned the integrity of my colleague Senator McLean.
—I have heard the three speakers on the point of order. It is unparliamentary to reflect upon any other senator's integrity, and I ask Senator Campbell to withdraw that aspect of his remarks.

—I withdraw. I want to conclude by saying that Senator McLean's reference to the failure of three State banks is something that he should perhaps reflect upon. I will not reflect on his integrity, and I have withdrawn that remark, but it is incumbent upon Senator McLean now to inform the Senate-I guess, by leave-what are the three State bank failures that he has referred to, because in his--
—Order! Senator Campbell, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two issues arise in this debate which, although closely related, are distinct and focus should be kept on that distinction. The first is whether banks have engaged in malpractice and, if so, what should be done about it. That issue has arisen because of allegations made against them on the basis of material brought forward by, amongst others, Senator McLean. He has been pre-eminent in bringing the conduct of Australian banks under community scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: The impression gained from what he has put forward is that banks have a case to answer, and he should be congratulated on that. If I may speculate as to the future, it is clear that the issue of how banks, and one in particular, have conducted themselves during the 1980s will become the subject of much scrutiny in the coming months. If at the end of that scrutiny they are seen to be what Senator McLean now alleges, then he will have achieved much for the community. Given the fact that there are investigations of banking institutions going on now and that, hopefully, fruitful material will come out of them, he should be congratulated on bringing that about.

The other issue is the process by which the allegations against the banks are to be dealt with. Included in that question is how the material to which I have referred is to be treated. I refer to the material that Senator McLean has tabled and put forward in this chamber, together with the letters that he has been prevented from putting forward.

Process may appear to be a dry subject but it is the cornerstone of civil liberties. Process involves the structure established to see that every person in this society receives fair treatment. Proper process includes the rules of procedures of parliaments and courts, guidelines for police investigation, rules of evidence, strictures on tribunals that they apply natural justice in their deliberations, a system of appeals, the need for investigators to obtain warrants to search property and people, and conventions directed to ensure that legislation acts for the benefit and not the detriment of citizens. There are others, of course.

The central concern in this debate is what is the proper process to deal with allegations made by Senator McLean. He says that a royal commission is the proper process. Ultimately it may or may not be, but the time is not yet ripe for that question to be determined. For a start, Senator McLean himself says that the letters he has been restrained from tabling are essential for a proper decision to be made. They are not available. The issue of what should happen about them has yet to be resolved. The courts have issued injunctions restraining their release to the public.

The courts cannot restrain the determination of Parliament and cannot restrain the processes and proceedings of this chamber. Quite properly, Parliament is independent of the judicial arm of government. On the other hand, the fact that it is independent does not mean that Parliament should ignore what the courts do. Our way of life, our civil liberties and our regard for our fellow citizens require that each of the three arms of government-the legislature, the Executive and the judiciary-should respect what the others do. If an unhappy strain is placed on the relationship between those three bodies, then our way of life is put at risk to a greater or lesser degree depending on the strain imposed.

In this case the courts have made orders restraining the use of two letters. Certainly it is within the power of this chamber to ignore those orders. Senator McLean-I heard him on this subject the other night and again today-has put forward powerful arguments as to why we as senators should ignore them. If we did, certainly we would place considerable strain on the relationship which the legislature has with the judiciary. There are times when that strain must be placed. The question is whether it should be in this case. I shall return to that topic a little later.

There is always a risk in calling for inquiries. I listened to a powerful address by Senator Kemp earlier today. He always puts his arguments powerfully and lucidly. He was discussing a call for an inquiry into the reporting of the Middle East war by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I think that there is great danger in Parliament deciding whether the ABC is biased and doing something that may affect its independence. There might be a case for that but if we call for and go ahead with inquiries into the ABC or bodies that should be independent of this Parliament, we will put considerable strain on the sinews that tie this community together. My view is that we should not interfere with the ABC in the present circumstances and that, if there is any case in which we should, it should be a very powerful case indeed. I raise that question to indicate that calling for an inquiry and going ahead with an investigation of particular institutions, although at times necessary, should only be done with the greatest of care.

The rule of law, the guidelines to our actions, suggested by social propriety and our sense of justice should work not only for the poor and the deprived and for middle Australians, but also for the rich and powerful. The rule of law is only a proper, universal and good rule of law if it operates for all sections of the community, be they high or low, powerful or weak, rich or poor. I am not saying that such a consideration has crept into this debate but if a proposition were put forward that Westpac or any other bank should not have the full benefit of the law because of its position of power in the community, such a proposition should be condemned. The problem with the legal system in Australia and with those who want to make use of it is not that the corporations and the banks, such as Westpac, can readily go to the courts and pay to do so. The problem is that those less powerful than Westpac cannot take that course.

The real scandal is not that the law is available to the rich and the powerful but that it is not as available, as it should be, to those who are not in that position. The failing of the law is not that it vindicates the rights of the rich and powerful but that it fails to do so in respect of those who are not.

The editorial in today's Sydney Morning Herald was based on material which Senator McLean has in my view properly put forward. It also referred to letters which he properly argued in this chamber he should be allowed to put forward. When he was not allowed to do so, he accepted that decision. So he has acted with propriety. The editorial stated:

Following that publication on January 29, and another report on January 30, determined measures were taken to stifle further public discussion. On January 30 Westpac moved the Supreme Court of NSW for orders restraining the publishers of the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age (which had also published details of the letters). Interim orders were readily granted by Justice Young restraining both newspapers . . .

I emphasise that word `readily' because the inference is that Mr Justice Young in some way was at the beck and call of Westpac, that in some way he did not do his duty, that in some way he ignored the public interest. The article continues:

Attempts by this newspaper-and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, which was made subject to similar orders-to have the injunction lifted have been firmly rejected, first by Justice Powell, and on Tuesday by Justices Samuels, Clarke and Hope sitting at the Court of Appeal.
Similar restraints were placed on other newspapers.

I simply say this: not only is the inference that Mr Justice Young has in some way failed to do his duty but so has Mr Justice Powell and the Court of Appeal. No matter what the delinquencies of Westpac may be and may hereafter appear to be, it seems to me to be lacking in propriety to suggest, without sufficient evidence, that the courts and the judges who occupy those courts have in some way failed in their duty and even, may I say, neglected the public interest in the interests of a rich and powerful institution in this land.

In that regard, if this chamber ultimately accepts the letters that Senator McLean clearly and so vehemently believes should be introduced, it should do so with proper respect to the courts which have considered the matter.

It seems to me that at some stage those letters will become available by some means or other. Without having seen them, it seems to be appropriate that that occurs. But that is a different question to the one we are talking about today, which is the proper process that should be used to bring this matter before the public.

Clearly, based on the injunctions issued by the courts, it would be certainly in my view inappropriate at this stage to have the executive arm of government-that is the only arm of government that can do so-introduce a royal commission. It is to Senator McLean's credit that he has worked as hard as he has in this area. But in my view, in pressing as he has for a royal commission at this stage, he has pressed too readily to rush into a situation which is not appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. As the mover of the motion that is before the Senate, Senator McLean has a right of reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the previous speakers for their contributions to the debate. I am conscious that some of them quite obviously found themselves with a lack of time and resources to adequately prepare for it. That was the difficulty that I was attempting to address earlier. However, we have had our debate and I would like to address some comments to the contributions of other senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I will start with Senator McMullan. The essential thrust of the arguments against this proposition that there be a royal commission focus on the fact that the inquiry into the Australian banking industry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-the Martin Committee -is in place. Essentially, it was being argued that it will do the job for us. I admit that in my discussions with Mr Steve Martin, the Chairman of that Committee, he has suggested the same to me. I disagree with that for reasons that I will elaborate on.

The fact is, I believe, that the Martin Committee has been convened to do other things. It may well be that, in that process, it will be revealed to it-and I would be very surprised if it is not-that there is sufficient concern and despair among Australians about the banking system as to warrant a royal commission. It may well be, as Senator Cooney just said, that that is an outcome. It may well be that the events of the past 72 hours and the debate in this chamber today will sharpen the focus of the Martin Committee on, particularly, managed foreign exchange loans. I am sure that evidence will come forward in the next few weeks that there has been rampant corruption in relation to that.

It may well be that today we have done no more than simply sharpen the focus of that Committee. But I still argue that such a committee is under-resourced. It has already said that it will have to extend its reporting period from six months to 12 months. Senator McMullan has already acknowledged that submissions have been pouring in. I went around Australia pleading with people to make submissions to the Martin Committee because I trust its integrity. I believe that it will sharpen its focus. I believe that it will finally lead to a royal commission into banking.

I accept Senator Cooney's proposition that, perhaps, the route to go along is by a public inquiry with a recommendation for a royal commission. I hope that today's debate has sharpened the focus sufficiently to ensure that as an outcome. But I still say that the Committee is under-resourced to perform the enormous task which it has in front of it. I still say that it is lacking in the expertise to do so adequately. In the last 48 to 72 hours alone-and I am not a lawyer-I have had to cope with an extraordinary barrage of legal argument. That will be the nature of what these people are up against. I do not believe that, with the best intentions in the world, with the best hearts and minds that they can bring to the inquiry, they have the sort of expertise that will allow them, with all the integrity in the world, to address adequately the magnitude of this challenge that they have before them.

Sadly, I must say that in the final analysis the Committee will produce a report that will come back to the Parliament and be politicised in exactly the same way as all of the propositions that I have brought forward to this chamber over the past two years have been addressed in political terms. That is what has happened to that material; it has all been addressed with political perception, political minds and political attitudes. Sadly, I think that will be the outcome of a report that comes back to a parliament. Only a royal commission will have the resources, the expertise, the detachment, the objectivity and the non-political perception to deliver to Australia what it needs in relation to this enormous challenge.

Senator McMullan said it can all be resolved in the courts. He should tell that to the people who have taken banks to courts. He should tell that to the thousands of bankrupt, demoralised and distressed people who have tried to take banks to courts. It is like sending good money after bad. The banks have got unlimited resources. They have got access to the best legal minds. They delay, they settle out of court. They extend the thing until people actually break under the strain of trying to resolve their problems in the courts. It is a futile exercise in most cases.

With the best intention in the world Senator Cooney, Senator McMullan and others may say that that is the way we should go. Senator Tate, as the Minister for Justice, has said that that is the way we should go, stating confidence in the judicial system, as he should. I frankly tell him that the human dimension of it is not like that. Let him tell Don Benson-who has been in my office over and over again and who cannot get legal aid because it is not available-to pursue commercial litigation. I interceded three times to Mr Wheeler, who would take the decision about legal aid, in saying that in the public interest Don Benson should be able to pursue his case in the court and get legal aid to do it. Last week he got a `no' answer.

Let him say that the courts are the way to go to Patricia Poulos who was told three days ago, when she went into court, by the judge that he would not consider her case unless she had legal representation. She stood in front of him and said, `I have spent $1m on legal representation trying to take on Westpac for years. I am broke. I am destitute. I am bankrupt and I cannot get legal aid'. He should tell those people that the courts are the way to go. I am sorry, the courts are not the way to go.

Senator Vanstone says, `Offer solutions'. I am an elected member of parliament representing constituents. I am not the Treasurer of the land. He is the one who is supposed to provide the solutions to a corrupt bank system. I do not pretend to have the solutions. I think the challenge is of such magnitude that it has to be addressed by not only a bank inquiry, but eventually a royal commission out of which, when we know the dimensions of the problem and the realities of the problem in a non-political, non-emotional sense, we might be able to formulate some solutions to a sick, corrupt bank system. It is pathetic for us to be asked here to stand up and provide the solutions.

I have pursued the matter, as Senator Campbell said, vigorously. I think he said I was on a crusade. Of course I am on a crusade. I do not apologise for being on a crusade, it is a very important one to be on. I do not believe that Senator Campbell has read one single word of what I have put before the Senate in the last two years. Frankly, it is absurd to think he stands up here and says that he is adequately prepared even to address the proposition. He attacked my integrity and it was withdrawn. I thank Senator Cooney for saying that he believes that I have acted with propriety for the last two years. I thank him for that. That is pretty important to me; it keeps me going.

When all this is said and done, I can give the Senate some names. None of this brings any joy whatsoever to the hearts of people like Batiste, Gilliland, Rigg, Blake, Corrye, Bayes, Benson, Somerset and Rahme. I could go on and name the 80 people whose cases I have tabled in this Senate. There is no joy for them in what they have heard here today, many of whom have been before the courts. Many have suffered broken marriages and many have lived with the consequence of trying to deal with the people who have prostituted their fiduciary obligations to clients. There is no joy in what we have heard today for those people. I have had thousands of phone calls on this issue. I have had hundreds and hundreds of letters. I will read one to the Senate that I got today. I read it just before I walked in here. It reads:
Dear Senator McLean,

I am writing to you primarily to encourage you to continue your efforts to see justice done in the ongoing saga of the ``Overseas Loans Affair''. It is heartening to myself and my wife that someone is prepared to stand up and be counted, and endeavour to see justice done against the corporate giants of our banking system.

Our own case is typical of so many of the cases involving small people. In 1984, I approached Westpac, Nowra for a loan of $250,000 to purchase a piece of farming land in South Australia for our daughter and son-in-law. The cost of the land was, in all, $360,000. I was told by the Bank that an offshore loan, in Swiss Francs, was ``the way to go'', as returns on rural land were low. I had no experience in this field, and had never heard of such loans. In fact, I had only borrowed small amounts of money for short periods of time prior to this. I had practised as a Dentist in Nowra all my life and had always banked with Westpac. I was subsequently told that the minimum loan was $500,000, that we had adequate assets, and I could invest the balance through the Bank and the loan would ``cost me nothing''! Being conservative people, my wife and I, after some deliberation, decided we did not wish to make money from the loan. At this stage the Bank manager was quite irate, and although finally agreeing to the reduced amount, said we would have to pay all costs etc., for both the original and new ``Facility Letter''. This we did and still possess these original documents, unsigned. The Loan was finalised for $250,000 on February 14th, 1985.

In spite of threatened penalties for early withdrawal, and the impact the whole affair was having on our health, we obtained a loan from A.N.Z. Nowra in August, 1986 and terminated our loan and all financial relationship with Westpac. During that 18 months we sought advice from Westpac officers in Sydney and Wollongong, but their attitude was deceptive, callous and non caring, and we were told to start liquidating our assets. It was a period in our lives we wish to forget.

As we knew in our hearts we had been wronged, we subsequently took action in the Supreme Court of N.S.W. Commercial Division, to recover our losses of some $330,000. We were encouraged by the Legal profession who felt we had a watertight case, and the Bank would settle ``out of court''. Of course it did not do so and employed top legal Council. After two days in the Witness Box, with no former experience in such happenings and deteriorating health, I withdrew from the case and subsequently paid Westpac expenses.
We now live a quiet lifestyle, our health has improved, but look back with horror on what occurred to us after a life of hard work.

We now know that similar experiences were had by hundreds of people around Australia from all walks of life, and whilst we may never see justice done in our own case, it is satisfying to know there are individuals like yourself who are prepared to pursue these matters.
With our sincere support,
Question put:
That the motion (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report into the death of Kwementyaye Price

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to speak on the next matter on the list, so I will not detain the Senate for long on this report. I simply rise to put on record that although reports of this nature come here regularly, the Senate has not become inured to the tragedy that lies behind these deaths. It would be a pity if the absence of comment upon this report was taken to mean that. If readers of the Hansard were to search through them in previous years, they will see that many speakers have spoken about this tragedy in Australian society. I simply note that this has not passed through without some comment.
