DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Inquiry into the death of the Aboriginal man who died in Darwin Prison on 5 July 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is a report into the death of a young man who died in custody on 5 July 1985, aged 26. The report shows that he had a most deprived life until the time of his death. What must be noted is that the death in this case and many others in prison-not only amongst Aboriginals but generally-occur amongst people whose background is deprived. We must be conscious of that fact and see that the remedy to a lot of the problems we have in gaols lies not simply in making the gaol a better place- although that is part of the problem-but in creating a society where everybody has an opportunity to take his or her proper place in the sun. I refer to page 4 of this report where it establishes what I am talking about. The report states:

The deceased was born in Townsville on 16 June 1959. His father was an Aboriginal man from Barambah (Cherbourg) Queensland. His mother, an Aboriginal woman, was from Cloncurry. The deceased was the youngest of five children. He, like some of the other children, took the maiden name of his mother. The parents were formally married in the European sense in 1985.
That is the year of his death. To continue:
His youngest brother, Walter, resided in the Mosman Hall Psychiatric Hospital in Charters Towers for a number of years and died there in 1986.
He was less than 26 when he died. The report continues:
He had one other brother and two sisters.

His father was an unskilled labourer who moved around a good deal in search of work. There is material from which one could draw the conclusion that the deceased's early life was difficult. He himself is reported as having said of his parents that both drank heavily and that there was a good deal of domestic violence. He was educated at State primary schools and left school at the age of 14 having completed Grade 7. He spent some time at least in an opportunity class.

Page 12 of the report, going on to page 13, gives the reasons for his being in gaol. They were all matters which arise from an inability to live a happy domestic life free, from drinking and from such things, all of which are consistent with a childhood and a young adulthood when he did not receive the proper example of how a happier life could be led. What comes out of this report, and many others, is the fact that the society in which we all live does contain glaring injustices which must be cured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the comments made by Senator Cooney, in general terms. He has outlined the tragic circumstances that have been recorded on the death of this particular Aboriginal person. Having had some experience of working with Aboriginal people and knowing first hand of their difficulty in accommodating themselves to our legal system, which is entirely foreign to their culture, I believe that so far at least we have made insufficient provision in our legal system to accommodate the cultural values and the heritage of Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: Shortly, the Senate will be considering legislation which seeks to attempt in one small area to engage in positive discrimination. I wish to say even now that the Australian Democrats will support that positive discrimination treatment of Aboriginal people, and that we should attempt to extend that into other areas of our legal and administrative systems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to congratulate Australian Defence Industries Ltd (ADI) on this first report that it has made since it was set up in 1989. It took over the defence production operations of the Department of Defence on 3 May 1989, and so this report for the year 1989 to 30 June 1990 is on its first year of operations. It has a very pleasing result, being able to report having made a small after-tax profit in this first year of its operations. It is engaging already-and this is detailed in the report-in a major restructuring process. That has not been completed, so the fact that it was able to turn around what was a very heavily subsidised operation by the Defence budget into an operating profit without having completed that restructuring is a matter for congratulation of the new management and of the board.

The company still has a very large task ahead of it in carrying out the restructuring operation from what was clearly a very inefficient operation. Indeed, the report notes that in the last five years of operations under the Department of Defence there had been a loss-in the shape really of a subsidy for its operations-of over $1.3 billion. That is an indication of the task that has been presented to this company. It is already showing good results.

The Chairman of the company, Mr Fynmore, notes in his report that this restructuring will be a rehabilitation exercise after many years of supervision by a succession of Government departments-I think he means largely by the Department of Defence. Of course, the obvious question that arises from this experience of the company and from the report-as clearly outlined here-is the fact that the operation of the former Defence factories production facilities was very inefficient. If that is now clearly established by this experience of commercialising these operations, one must ask how many other Defence related facilities will be labouring under the same poor management. It is quite clear that there is a major task of restructuring many aspects of the Defence Force's infrastructure. It will be a daunting task but it extends from logistics supply to communications and maintenance operations.

It is a task that simply must be undertaken. This report indicates that it can be successfully turned around from loss making to, as I said here, even a small profit. So the message of this report is that there is an urgent need for the Government to tackle this problem and, although it is being tackled in relation to this particular Defence function, it needs to be tackled in many other areas.

There are a couple of matters that arise out of the report that the Government has to tackle quickly. One is the capital structure for ADI, which has taken over many properties and production facilities but is burdened with a loan from the Government to cover those assets. The loan is interest free, but it is not a very satisfactory way for a company's capital structure to be commenced. The Government really must get onto solving that. The other matter relates to the restructuring process. I believe that the company is on the right track with this process and it should be supported by the Government in its efforts to implement what is a very difficult and, in many cases, sensitive process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling of this report is very timely, coming so soon after the speech by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to the National Press Club in February in which he said that a major lesson for the future relates to the need to control and reduce the international arms trade. I realise that much of the output of Australian Defence Industries Ltd (ADI) is geared to the requirements of the Australian Defence Force, but it has also been a component of the Government's push to double military exports. For example, at the Asian Defence Services Exhibition in Bangkok in December 1990, ADI was advertising its latest mortars, promising `a 25 per cent increase in lethality'. At this exhibition there were 200 companies from 24 countries, while customers included the infamous Chief of Intelligence of Burma's military junta and a representative of the Cambodian guerilla army. Given the concern of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade about Myanmar and Cambodia, I find it ironic that ADI was peddling its wares in the company of such customers.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister for Defence is reconsidering his Department's support for the Australian International Defence Export Exhibition 1991 in Canberra this November, then perhaps he should also consider the Department's active support for arms bazaars in the region. Conversely, arms bazaars, which used to be commonplace in northern hemisphere countries, especially North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, have often been cancelled owing to community pressure. So a major arms race is under way in our region, the same region where `the threat ` to Australia is supposed to come from, and here we are peddling our mortars and other military equipment.

Only last year the United States of America Arms Control and Disarmament Agency pointed out that South East Asia was emerging as the growth area for world arms transfers, having increased its share of the world total from 6 per cent of arms sales in 1977 to 23 per cent in 1987. That is quite a big jump. The Middle East is an obvious exception. Australia wanted to get in on this market as well. Following the South East Asia industrial mission in December 1988, Australian Defence Industries opened its first overseas branch in Kuala Lumpur in March 1990. It is interesting to note that the Manager was formerly Defence Attache at the Australian High Commission in Kuala Lumpur.

Another dispute concerning ADI during the past year has been in regard to its efforts to sell 76 millimetre ammunition to Sri Lanka, a tragic country torn asunder in recent years by a bloody civil war. Fortunately, Senator Ray stepped in to stop the sale last July after details were leaked to Channel 7, but it should not have ever got to that stage. Another ADI product which the management hopes to promote is the rifle pictured on page one of this report, the Austeyr F88 assault rifle. The company has rights to sell this weapon in the Asia-Pacific region as well as other parts of the world, although I note that in terms of exports it has so far sold some 18,000 to New Zealand, as indicated on page 11 of this report, and that has been its major market.

In economic terms, I realise that ADI made a profit this year, as Senator Durack said, but the trade journal Defence Industry warned in December last year that individual enterprises are having much more difficulty than was first anticipated in translating defence related production skills into defence related exports. According to Trevor Thomas, editor of Defence Industry, this is particularly the case because of the shrinking of the international defence market, forcing a concentration of overseas competition into the South East Asian region, originally considered of significant potential for Australian companies.

The Managing Director noted the difficulties of sales in South East Asia in his review of operations on page four, confirming the Defence Minister's warning that detente in Europe would mean a flood of arms into South East Asia. This is not something that I think we should be happy about. I welcome the Defence Minister's concern about the international arms trade. However, I point out once again the contradiction with his desire to promote defence industries in Australia which can only keep prices down by exports. This economic logic, of course, applies to all other companies in this field around the world, so I suggest that ADI could usefully look at ideas for economic conversion in the year ahead with a view to transforming its image and producing socially useful goods for export.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-DECEMBER 1990SUPPORTING APPLICATIONS OF ISSUES FROM THE ADVANCES TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-DECEMBER 1990ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-JANUARY 1991SUPPORTING APPLICATIONS OF ISSUES FROM THE ADVANCES TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-JANUARY 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.
I would like to make a few comments on the Advances to the Minister for Finance for December 1990 and January 1991 and the supporting applications for the issue from those Advances.

On numerous previous occasions I have noted with concern the use increasingly made in recent years of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for purposes which I think can very well be argued are contrary to the legal position so far as the use of the Advance is concerned. Advances to the Minister for Finance are supposed to be only for payments which are `unforeseen and/or urgent'. There have been numerous examples in recent years where those criteria quite obviously have not been met.

Over several years now we have had examples of payments to the States under special deals made around the table at the Premiers Conference in June each year. In all instances these deals have been made with States that have Labor governments; the three States concerned being Western Australia, South Australia, and Victoria. In all those instances, deals have been made under the table at the Premiers Conference. The funds have been allocated, so-called urgently, despite the fact that the requirements for them have been known for some considerable time.

The significance of putting the payments through the Advance to the Minister for Finance is that they escape much of the normal public scrutiny of expenditure by the Government which occurs if the normal Appropriation procedures are followed. I take this opportunity to call again on the Government to look very closely at the legality of what it is doing in its use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

The documents before the chamber also highlight some of the extra payments that the Government did not anticipate at the time it drew up the 1990-91 Budget. For example, the figures contain an amount of $22.1m, which has been paid through the Advance to the Minister for Finance for the Australian Tourism Commission to produce and run television and print consumer advertising programs in Australia's key overseas tourist markets.

Whilst welcoming that very worthwhile initiative-and the Opposition supported and welcomed it at the time-it is important to note that it is a very large amount of money. It should have been subjected to the normal budgetary consideration processes. But I find it quite incredible that the Government did not include it in its August 1990 Budget, which was delivered only four months prior to the Government's decision to make that payment in December. I think this is yet another example of the way in which the Government is demonstrating at the moment a total lack of fiscal responsibility and, even more seriously, a level of incompetence in the management of its financial affairs.

Yesterday in the Senate Senator Cook said, `We have already run a very, very tight fiscal ship'. If this sort of payment to the Tourist Commission-and there are many others in the Advances to which I could draw the chamber's attention had I the time-is any example of the Government's definition of `very, very tight', it is no wonder that the Budget for this year has unravelled to the enormous extent that it has. It is no wonder that the Australian economy, as a result of that plus other mismanagement by the Government of its policies-let alone the policies themselves-have brought the Australian economy to its knees.

I would mention one other payment in the time available, and that is the extraordinary act of grace payment to Australia Post of $15,294 for outstanding accounts for postal services provided to members of Parliament prior to 3 May 1990. The supporting application from the Department of Administrative Services to this payment says:
Following advice from the Attorney-General's Department on 18 May
this Department ceased payments to Australia Post on behalf of members who had expended in excess of their $9,000 entitlement.

The Senate will recall that Parliament has had considerable debate on the extraordinary payments made just prior to the last election by way of increased postage allowances to members of the House of Representatives. Quite obviously, those payments were made to Labor members in the many marginal seats held at that time to enable them to flood their electorates with the additional postage. The payment was subsequently ruled illegal by the High Court of Australia.

Why would the Attorney-General's Department advise the Department of Administrative Services to cease making these payments to Australia Post in the way that it did? The answer would appear to be that Attorney-General's was obviously advising caution until the matter was settled. This was despite the Government's assertions in response to questioning last year by the coalition that its decision to write off the amounts was based on the Solicitor-General's advice that the Government was legally able to do so. That advice, of course, was subsequently produced into the Parliament, very belatedly after continual pressure from the Opposition.

However, I note this payment; I have only just come across it in the last couple of hours and it is certainly something I will pursue because it looks very odd. I believe it is another example of the way in which the Advance to the Minister for Finance is being used to cloak the normal, proper public scrutiny of the use of taxpayers' money. These statements should be subject to much greater scrutiny than they are. They should be used much more properly than they are. I believe it is a subject that warrants the continuing attention of the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO SWEDEN, FINLAND, NORWAY AND DENMARK

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Sweden, Finland, Norway and Denmark. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Having been a member of the delegation that went to Scandinavia, my greatest recommendation to honourable senators is that if they get the opportunity to become a member of such a delegation at any stage they should do so. The delegation visited Scandinavia between 20 October and 9 November. It was certainly a most educational, enjoyable, politically advantageous and interesting visit. The countries, while all have relatively small populations, have had a fairly wide influence throughout the world over a long time. Quite a number of Australians originated in those countries. The people are very compatible one with another, and from the point of view of tourism the countries are attractive to one another also. It is noticeable that, amongst the Swedes alone, 40,000 come to Australia every year. Socially, the Scandinavian standards have been promoted widely. Scandinavia has often been referred to as a workers' paradise, and many social issues that have been discussed and implemented around the world reputedly come from the Scandinavian countries-for richer, for poorer.

In all of the four countries it was noticeable that the wages were very high-much higher than in our country-as was unemployment. They were in the phase of a decline in manufacturing as a result. Their governments have heavy industry support, and the economies of all the countries are still basically dependent on primary industry. They have specialised in high quality, high-priced goods, and they have done that very well. Everything there was very expensive to us. For instance, we noticed that items such as a fairly average quality lunch would possibly run to the order of $70 to $90 Australian.

The social benefits payments are very high and, of course, that brings with it quite high abuse in a system of such a nature. For instance, in discussion with officials of the Stockholm City Council, which employs 70,000 people, we were told that at any stage they would have 24,000 people absent. The other half of that is that the employees do not have to check in until they have been off work for five days. That means that from Sweden one could go to the Swiss Alps for 10 days-leave on a Friday night and come back the following Sunday week-without the need to notify the employer of the absence. As a result, the economies in the area are struggling. We have the same problems that they have; they have been doing it a little longer than we have. It is very difficult to maintain incentive and national debts are very high.

We visited the parliaments of all four countries. Their systems are quite different from ours and, of course, quite different from one another-except that they are all unicameral parliaments and in each case they have varying degrees of proportional election. I found it quite interesting that they do not have the Westminster type of seating with the adversarial arrangement that we have. They usually have a semi-circular parliament with the President or the Speaker, or whoever it is, in the middle of the long wall. I found it interesting that in one of the parliaments the members sit according to their electorates and not according to their parties. It would probably be advantageous in many cases in that people would treat the person beside them a lot more courteously than they treat the person opposite them, as in our situation.

We visited the submarine project and looked at the progress that has been made on our $3.9 billion six submarine project at Kockums. We inspected paper mills and took a particular interest in the question of waste disposal, so that we were able to provide better advice, or better comment, about what is likely to happen with future pulp or paper mills in Australia.

We then visited a business the whole function of which is waste disposal. We found that a most interesting project. It is a business that I would dearly love to see come to Australia and, if possible, be established here on some sort of joint venture arrangement. As a result of the visit, I have had discussions with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and arranged contact between the people involved at both ends. I am looking forward to the Finns coming to Australia to follow that up.

We visited schools in both Sweden and Denmark and were most impressed with the way that they were operated, as distinct from ours, particularly the one in Denmark. It was very much a community centre. It operated from 7.30 a.m. to about 11 p.m. It dealt with students from the age of about 14 upwards. It had a complete integration of all types of courses. It included not only the school library but also the municipal library, all in one. It had theatres; it had training areas for senior management people; and a 25-unit motel was attached for visitors who went there for courses so they could reside on the premises while they were working. One of the big advantages of this is that it prevents the gap that is created when students move from one place of education to another. From the time that students get into reasonable secondary education they are able to stay in the one place until they have finished. It also provides them with excellent training facilities; it has a mixture of everything from engineering to acting. The whole thing was most impressive. There is a considerable amount that the Scandinavians could teach us.

We visited a sports institute. We were given a taste of the country's culture. We were taken to see Tosca at the Royal Opera House in Stockholm. We went to the ballet Midsummer Night's Dream in the Copenhagen Royal Theatre. We saw the viking ship museum and many other things. I was particularly interested in a gentleman called Mr Tapio Perianen, the director of the Finnish Society of Crafts and Design. He has done an enormous amount to improve the way things are done in the manufacturing of furniture, fabrics, ceramics and glassware. He is interested in better design and better construction. It is really most interesting to see the result this has had in the community at large. A few years ago this gentleman went to Tasmania. He made a great impression there. He has helped people in these areas very considerably. I would like to think that he could come back to see the results of the seeds that were sown by him at the time.

The agricultural system of these countries must be mentioned. After Japan, Finland and Norway are the two most highly subsidised agricultural countries in the world. The average subsidy for every farmer in Finland is over $A25,000. I understand this because Finland wants to keep its farmers in the country. It does not want them to drift into the towns. The only way that this can be done, with land that is rather poor and not capable of very high production, is to pay them virtually a social security payment. This is done by assisting production. This does not suit us but I understand why it is done. The same thing applies in many of the other European countries such as France, Germany and Austria. The success of the Uruguay Round seems to be a long way off when one understands the circumstances behind it. Whilst this does not suit us, I understand the view and accept it.

We visited many beautiful buildings and we enjoyed lovely scenery. We were most impressed by the way our two ambassadors, Ian Nicholson in Sweden and Jeff Benson in Denmark, assisted us and by the very high standing they had in their communities. I understand that Mr Benson has now come back to Canberra. They had a very good reputation. It is very good to go overseas and see that our representatives are so highly thought of.

The hospitality of the countries that we went to was absolutely tremendous. The way that they looked after us, transported us and entertained us was excellent, as were the hotels. It was a wonderful 20 days. As I have said before, I recommend to anybody who can get a trip like this to do so. What was important and what greatly assisted was the fact that the group was most compatible. Caroline Jakobsen was a good leader and Peter Grundy an excellent manager and secretary.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The speeches read as follows-
CRIMES (INVESTIGATION OF COMMONWEALTH OFFENCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

In 1986 the High Court decided the Williams case (161 CLR 278), in which the central issue was whether, after his arrest, the suspect was detained longer than was reasonably necessary to enable him to be brought before a magistrate. He was arrested early one morning. The police were satisfied that he was responsible for several burglaries in the northern area of Tasmania. The relevant State law provided that he should be taken before a justice as soon as practicable. At the police station he was questioned both about the crimes in respect of which he was arrested and about a number of other crimes, and he made a number of admissions. He was eventually charged on 26 counts in relation to those other offences, as well as the crimes for which he was arrested. He was taken before a magistrate at 10 am the following morning.

The trial Judge was satisfied that the confessions were voluntarily made, but in his discretion, he rejected them. He held that Williams was wrongfully detained because he was subjected to lengthy questioning about matters other than those for which he was arrested. The High Court, however, held on appeal that ``as soon as practicable'' gave no power to question an arrested person about the offence for which he had been arrested or other offences and did not make justifiable a delay which resulted only from the fact that the arresting officer wished to question him. It had previously been taken for granted that an arrested suspect could be questioned about an offence in the course of deciding upon a charge or charges before taking him or her before a magistrate.

This decision has created a real and serious dilemma for me. I come to the Parliament with two important competing responsibilities: my responsibility to maintain and defend the civil liberties which we have inherited through the centuries in our common law, and my responsibility to ensure that the laws made by the Parliament are able to be properly enforced, so as to afford appropriate protection to the community. Law enforcement agencies cannot be expected to function effectively with their hands tied behind their backs. Not only must they be able to investigate and prosecute offences effectively, but they need to ensure that they do not proceed to invoke the inexorable machinery of prosecution against a suspect, with all the suffering and expense for the person that that entails, when an early period of questioning and investigation may disclose that prosecution is not justified.
The solution which satisfies me, and which I trust will satisfy the Parliament, appropriately balances these competing interests in a just and equitable manner.

That solution, which I find most fair, balanced and workable, is to provide for a maximum period during which an arrested person may be held for questioning or investigation before being taken before a magistrate. Within that maximum is a defined ``investigation period'' which is a period of active audio/video-recorded questioning or investigation regarding the relevant offence or offences, reasonably appropriate in the circumstances of a particular case.

The specified period is a maximum period in which a person may, unless a longer period is authorised by a magistrate, be held in custody before being brought before a magistrate. I emphasise the word maximum. It is not a period during which the police may simply hold the person; even within that period the time for which the person is held must be reasonable in the circumstances of the case. Any gaps in time apparent from the audio/video-recording would need to be stringently accounted for, even though occurring within the permitted maximum, though some provision may be made for ``dead time'' which I will explain later. As well as the tape-recording, other safeguards are built in-communication with friend, relative and legal practitioner, a right to have the latter present during the investigation period, and special protection for vulnerable groups which I will go into later.

If an extension of the investigation period is required, which I would expect on the basis of experience in other jurisdictions to be rare, it may be granted for a further finite period up to 8 hours, by a magistrate, or, where a magistrate is unavailable, a justice of the peace, who must be satisfied that this is justified in the particular circumstances of the case. The suspect is entitled to make representations to the judicial officer. Where an extension application is made by telephone or other electronic means, procedural safeguards similar to the usual provisions relating to telephone applications for search warrants must be complied with.

Any periods of custody of the same person within any 48 hour period, whether for the same or different Commonwealth offences, must, in the aggregate, be within the relevant permissible investigation period. Briefly, that is the outline of my proposal.

In reaching the position I have just put before you I surveyed, and will share with you, the background against which the issues dealt with in this Bill arise, the work already done in the area by others, and the efforts of other jurisdictions to solve the dilemma.

As you are aware, section 68 of the Judiciary Act 1903 applies the law of the particular State or Territory in respect of the arrest, custody, examination and trial of persons apprehended for Commonwealth offences.

The laws of the States and Territories are becoming increasingly diverse and based on different approaches of principle. This is particularly apparent in the area of post-arrest procedures where there is wide variation in the degree of safeguards provided by legislation extending the permissible period of pre-charge detention. Further divergence is likely to be created by the introduction of corresponding legislation in the remaining jurisdictions. The various State and Territory legislative measures taken regarding pre-charge detention were mainly introduced, as is the present Bill, to deal with the problems crystallised in the Williams case.

The result of that decision is that, subject to the exception I will mention later, where a confession is obtained from a suspect while he or she is in police custody after the time when it has become reasonably practicable to bring him or her before a magistrate, that confession is liable to be rejected in the discretion of the trial Judge as having been unlawfully or unfairly obtained. The exception is where legislation, either Commonwealth or applied State or Territory legislation, lays down a different rule.

Four of the five Judges in the Williams case refer to the need to strike a balance between the requirements of effective law enforcement and the long-standing common law protection of personal freedom. They express awareness, too, of the difficulties presented by complex investigations. In this context Mason and Brennan JJ in their joint judgment point out that ``if the legislature thinks it right to enhance the armoury of law enforcement, at least the legislature is able-as the courts are not-to prescribe some safeguards . . . '' (at 296). Wilson and Dawson JJ also recognised that the policy issues involved were properly the province of this Parliament. They said: ``if the law requires modification then it is better done . . . by legislation for there must be safeguards, if necessary in the form of time limits, and they must be set with a particularity which cannot be achieved by judicial decision'', (at 313).

The questions which I, and the Parliament, have to face are, first, whether we should move at all to alter the effect of the decision of the High Court in the Williams case, and secondly, if we do so, what should be the manner of the intervention, best to balance the community's interest in effective law enforcement and the interest in maintaining high standards of criminal justice in which individual rights are given appropriate protection and respect.

Law and practice in this area have been uncertain and unsatisfactory since well before the Williams case. In 1975 the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report on criminal investigation noted that, although the common law principle that an arrested person must be brought before a magistrate without unreasonable delay had been given statutory expression in most jurisdictions in Australia, the words used to delimit the permissible time period were variable and imprecise. Judicial interpretation of a permissible time ranged from holding ``forthwith'' to mean exactly that in Drymalik v Feldman [1966] SASR 227 (that is, no time at all for interrogation, similar to the Williams position) to holding permissible a time which extended several hours after it became practicable to bring the person before a magistrate, in R v Banner [1970] VR 240.

Police practice was similarly variable, and the Law Reform Commission found that one of the most frequently voiced complaints against the police was unnecessarily prolonged custody, in some cases up to 3 days on minor public order charges.

The Law Reform Commission recommended that there should be a precise time limit set for police custodial investigation. It set this at 4 hours with some provision for ``dead time''. ``Dead time'' means those periods of time which it is considered appropriate to exclude from the calculation of the investigation period, as they are all periods when investigations should not, in fairness, take place. They include direct travel time to the police station, time arranging communication with family, friend or lawyer, and time spent waiting for the attendance of a lawyer or prisoner's friend. They also recommended provision for extension of time, in appropriate circumstances, by application to a magistrate, (by telephone if necessary), in no circumstances to exceed a further 8 hours.

The Commission was well aware of, and gave careful consideration to, the objection that any acceptance of post-arrest investigation is undesirable because it is a retreat from the common law principle that arrest marks the point of executive commitment, when there should be a reduction, not an expansion of police power, and when the Judicial arm should take over as soon as possible.

Subject to the dissent of Mr F G Brennan, QC, as he then was, who would have preferred to increase police powers prior to, rather than after, arrest, the Commission felt that this argument was outweighed by other considerations.

In September 1988 the Committee Reviewing Commonwealth Criminal Law chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs, was asked to report specifically on the issue of detention of a suspect by investigating officers for the period necessary to complete an investigation, and on the issue of introducing a requirement that confessions be tape-recorded. The Committee's report was presented in February 1989.

In the course of its deliberations the Committee considered the history of the responses to the problem in other jurisdictions. There are essentially two approaches to defining a period of pre-charge detention. One involves providing a reasonable investigation period within a specified maximum period, (with or without allowance for ``dead time''), usually with provision for its extension by application to a magistrate in appropriate circumstances. The other allows a reasonable period of pre-charge detention and provides statutory criteria to define those matters which may be taken into account in deciding what constitutes a reasonable time in all the circumstances of a particular case.

Victoria provides an example of the actual operation of both approaches. The history of the Victorian legislation began in 1983, even before the High Court's decision in the Williams case, after confessional evidence had been held inadmissible in several cases as having been obtained during a period of unlawful detention.

A committee was appointed, chaired by the then State Director of Public Prosecutions, now Mr Justice Phillips, to address the problem. That committee recommended legislative amendments to provide for a maximum period of six hours, which could be extended on application to a magistrate with the consent of the arrested person. These recommendations were put into effect by amendments to section 460 of the Crimes Act 1953 (Vic) in 1984.

After a period of close monitoring, the police compiled a report detailing a number of deficiencies in the operation of the amendments, and the consultative committee was reconvened under Mr Coldrey QC, Mr Phillips' successor as Director of Public Prosecutions, to examine the effectiveness of the amendments.

The Coldrey Committee recommended that a reasonable time be substituted for the specified maximum period, and that practical criteria be provided to guide the courts in assessing the conduct of the investigators. The maximum period was considered insufficient for major investigations into complex crimes and multiple offences. It also required the interruption of the continuity of the interview or investigation to seek an application for extension of time, and, generally, lacked flexibility. The committee's recommendations were enacted in 1988. It should be noted that the Victorian fixed time provision made no allowance for ``dead time''.

The law as it stands at present, as is reflected in the conclusions of all the committees which have published reports on the issue, manifestly fails to take into account the legitimate needs of the police in their investigations of crime, particularly of complex and serious crime. It is necessary to make provision in the system for the realities of police investigatory requirements.

Both the Law Reform Commission and the Gibbs Committee were well aware of the concern that by providing for a lawful period of custodial detention there might be a tendency for the maximum permissible period to become the norm, thus endangering civil liberties.

Mr Coldrey QC, in his report of April 1986 on the Phillips amendment to section 460 of the Crimes Act 1958 (Vic), quoted research findings on a similar Scottish provision for a fixed maximum of six hours pre-charge detention, in operation since 1980. The findings were that the average time a suspect spent at the police station, despite the permissible six-hour maximum was 2 hours and 15 minutes, 20% spent less than one hour and 50% of all detentions lasted less than two hours. Coldrey found that over 99.5% of investigations under the Victorian provisions took place within the six hours but no break-down of figures within that period was available.

Having reviewed the legislative and case-law history of the pre-charge situation, the Gibbs Review Committee formed the clear opinion that the law should provide investigating officers with a reasonable opportunity to interrogate an arrested person, and conduct other necessary investigations, before taking the arrested person before a magistrate. It quoted Wilson and Dawson JJ in the Williams case as recognising that ``the restrictions placed by the law on the purpose for which an arrested person may be kept in custody have on occasions hampered the police, sometimes seriously, in their investigation of crime and the institution of proceedings for prosecution. And these are functions which are carried out by the police, not for some private end, but in the interests of the whole community'' (at 312).

The Committee pointed out that the questioning of suspected persons is not in itself an evil, but a necessary and very important part of law enforcement. Objection can only be taken to the use of compulsion to answer questions and to unfair or oppressive methods of questioning, and it is these risks associated with extended pre-charge detention that the safeguards in the proposed legislation address.
Recommendations of the Review Committee relating to safeguards which are reflected in the Bill include the following:

provision for the customary caution that the person in custody does not have to say, or do, anything, but that anything he or she does say or do may be given in evidence, the caution to be given in, or translated into, a language in which the person is fluent, where necessary;

provision for the person, before the commencement of questioning or investigation, to communicate with a friend or relative, and with a lawyer, and for a lawyer to be present during investigations involving the arrested person, subject to some specified conditions;
special provisions for the protection of young persons, foreign nationals and Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders;
provisions requiring persons in custody to be treated with humanity and respect for human dignity, and prohibiting cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment;
provisions requiring electronic tape-recording of interviews, a copy to be made available to the arrested person.

Both the Law Reform Commission and the Gibbs Committee also recommended the incorporation of measures to control any possible tendency for police to allow the maximum to become the norm. The Commission favoured a formulation requiring police to take a person before a magistrate, or make a release or bail decision ``as soon as reasonably practicable, and in no event longer than four hours'' after the commencement of custody. The Gibbs Committee suggested a provision ``that the `investigation period', for which the person may be detained, be defined as a period, not exceeding the specified maximum, during which that person is detained for the purpose of investigating whether he or she has committed an offence'', that is, a period during which active questioning or investigation is taking place directly related to an offence for which that person is being held.

The investigation period is not intended to provide time in which a person may be simply held in custody while police engage in other activities to which they accord a higher priority. The time is provided for active investigation with participation by the suspect on a voluntary basis, and if the permissible fixed time (after allowance for any ``dead time'') is improperly used, evidence obtained even within that period may be inadmissible. In other words, even within the investigation period, the time for which the person is held must be reasonable in the circumstances of the case.

In addition, the usual civil damages remedy remains available, and an externally enforceable police discipline code may be invoked as provided by the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981. If a person who is being held, being involved in active investigation or questioning, withdraws his or her voluntary cooperation in the investigation, this fact will be electronically recorded and if confessional material is later obtained, even within the permitted period, there is a real likelihood of its being held inadmissible if the prosecution is unable to discharge its onus of proving the voluntariness of the confession and the propriety of the ``investigation period''.

Indeed, the most potent safeguard against abuse of the custodial investigation period is the tape-recording requirement. The caution and any other information required to be given to the person under the legislation must also be recorded, together with the person's response, if any, prior to the commencement of the interview. Subject to judicial discretion exercisable in the interests of justice, no confessional evidence will be admissible unless the tape-recording requirements are complied with.

The equipment to be used by the Australian Federal Police, and other Commonwealth investigators subject to the proposed legislation, for the tape-recording of interviews is intended to be composite audio/video-recorders with a built-in, tamper-proof timing device which will show the time and duration of all recorded interviews. Any gaps in time, not identifiable as ``dead time'' (which would usually be independently verifiable) would need to be strictly accounted for, even within the permissible fixed period.

``Dead time'', as recommended by the Gibbs Committee, is time to be disregarded in the calculation of the ``investigation period'', and an exhaustive list of those periods of time is to be found in proposed subsection 23c(6) in clause 3 of the Bill: reasonable travel time to the nearest premises with the required facilities from the place where the person is taken into custody, any period required to allow the person to communicate with persons that he or she is entitled to contact under provisions of the Act relevant to him or her, any period reasonably required to allow such persons to arrive at the place where questioning is to take place, periods required for the person to be questioned, to receive medical attention or to recover from intoxication, or any period during which an application for extension of time is taking place.

The maximum periods in the Bill vary slightly from the Gibbs Committee recommendations. It is proposed that no distinction be made between summary and serious offences in relation to the maximum permissible period of detention, which is set at 4 hours. The Committee recommended a 4-hour maximum in respect of summary offences and a 6-hour maximum in respect of serious offences. The reason for not following that recommendation is that such a distinction may lead to evidentiary problems in situations where a person was arrested in respect of a serious offence but, in the final analysis, a charge of a summary offence may be more appropriate. It would be unfortunate in such a case if a more serious charge were adhered to in order to try to ensure that evidence would be admitted.

It is also proposed that the maximum period for which a young person, that is a person under 18 years of age, or an Aboriginal person or Torres Strait Islander, may be held for voluntary participation in questioning or investigation in relation to any Commonwealth offence, be 2 hours. That questioning, of course, will take place subject to the special provisions in the Bill for the protection of young persons and Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders which essentially involves a right to the presence during any questioning of an ``interview friend'' (specifically defined for each group), whether or not the person has been taken into custody in any of the ways defined. The two hour maximum period will also be subject, as in all appropriate cases involving serious offences (that is, offences punishable by more than 12 months imprisonment) to extension by a magistrate for a period not exceeding a further 8 hours.

The fact that the bill proposes that Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders be subject to similar special provisions to those found suitable for young persons may strike some as patronising and some as discriminating in an unfair way against non-Aboriginals or non-Torres Strait Islanders. The intention is, and the operation of the provision should be, neither of these things. Firstly, Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders come from a vast range of backgrounds, and any particular background may not be apparent superficially to a member of the police. An Aboriginal person from a remote, traditionally-oriented part of Australia may visit friends or relatives in the city, as may a country-dweller. When Forster J first formulated the Anunga rules for the questioning of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory in R v Anunga ((1976) 11 ALR 412 at 414), he emphasised that he was ``not expressing the view that Aboriginal people are any less intelligent than white people but simply that their concepts of certain things and the way in which they are expressed may be wholly different to those of white people''. Even if they understand the words, they may not understand the concepts which the English words and phrases express. Cultural values of polite agreement and deference to authority may also affect responses to questioning. Protection in these circumstances is justified as a special measure under Article 1(4) of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and section 8(1) of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Furthermore, the Interim Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody refers specifically to the risks associated with the initial period in custody.

If an investigating official has reasonable grounds for believing that such a person's level of education and understanding is such that he or she is not at any disadvantage in comparison to members of the Australian community generally, then the official is not required to comply with the special provisions; however, he or she should bear in mind that cultural as well as purely linguistic factors may contribute to disadvantage and that the onus will be on the prosecution to prove that the investigating official had reasonable grounds for the belief.

Other departures from the Gibbs Review Committee's draft Bill are mainly matters of drafting or made for the purpose of clarifying the way in which the provisions are intended to work in practice, particularly given that the Commonwealth legislation has to operate against a background of State and Territory law. A detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the Explanatory Memorandum and here I have addressed only its more significant aspects.

In summary, the whole emphasis of the proposed legislation is on achieving, with proper and adequate safeguards, that necessary balance between the reasonable requirements of law enforcement and the protection of the rights of individuals which the High Court, constrained to interpret and apply the existing law, acknowledged that it was for the legislature to determine.

Legislation is essential to provide this balance. The law applying to persons arrested for Commonwealth offences in different parts of Australia is highly divergent and can be expected to become more so as other jurisdictions enact legislation to resolve the problems exposed by the Williams case. Different results can occur in different jurisdictions in similar Commonwealth cases.

I consider that the concept of a strictly defined reasonable investigation period within a specified maximum period of permissible pre-charge detention, with appropriate provision for ``dead time'', and provision for extension by a magistrate in those very few complex cases where it may be necessary is, of all possible solutions to the Williams problem, the one which best balances, within a democratic society, the community's interest in effective law enforcement and the rights and freedoms of the individual.

The introduction of mandatory tape-recording of interview with suspects is the best kind of safeguard against any possible abuse of the extended pre-charge period. Together with rights of communication with a friend or relative, (with special provision for the protection of young persons, foreign nationals, and Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders), and rights of consultation with, and the presence of, a legal practitioner, the uniform and mandatory tape-recording of interviews provides the best guarantee of fairness in investigatory procedures operating in Australia at this time.

I must emphasise that nothing in the proposed legislation alters the law so as to give police a power to detain involuntarily a person who is not under arrest. The Bill does not extend powers of arrest. The right to refuse to participate in questioning or investigation is preserved. The onus remains on the prosecution to prove the voluntariness of a confession and the court retains its discretion to exclude unfairly, illegally or improperly obtained evidence.

The only financial implications arising from the Bill concern the cost of electronic recording which will be required by proposed sections 23U and 23V. It is estimated that the costs involved will be $2,625,000 in 1990/91 and $804,000 in 1991/92. These costs relate to equipment (including cassettes and editing, enhancement and reproduction facilities), building alterations and transcription.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990
This Bill provides for amendments to the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971 to
increase the maximum rate of the research and development levy to one dollar per each pig slaughtered and
the maximum rate of levy for marketing and promotion purposes to two dollars and fifty cents per pig slaughtered.
The levies are used to partially fund the operations of the Pig Research and Development Corporation and to fully fund the Australian Pork Corporation.
Both levy increases have been requested by the Australian Pork Producers' Federation, which is the recognised body representing levy payers.

Like a number of the levy collection Acts for the industries within my portfolio, this Act provides for the maximum levy chargeable to be contained in the Act and for the operative level of levy to be set by regulation up to that maximum amount.

The present operational levy rates for research and promotion are at or near the maximum rates provided in the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971. Increasing the maximum rates will give industry the flexibility to increase contributions to research and promotion over some years and thus avoid the need for frequent amendments to the legislation.

For the research and development component the operative levy rate within the maximum is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Pig Research and Development Corporation, following consultation with the Australian Pork Producers' Federation.
The levy raised is matched by the Government for funding of research and development projects up to a maximum of 0.5% of gross value of production of the industry.

This Government is keenly aware of the necessity of primary industry research and development. We have encouraged rural industries to increase their contributions to research to 0.5% of gross value of production.

In our May 1989 statement ``Research, Innovation and Competitiveness'', the Government reaffirmed its commitment to continued matching of industry levies for funding of research and development up to 0.5% of gross value of production.

The Australian pig industry is currently contributing about 0.35% of its gross value of production to research and development and is planning to increase its levy payments to research and development beyond the present maximum rate. I would like to commend the industry's foresight and support of the need for increased research and development.

The operative rate for the marketing and promotion levy is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Australian Pork Corporation, again in consultation with industry. The levy is used to fund the operations of the corporation which primarily develops and administers marketing and promotional strategies aimed at increasing the consumption of Australian pork and pork products.

The Australian Pork Corporation has been successful in recent years in assisting the industry to achieve increases in the market share of Australian pork as evidenced by the rising per capita consumption of pork meat.

The operative levy rate for these purposes is currently set at the maximum rate. This Bill will make it possible for industry to seek increases in the operative rate which would allow the corporation to maintain or expand its marketing and promotion program.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from this amendment. However, it will enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase in the research and development levy, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays in future years.
I commend the Bill to honourable Senators, and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1990

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 and the Grape Research Levy Act 1986 to remove minor legislative inconsistencies and improve the operation of research and development in the portfolio.

The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 set the framework for the establishment of research and development corporations, and councils for smaller industries, to improve the management of portfolio research activities. There are a small number of drafting errors in this Act, which this Bill will correct.

While these changes are relatively minor in themselves, collectively they are important and necessary for the smooth operation of the research and development corporations and councils established under the principal Act.

These amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act remove anomalies in reporting requirements for research and development corporations and councils and streamline reporting requirements for selection committees by allowing the incorporation of their report in the annual report of the Associated Research and Development Corporation.

This Bill makes references to representative organisations consistent throughout the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. Representative organisations as defined by that Act are declared to be associated with the R& corporation or council, rather than with industry. This Bill corrects inaccurate mention of representative organisations being associated with industry.

This Bill removes the unintended anomaly of having different reporting schedules for research and development councils and corporations. Annual operational and five year plans for research and development councils will now be submitted in line with timing requirements for research and development corporations.
This Bill also provides that the chairpersons of research and development councils attend annual co-ordination meetings along with chairpersons of R& corporations.

This Bill also amends the Grape Research Levy Act 1986. The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 inadvertently amended this Act and removed the right of relevant industry organisations, whose members pay the levy, to make recommendations to the Minister regarding the rate of the industry levy for funding grape research. This amendment will restore that right.
The measures set out in this Bill will involve no Commonwealth outlays.
Administrative savings may be achieved for the research and development corporations and councils through the inclusion of selection committee reports in the relevant corporation's annual report.

The major impact of the Bill will be the removing of inconsistencies in reporting requirements for research and development corporations and councils, the clarification of the use of the term `representative organisation' and the remedying of the unintended alteration to the process for determining the level of levies in the grape and wine industry.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two treaties here that I wish to refer to. They are the treaties on co-production of films between Canada and the United Kingdom. I am glad to see that Senator Richardson is here. He may well have some interest in this matter from his time as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems that has emerged is that there is now a difference in definition between a co-production for Australian content in terms of funding film making and the definition of `Australian film' for the purpose of broadcasting on television. This is arrant nonsense. So a film that attracts Australian taxpayers' money, which is regarded as a co-production under the treaties listed here, may well not be an Australian film for television broadcasting purposes and will not be part of a television station's Australian content as required.

The Government should get off the pot and do something about this. It has been aware of it for a long time. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) has been totally unhelpful about it. I do not know what the current Minister may be able to do to encourage the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to cease being so pig-headed about it. Quite frankly, it is a nonsense that the economic viability of a film-in the case of these treaties, a co-production film-can be damaged and the prospects of getting funding for it severely diminished because the ABT will not use the criteria being used by the Australian Film Finance Corporation and other government bodies-the 10ba requirement, for example-as the criteria for judging whether it is an Australian film for television content purposes.

We get the ludicrous situation where two government bodies simply ignore each other. I have heard disturbing news this morning that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has totally rejected the latest suggestions by the Government and, I think, by the Australian Film Corporation that there should be one set of criteria. In a Senate Estimates committee I asked how the resolution of this matter was going. Ms Robinson, from the Australian Film Commission, said:
. . . the AFC submitted during the Australian content inquiry-
that is, of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-

that the Tribunal should consider giving national treatment to approved coproductions because they were approved for the purposes of domestic financing purposes. The Tribunal rejected our submission on this count . . . at the moment-
the Government and the Australian Film Commission-
are looking at how we might proceed on that question.

As I say, that was back in September. I understand now that absolutely no progress has been made. To that extent, signing co-production agreements in relation to films, the economic viability of which will depend on their being shown on television, becomes next to meaningless. I hope that a greater sense of urgency will exist within the Government.

Quite frankly, I would be prepared to suggest to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that, if it does not feel it within its capacity to act in this way and to use the criteria adopted by the other governmental bodies, then it seems to me quite possible that the Act relating to it could be changed to ensure that it does. I believe that there is a clear need for this Tribunal to wake up to the facts of life and to recognise that these treaties, such as the two we are discussing today, should be made meaningful rather than be disrupted by, frankly, a self-important tribunal which does not recognise that it has a duty to act sensibly in relation to a very important industry, the Australian Film Industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points in relation to the Pipeline Authority which were alluded to in its annual report and which I would like to take up and make comment on. They relate also-and it is in this context that I will speak mainly of them-to the allegations that have been made by the Government in recent times about the Opposition's refusal to support the legislation that would have set in train the sale of the assets of the Pipeline Authority to the private sector, a piece of legislation which was introduced last year and which was rejected by the Senate late in 1990, as a result of which the Government has now withdrawn the pipeline sale.

SPEECH.PARA: There are several points that I really want to stress in relation to this because the Government, in its portrayal of the Opposition's position, has been totally misleading in its comments. It claims that our opposing of the sale was done, in effect, to frustrate the Government's Budget and that the amount of money, therefore, that the Government will get into its coffers this year towards its Budget surplus will be reduced by what it is now saying is the figure of $700m. Apparently, that is the figure that the Government claims it would have got in this financial year for the sale of the assets of the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline.

First of all, it needs to be stressed that that is a very rubbery figure indeed. We had long debates about the figure last year in this chamber, in the Estimates committees and elsewhere. It was quite clear from that that the Government was very reluctant to release a figure at all, and when it did produce a figure-eventually Senator McMullan did so in the Senate late last year-it was quite clear that the $700m was part of a range and was very much the upper limit.

Let me make it clear that the coalition opposed the sale of the assets of the pipeline because the Government was deliberately breaching its contract with the Australian Gaslight Co. without any meaningful attempt at proper negotiation of the sale. Indeed, the Government admitted-and it was included in the legislation that this Senate quite properly rejected-that it was breaching contract and that there would be scope for large compensation payments involved; and something like one-third of the Bill before the Parliament was related to how to handle the compensation issue.

This coalition was not prepared, and will never be prepared, to sanction decisions by this Parliament that deliberately breach the Government's contracts with the private sector or with anyone else. To do that goes right to the heart of the propriety of government and we are not going to be party to reducing the integrity of government. If the Government had approached the sale in a proper manner which respected normal commercial relations, it would have had our support.

We told the Government that, but the Government spat the dummy and withdrew the whole thing from sale without attempting to put it in a proper form. Privatisation of the pipeline has long been on our privatisation agenda. It still is, but we will conduct the negotiations with full regard for propriety and for normal commercial considerations. Another point I want to make is that it was always highly doubtful whether the sale would have been completed this financial year. To say that this has frustrated the Government's Budget is nonsense. The Government's shortfall this year will be of the order of between $4 billion and $8 billion. At the very most we are talking about $700m for the pipeline-a large amount, but a minuscule amount in relation to the Budget shortfall as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday I and some other members of the Opposition visited the Qantas Airways Ltd jet base in Sydney. It was at the invitation of Mr John Ward via Mr Jull, the shadow Minister. Eight of us attended the base and I wish to say how much I enjoyed the opportunity and the experience. We saw a splendid presentation dealing with the role of Qantas and its activities, and the situation in which the airline at present finds itself with the downturn in tourism and air travel.

SPEECH.PARA: We visited the apprenticeships school which has now been open for about 12 months. It trains a number of apprentices obviously to a very high standard. We had an opportunity to meet the apprentices and teachers in the school. We also visited the engineering section where work is done on machines. We visited the area and were shown how to escape from a plane. It is set up in such a way that indicates the actual distance a passenger would have to slide if coming out of a plane that came down into water or onto the land. I hope that I shall not be present if that ever happens, but certainly Qantas's record in this regard is one of which we can be very proud. We also went to the maintenance areas and had experience of seeing one of the flight simulators.

TALK.START.PARA: —We went to Hong Kong and back in one day.

—Yes, it was a remarkably quick trip to Hong Kong and back. We visited the catering service where Qantas prepares food for 23 airlines that travel in and out of Australia. We did not have as much time there as I would have liked. I hope to return because I found that area and the organisation quite fascinating. Earlier in the day some of us took the opportunity to see the new safety centre, which is a significant advance in air safety and the checking of aircraft safety. There is an opportunity for Qantas to offer this service to other airlines, which I am sure will be taken up. Altogether, it was a most instructive day.

SPEECH.PARA: What stands out in my mind is the number of people we met who have been with the company for such a long time. The first person who showed us around, Ken Lewis, was celebrating his 25th year of service. The following day we met another man who was celebrating 30 years of service. We came across a number of other staff who had been with the organisation for 25, 30 and even 35 years. That length of service seemed to apply throughout the company. It indicated to me a great sense of purpose, identity and family among those who work for our airline. It is an experience I shall long remember. As I have said, I hope to be invited back again to have a more in-depth look at the catering service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—We had a quick working lunch.
—What about doggy bags?

—No, there were no doggy bags. We had one small chocolate as we went around the catering section. I wish to take this opportunity, while this report is before the Senate, to place on record my appreciation to Qantas for the visit and for what the airline is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments made by my colleague Senator Reid. I, too, am a member of the committee and I enjoyed the hospitality of Qantas Airways Ltd at its jet base last Friday. Qantas is an exceptionally fine airline and one of which Australians wherever they go throughout the world can be particularly proud. What we learned about the airline, its record, its safety history and so forth will hold us in good stead. We are most concerned about the troubles that are besetting the industry in general, and perhaps to Qantas in particular, largely because of the Gulf war which has led to a decrease in passenger traffic.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with Senator Reid in thanking Qantas for what it has done for Australia and for its efforts in looking after us last Friday. I hope that Qantas will be able to struggle through the present tough times. It is a fine airline and we should all support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having also visited the jet base last week, I join my two colleagues in thanking Qantas Airways Ltd. I also wish to make an additional point as shadow Minister for youth affairs. On the visit I was heartened to see that Qantas is determined to ensure that it maintains its training programs, despite the economic pressures that are being put upon it by both the rise in oil prices as a result of the Gulf war and the falling off in patronage because of people's concerns about flying at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The company found in the last economic downturn that a cancellation of its training programs, certainly a large number of its technical programs, resulted in an acute shortage of skilled maintenance workers when airline business picked up. The result was that Qantas had to do a large amount of its servicing with overseas companies. The United States of America was providing a fair proportion of major service work for Qantas.

Those of us who saw the Qantas facility at Mascot and the extraordinarily high level of training recognise that there is nowhere else in the world that would provide the same high level of maintenance as that employed by Qantas. As a result I am glad that in this downturn we were given the clear impression that no matter how many staff unfortunately may have to be shed as a result of reduced business, Qantas is determined to maintain its training programs so that it will be able to keep up its extraordinary record-the best of any airline in the world-in terms of lack of accidents.

We must recognise that the problems facing Qantas are very serious indeed, as indeed they are with all airlines. We have already seen many international airlines in the United States filing for bankruptcy, and ending up totally out of business in one or two areas. It will also mean a reduction in the services to Australia from some European airlines, some of which I believe will withdraw from this service altogether. I am glad that we have an airline as safe, efficient and forward looking as Qantas to provide us with international links, even though I fear that some of its direct services to London may have to incorporate other services, such as Frankfurt and Rome. Therefore, there may be some added inconvenience to passengers, but at least we have an airline that will meet Australia's requirements, particularly if some international operators remove their services from Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just briefly want to endorse the remarks made before the suspension of the sitting for dinner by Senator Reid, Senator Knowles and Senator Michael Baume about Qantas Airways Ltd. They addressed their remarks particularly to their visit to the Qantas facilities in Sydney a few days ago. Unfortunately, I was not on that visit but I have made a similar visit in the past. It is quite obvious that the briefings accorded to them were very similar to the one that I was given-that is, very professional. The briefing, which ran through the operations and the issues facing Qantas, was presented by a very professional team.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment Qantas obviously faces, as does every other international and domestic airline, very considerable problems, particularly with the fall off in the international tourist travel due to a variety of reasons, not the least of which those associated with the Gulf war and the increasing price of fuel. I just want to endorse the commendation that my colleagues have made of Qantas. I think it is a great airline. It has had a great past and I hope that it continues to have a great future.

From the coalition's point of view, that future would be greatly enhanced if the ownership of Qantas were to be put entirely into the private sector. We believe that there is no reason at all why governments should be in the business of running airlines, or for that matter, any other business enterprise.

The sale of 100 per cent of Qantas has been on the Opposition's agenda for some considerable time. Last year the Government took a decision to open up for private ownership 49 per cent of Qantas. The only reason that it did not adopt the coalition's policy of a 100 per cent sale was that the left wing of the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement at the special conference that was held in Sydney to get at least that far on the privatisation debate refused to go any further.

The reason for the constraint on the degree of private ownership of Qantas is that the left wing pressures-the old socialist pressures-still exist very considerably within the Labor Party, despite the Government's rhetoric in terms of its greater adherence to free market conditions and the like. If we strip away the rhetoric, we will find that the performance of the Government is vastly different from that rhetoric. The Qantas example of a 49 per cent sale, as distinct from a 100 per cent sale, is a very good example of that.

Having said that, I believe that it is extremely important that the sale of the 49 per cent is properly handled. It is a major sale of a part of a government undertaking. Of course, it is not any old undertaking; it is an international airline that has had a great association with the Australian image and Australian culture. So the handling of the sale of the 49 per cent of the equity in Qantas has to be done very carefully indeed.

I understand that, contrary to what I thought was to be the earlier process for handling this sale, in fact the Commonwealth Task Force on Asset Sales, located in the Department of Finance, is the government agency that will have the responsibility for handling that sale. If that is the case, I can only counsel caution on the Government's part. I have observed very closely the performance of the Commonwealth Task Force on Asset Sales in respect of the Pipeline Authority and one would hope that we would not have a repeat of that experience.
