TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I wish to speak to the annual report of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It is my intention to direct my remarks to that section of the report dealing with Antarctica. Honourable senators will be aware that I have pursued a number of reservations, within this chamber and at Estimates committee hearings, about our Antarctic operations. My prime objective has been to ensure that the decisions which are made should be to the best possible advantage of our Antarctic program. Of course, of equal importance is that there should be a judicial use of Australia's taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not to say that any of our Antarctic operations should ever be done on the cheap. Because of the obvious isolation and the climatic extremes, simply maintaining a presence in the Antarctic region is a very expensive business. Nor am I advocating in any manner that the safety of our Antarctic expeditioners should be jeopardised. I am totally committed to the belief that no amount of money is as important as safety. These concerns aside, there have been instances where all has not been well. I need only refer to the recently released report by the Auditor-General regarding the arrangements surrounding the negotiations for the replacement Antarctic vessel, the Aurora Australis.

The former Minister, Senator Richardson, and I have often clashed on the tendering process for the Aurora Australis, but the fact remains that the Auditor-General did express reservations about that process. In particular, the Auditor-General stated that whilst he may have understood why the Government signed a letter of intent with P and O Polar to construct the vessel, he also quite correctly pointed out that the signing of this letter of intent severely hampered the Commonwealth's bargaining position.

Put simply, signing the letter of intent before matters were finalised was the equivalent of going into a car yard and signing a contract to purchase a motor vehicle before agreeing on the price. Once a person has signed the letter, he is committed, which is a most irresponsible business attitude at best. No-one, least of all I, is going to argue with the Government or the Minister's intention to have the vessel built in Australia. This is commendable. However, as with all things, this desire should have been kept in its proper perspective. To have a vessel built overseas was always going to be the cheaper option. No-one minds paying a little more for the Australian product but, in the case of the replacement Antarctic vessel, the cost of the Australian vessel rose so rapidly that a very valid question to ask is whether the equation became unreasonably balanced.

I have also had to find out whether the vessel which we got was the one we originally ordered. I regret very much that P and O saw fit to jettison its experienced Antarctic partners, Polar Schieffarts, once it had been awarded the contract. It should be remembered that under the terms of the original expressions of interest, P and O would not have gone past first base without its partners because relevant experience was an important prerequisite. I know that there were other tenderers who were very aggrieved that the Government saw fit to allow this to happen. Once again, I believe these concerns were very valid.

The Antarctic Division is made up of hundreds of individual scientists, administrators and support staff. I know that their work is held in high esteem, particularly at an international level. I would not like this opportunity to pass without first congratulating these men and women on the outstanding job which they do and, secondly, commenting briefly on some particular matters which I believe would be of interest to the Senate. One of those particular matters was the role which the Antarctic Division is playing in initiating a program to monitor and investigate the impact of marine debris on seals and seabirds in the southern ocean. This is a subject which I believe most Australians find particularly distressing, especially as some of this debris, such as plastic lines and nets, has the potential to be a danger for up to 50 years. It is evident that this marine garbage poses a seal threat and I trust that the definite research of the Division will prove a catalyst for an international approach to controlling the problem.

During Estimates, my colleague, Senator Baume, commented on the Casey oil spill. Since that, we have had another oil spill in Antarctica of 19,000 litres. That is of great concern to me. My final point is that the environmental policy activities conducted by the Antarctic Division-the proposed trials for an air transport system-have been a bit of a failure. With those few words I conclude.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The report has been lauded by the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Ian McLachlan, as a practical, if not perfect, program of reduced assistance for the automotive sector. Point 2 of the terms of reference which the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, issued specifies that the report and recommendations will cover the assistance arrangements for the industry from 1993 to the year 2000, and will include any factors including institutional, regulatory and other arrangements affecting the competitiveness of the industry.

My colleague Mr Ian McLachlan in the other chamber said that it was not a perfect program for the whole industry. I wish to refer to what I perceive to be some of those imperfections in the Automotive Industry Report No. 5, particularly because I believe that the report does not adequately address the problems of a macro-economic nature, the overvalued nature of the Australian dollar and the effect of the competitiveness of the automotive industry in such an environment. It also addresses inadequately the micro-economic issues which are so necessary to accompany the tariff cuts that are envisaged.

I remind the Senate that the macro-economic issues were limited to two pages; the micro-economic issues were limited to three pages. That has to be looked at by reference to the fact that the report was over 250 pages long. This term of reference thus allows the Commission, under chapter 9 entitled `Other matters', to make specific reference to a Commonwealth Government regulation, including legislation; that is, the luxury sales tax and its impact on the industry.
The Industry Commission states:
A number of participants raised concerns about . . . the higher rate of sales tax applying to luxury vehicles, and the level of taxation on vehicles as a whole.

As most senators present, and even those absent, would be aware, the matter of luxury sales tax on vehicles is one which has been debated several times in this chamber over the past 12 months. Having considered all the submissions put before it, the Commission concluded, and I quote from page 167 of the report:

. . . the Commission is not convinced that the luxury sales tax, in either its current or previous form, has provided significant de facto protection to the local industry. By virtue of the pattern of domestic vehicle production and vehicle importation, its incidence obviously falls more heavily on imported marques. However, the sales tax regime in general does not discriminate between domestically produced and imported vehicles.

That said, the revised sales tax regime still has deficiencies. The base rate on sales tax on luxury vehicles of 30 per cent remains higher than the rate applying to non-luxury vehicles. Hence a price void, albeit smaller, remains. And, there will also remain some disincentive to include safety features and other options on vehicles priced just under the luxury tax threshold.

In the Commission's view, it would be preferable if any luxury sales tax applied only on the value of the vehicle above the designated threshold. Given the current sales tax regime for non-luxury vehicles, this would imply a split rate regime of 20 per cent on the wholesale value below the threshold, and a higher rate of wholesale value above the threshold.

Whilst the Industry Commission refrained from making any specific recommendations about vehicle taxation because of the implications of such a recommendation on areas other than the automotive industry, I feel that the Commission has raised a valid point which the Government should consider. No doubt vehicle importers would contemplate suicide at the mere suggestion of a further change to the luxury car sales tax. However, the view expressed seems to me to be a sensible one. Indeed, it is a pity that the Government did not have the opinion to work with when it attempted to correct its first botched attempt at increasing the luxury sales tax on cars.

The Commission also commented on an almost unanimous complaint amongst participants which was that high taxes on vehicles adversely affected vehicle producers and importers alike. The position was best summed up in the submission of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries Importers Group. Given the limitation on my time, I will not have the opportunity to comment on that, but I endorse the remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on this Industry Commission report on the automotive industry-report No. 5. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that when we were debating the Industry Commission Bill, which replaced the old Industries Assistance Commission with the Industry Commission, the Senate accepted several very significant amendments: one was that as a constant term of reference, the Industry Commission would have before us the environmental consequences of any of its other references; and, secondly, that there would be appointed to the Commission somebody whose expertise was in the area of environment.

SPEECH.PARA: When we turn to this important document-the report of the Industry Commission-we find that Mr Keating gave terms of reference to the Commission without any mention whatsoever of the extreme importance of the automotive industry in relation to environmental effects. I refer, specifically, to the large contribution which the automotive industry in Australia makes to greenhouse gas emissions.

Yet, despite that absence and despite the fact that the Industry Commission is supposed to be working under its Act which charges it with the responsibility of considering environmental matters, it did not take on board Mr Keating's second term of reference, which states:
. . . specify that the report and recommendations will cover the assistance agreements for the industry from 1993 to 2000 and will include any factors, including-
I take it that `including' is not exclusive-
institutional, regulatory or other arrangements affecting the competitiveness of the industry.
Reference 3(v) states:
. . . the measures which enable the industry to concentrate on areas of greatest comparative advantage and to take advantage of opportunities arising from globalisation of the automotive industry.

I would have thought that the growing global awareness of the importance of greenhouse would have indicated quite clearly to the Australian automotive industry that it is in its interest to start making motor cars which emit less greenhouse gas, are more fuel efficient and so on.

Turning to the automotive business pages of today's Australian, there is a major headline `Buyers swing to fuel-efficient cars'. When we look at how the Commission has actually discharged its duty in relation to considering environmental matters-Senator Watson pointed out that this report is 252 pages-we find that only two pages out of 252 say anything whatsoever on environmental matters. There is no consideration whatsoever of the very important role which the automotive industry plays in environmental damage, and the comparative advantage which Australia may well achieve in the next 10 to 15 years if it quite deliberately starts manufacturing cars which are more fuel efficient and less polluting.

Most of those two pages are devoted to a very cursory resume of the evidence that was put before the Commission. It then has two very brief paragraphs, which is really all the Commission says in the discharge of its duty under its Act. The report states:

However, the Commission considers that industry policy measures should not be tailored specifically to achieve environmental objectives: rather, such objectives are generally best pursued through direct measures. This suggests that, once policies governing vehicle emissions are in place, vehicle producers should be allowed to adjust their production and marketing decisions as they see fit. By augmenting rather than supplanting market forces, such an approach should achieve environmental objectives in a way that least distorts consumer preferences, and hence maximises overall community well-being.

Reading between the gobbledegook, what that really means is that one should intrude into the market by putting appropriate price signals into place which would cause the industry to make different vehicles. Yet, in addressing this very important question of the industry between the years 1993 and the year 2000, the Industry Commission has not seen fit to actually make that a specific recommendation. I believe that the Industry Commission has not fulfilled its responsibility under its Act.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TORRES STRAIT PROTECTED ZONE JOINT AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I also was caught slightly by the large number of papers that we are dealing with, so I do not have this paper in front of me. But it was one that was on the Notice Paper yesterday and I was expecting to speak to it then. I merely wish to observe in moving that this document be noted that it is very fortunate to see that the waters of the Torres Strait have been substantially reserved for the people of the Torres Strait to use as their exclusive fishing zone; that is one of the things that comes clearly out of this report.

Also, I noted in the report that most of the species which are being fished-the crayfish and other species-are apparently, according to the report, being managed in a sustainable way. I think the report says that the crayfish are being harvested up to close to their maximum yield, but many of the other species are certainly being harvested at considerably less than that-which is a very desirable objective, given the natural variation which occurs in wild populations.

The other matter on which I wish to comment is that the report also draws attention to the likelihood of pollution of the waters of the Torres Strait. I think it should be noted here that the activities of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in relation to the OK Tedi mine have caused very considerable pollution of the Fly River from the sinking of a barge containing cyanide some years ago and also from the loss of the tailings dam in the mine site and the consequent loss of a great deal of material, including heavy metals and other things. Potentially, there is very considerable danger there to the waters of the Torres Strait. One hopes that very careful attention is given to the operation of that particular company.

That, of course, is also relevant in relation to the proposed Coronation Hill mine, which is also a proposal largely involving the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, and involving the East Alligator River and the possibility of pollution not going directly into the Torres Strait but certainly going into the general areas of the marine environment to the north of Australia. I think the main thing that should be noted from this report is the highly desirable way in which, for once, a natural resource has been substantially reserved to the indigenous people of the area for their use.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
