SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Short, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the damning admission on 8 February 1991 of policy failure by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that `the Government did not want a recession, it wanted a slowdown' and that `it is a slowdown, not a recession, that Australia requires';

(b) notes the equally stunning admission by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Sunday program on 10 February 1991 that `we obviously got wrong a proposition that said that there would not be a recession';
(c) condemns the Government for the massive hardship its disastrous miscalculations and mismanagement have wrought on all Australians; and
(d) urges the Government to pursue the policies advocated for so long by the Coalition, to restore sustainable private sector growth and employment.

How grateful we must all have been to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say last Sunday that his Government had got it wrong on interest rates, and to hear the Treasurer (Mr Keating) say that what he really meant to say last year was that we needed a `slowdown' and not a `recession'. This, sadly, is just so typical of the deterioration of sound management by the Treasurer and the admission that he did get it wrong.

Last month former Treasury official David Morgan placed on record the fact that warning was given of a shakeout in financial services-just one more warning that the Treasurer and the Hawke Labor Government did not heed. Now, when trouble strikes the corporate sector, we are told that it was entirely its fault.

I simply cannot come at the fact that the dramatic increases in bankruptcies are all the fault of the private sector and management and mismanagement. No-one can convince me that businesses that have been quite viable for 30, 40 or more years go out of business not because of the current economic climate but because of their mismanagement. Restructuring through economic collapse seems to be the modus operandi of the Treasurer and, while this Government rightly stands up to Saddam Hussein, there seems to be a touch of his logic in the Treasurer's statements when the hardship suffered by business, farms and ordinary wage earners is somehow held up as proof of courageous economic management. I referred a short time ago to one constant indicator of all the suffering and that is, of course, the bankruptcy levels and the statistics for the December quarter of 1990. Last year 11,000 or 57 per cent of small businesses went bankrupt and one does not have to think too hard to realise how many people lost their jobs as a consequence. That is the real tragedy. Today we have the highest unemployment figures for nearly eight years, yet this Government still says that it is on track. In my State of Western Australia, the rise in bankruptcies from the previous December quarter was 89 per cent.

The cost of this Hawke-Keating Labor Government can be summarised in very simple terms-the ever increasing dole queues, the ever increasing numbers of businesses going broke-and that does not include those businesses that shut up shop before they actually went into bankruptcy, resulting in all the staff losing their jobs as well-the ever decreasing value of assets, the increasing dole queues, the increasing number of businesses going broke and the decreasing value of assets, all of which is taking everyone out backwards. Australia has a rural sector that is left like a carcass on the track and job opportunities for school leavers are virtually non-existent. All this has been cleverly done as a home-grown market.

This Government cannot even say that this depression-not recession-has been brought about by overseas factors beyond its control. Australia started to drop out of sight long before any other country was experiencing difficulties, and the trend has just continued downwards. This is the depression that Messrs Hawke and Keating `engineered' and that is what the disgrace is all about. They engineered this with little or no regard for those who have lost everything-their futures and all their hard work in the past. They and their political masters-the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-have not had the courage to make the policy changes necessary to save Australia from ruin.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has repeatedly offered bipartisan support if the Government, for the sake of Australia, undertakes real policy reform of things such as tax reform, significant spending cuts, significant shifts in work practices and productivity, particularly in areas such as transport, telecommunications and the waterfront, and real privatisation reform. By that I do not mean simply selling off the assets when they become an embarrassing liability or bailing out people with private sector money. It is a case of selling off things while they are viable and not when they become a liability. This is a real opportunity for the Government, if it is prepared to make the hard decisions, to have bipartisan support from the Opposition to make sure that this country gets back on track. But will it do it? No, because its political masters, the ACTU, will simply not allow it to do so.

To have not only the support but the encouragement of the Opposition is something that is fairly rare in politics today, but we recognise the gravity of the situation for this country and we want to make sure that it does not deteriorate for another two years before we have an opportunity to pull it out of the woods. There is an opportunity to set things straight and it would leave the Australian Democrats in absolute isolation as the Party that really wants to see this country go downhill. They would be the only ones pursuing policies of destruction.

We must look at the areas that have to be reformed because there are at least eight fundamental structural policy changes which must be implemented. I will briefly run through some of them. The first is taxation reform. We must have a simpler tax system that gives incentive to Australians to work harder, earn more and be able to save. That means less tax overall and a bias in the tax system towards saving rather than spending. Labour market reform is another area. The Government must abandon the accord which has eroded real incomes, propped up inflation and given the ACTU far too much power. Only in recent months have we seen the ACTU flex its muscles again. This is the real weakness in this Labor Government that huffs and puffs about waterfront reform but is yet to get rid of one excess wharfie and stood by while John Halfpenny tried to sabotage the agreement of the SPC Ltd cannery where employers and workers were trying to save jobs in the face of an economic reality that the ACTU simply does not want to know about. We must look at inefficient infrastructure and inefficiencies in telecommunication, transport, shipping, the waterfront and power generation, which impose major cost disadvantages on Australian industry trying to export or compete against imports.

We must look at reform of Government operations. Contracting-out of Government services to the private sector can bring savings of up to 20 per cent. So why will the Government not take on these challenges and say, `Now is the time. We are not going to just stand by and let the ACTU run this country any longer. These hard decisions must be made.'? The same applies to the question of privatisation. Sleepy, inefficient Government-owned monopolies must be shaken up through exposure to competition and privatisation. Earlier this evening we were talking about Qantas and what a fine airline it is. It would have to be one of those industries that is absolutely ripe for an injection of real funds and being privatised. We must look at industry reform and orderly and pre-specified reductions in protection. Protection shields Australian industry from the stimulus of international competition and we simply cannot afford that. If we do have orderly and pre-specified reductions in protection, they will be an integral part of an economic reform package.

Immigration is another area that should be very seriously considered because in recent years standards have been lowered to actually achieve the annual targets. It is essential for this country that existing migration criteria be enforced and the integrity of our program be restored because, in the short term, as the recession makes Australia less attractive to skilled migrants and our economy has a reduced capacity to absorb migrants, the overall level of immigration will fall. However, in the longer term, increased immigration will be of substantial economic benefit and Australia should retain its commitment to family reunion and refugee programs. But we must bite the bullet today and not in months or years to come.

The Government must urgently set out clear, consistent and unequivocal guidelines to achieve an appropriate balance between development and conservation of the environment. It is not good enough for the Government to say at election time, `We will promise anything and win the votes and get re-elected and worry about it later'. I am not Robinson Crusoe when I say that Australians generally are concerned that with any major development project that is proposed these days there is such a song and dance routine from the Green movement that it is always put onto the back burner.

Senator Collins happens to be the Minister on duty in the chamber tonight-a Northern Territory senator. I went up to Coronation Hill to look at it for myself and to learn more about it. I would have to say that that is one area that should be allowed to be mined. However, we have this current, ongoing situation in which, if oil drilling is to take place in the Tasman Sea, there are people who say, `There are whales in the Tasman Sea and we cannot drill for oil there'. We cannot allow this situation to continue. We all have a role to play in this and it is particularly important. That is why it is vital that Senator Short's motion be talked about at this early stage of the autumn session. Senator Short and the coalition parties as a whole urge the Government to pursue the policies about which I have talked tonight and to restore sustainable private sector growth and employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating a motion moved by Senator Short on the economy in which he calls for the introduction of new economic policies in this country. I should point out that a key objective of the policies of the Hawke Government has been to reduce the impact of the balance of payments constraint on Australia's economy. This constraint has been around for many years.
—You haven't been too successful.

—We have. I will get onto that in a moment because I have some illuminating data which I would like to share with Senator Short. However, we have been operating to moderate the impact of this constraint. The predilection of the economy to spill over purchases into excessive imports has been a constraint on Australia's economic growth since Federation. It is important to note that the policies in place to slow down gross domestic production and the rate of growth in the economy have been working to slow down the rate of import growth and to close the balance of payments current account deficit. It is important to look at those figures. For example, I calculated today that in the six months from July to December in the calendar year 1989 the current account deficit on our balance of payments was $11.9 billion, very close to $12 billion. In the equivalent period in the last six months of 1990, the balance of payments current account deficit had been reduced to $8.6 billion. In just a 12-month period there was a reduction in the current account deficit of 28 per cent. By anybody's calculations that is a major reduction in that constraint on the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note-Senator Short is not listening at the moment-that the $8.6 billion deficit in the first six months of this financial year is very much on track to meet the Budget forecast of $18 billion for the whole financial year. It was $8.6 billion in the first half of the financial year, the forecast being $18 billion for the full year. At the same time that this improvement in the current account deficit has been occurring, there has been a relaxation of monetary policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —But do you think $18 billion is an improvement?

—It is certainly an improvement in proportion to the gross domestic product. One must always relate items such as imports and current account deficits to the size of the economy. We should not talk about them in sheer absolute terms. The deficits now are not much different as a percentage of gross domestic product from the deficits under Mr Howard and Mr Fraser in the early 1980s. One has to look at those sorts of things because there is a very clear link between gross domestic product and imports. That is one of the few well-documented linkages in economics. One should therefore relate imports and current account deficits to the size of the economy and not just speak about them in absolute terms.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not deny that, as Senator Short's motion states, there has been hardship in the Australian economy. I readily admit that there has been hardship in some sections of the community. Family living standards have been compressed; they have been very tight in recent months. Families have been feeling the pinch. I should point out that, as well as interest rates being relaxed, fiscal policy has been relaxed in recent times. From 1 January Australian households have been getting not only an initial round of personal income tax cuts; they have been getting two lots of personal income tax cuts, because in the last few months of 1990 we agreed to fund a second round of personal income tax reductions, which took effect from 1 January this year. I am sure that people who have been looking at their pay slips have been rather impressed by the reduction in the tax burden and the increase in their take-home pay. It is rather striking to see the impact on the pay slips.

The original round of tax cuts for somebody on an income of $20,000 per annum-which is a fairly typical income in my State-would mean a tax cut of $4.80 a week. As a result of the second round of tax cuts, the additional tax cuts which have been given effect from 1 January, an extra $2.80 a week is being provided to Australian employees. The sum of the two tax cuts for somebody on an income of $20,000 per annum is of the order of $7.60 a week. That is the increase in take-home pay of after-tax disposable income which translates into a $10.90 per week gross wage before tax. If one allows for the tax that would be taken out of $10.90 a week, it would translate to the after-tax take-home pay rise of $7.60 a week. It is very important to fund increases in disposable income in that way, because it takes pressures off employers by reducing the impact of extra wage rounds on their wages bills.

The tax cuts have been given effect by an increase in the amount of tax-exempt income. The amount of tax-exempt income has gone up from $5,100 to $5,400 and the bottom rate of income tax has been cut from 21c in the dollar to 20c in the dollar. That is one example; I will not go through all the tax changes that are occurring. I should also point out that as part of this remuneration package-and Senator Short has moved a motion here tonight about hardship in Australian families-there is also to be a wage rise. In May this year there will be a flat wage rise of $12 weekly for members of the work force. It will be paid to all members of the work force so that lower paid members of the work force get as much as higher paid members. It is an effective way of getting a larger percentage wage rise to lower paid workers.

As a result of that $12 wage rise, the total gross wage equivalent of the tax cuts-the two elements of the tax cuts and that wage rise-will mean that somebody on an income of $20,000 per annum will get a gross wage equivalent increase by May of some $22.90 a week. That is equivalent to a 6 per cent wage rise, which is fairly impressive. A 6 per cent wage rise is in effect what Australian workers earning $20,000 per annum will obtain as a result of those two tax cut increments and the $12 wage rise.

I am interested to note that, despite the Liberals moving this motion about hardship this evening, they have never supported this $12 wage rise. I asked them yesterday when I made a speech on the subject whether they were going to endorse this wage rise and there was a deafening silence from the other side of the chamber. Tonight we are debating a motion about hardship in the Australian community and the Liberals are saying, `This Labor Government has brought hardship to Australian families and therefore its policies should be changed'; meanwhile in the very near future this Labor Government will be providing a $12 a week pay rise to Australian workers-and the Liberals are opposed to the rise. I have not heard anyone on the other side of the chamber speak in support of this $12 a week wage rise. Again, there is a massive difference between Liberal Party rhetoric and reality under the Liberals.

Senator Short in part (d) of his motion calls for the implementation of alternative economic policies in Australia. He says that we have to go down a new road, bring in new policies-in fact `policies' advocated for so long by the coalition. What are these policies? What specifically would the Liberal Party do in government-heaven forbid if it ever got into government-and it controlled the Treasury bench of this Parliament? I suppose we can say categorically that the Liberals would bring in a consumption tax. That is pretty clear: the Liberal Party is wedded to a goods and services tax. For the first time in Australia's history we would see a tax on services. Everything from medical bills to public transport and the cost of funerals would be taxed by these people. That is what they would be on about.

I said yesterday that I think the Liberal Party is dressing up self-interest as an economic virtue. It claims that we have to have a consumption tax as a panacea to improve the economy and dresses up self-interest as an economic virtue, as yet another pathway for the Liberal Party to bring in big income tax cuts for people at the big end of town. That is the way the Liberal Party would go if it ever got into power.

It is very interesting to look at the situation in the United Kingdom. We are told that if we had a broad-based consumption tax in Australia-the Liberals call it a goods and services tax-that would help solve our overseas balance of payments problem. But one has only to look at the United Kingdom under the Conservative Party. It had the great double; it had a broad-based consumption tax and a massive balance of payments deficit. The United Kingdom still has a massive balance of payments deficit despite all that North Sea oil. Despite being an oil rich country, it has a massive balance of payments deficit and a broad-based consumption tax at the same time.

I would like to look at some of the specifics of a broad-based consumption tax as it could be operated by a possible future Liberal government. First of all, a goods and services tax, which is a variation of a broad-based consumption tax, would change relative prices. Clearly, such a tax would make many products in our community more expensive and some products very much cheaper. I think we can work on the assumption, doing the sums, as I have, that if the Liberals brought in such a tax with the idea of abolishing the current sales tax, they would have to bring in a consumption tax at a rate of about 15 to 18 per cent. That is the sort of rate they could be working on.

But the catch is that the Liberals would be replacing a sales tax which currently has a number of items taxed at a 30 per cent or 50 per cent rate. That is the big catch. What those people on the other side are up to is bringing down the price of some goods and services, particularly goods which currently are taxed at either a 30 per cent or 50 per cent rate. They would tax these items at the general rate. Under the Liberals' theory, everything would be taxed at the same rate-I estimate 15 to 18 per cent.

There are three main areas in the Australian economy which historically have been tax-free. These include services, a whole range of intangible products in the community-everything from hairdressing to medical services, rent, public transport fares-as well as food and clothing. The Liberal Party's policies would make fruit and vegetables, groceries, meat, shoes, clothes and all the services I mentioned more expensive. All those items would go up in price roughly by the extent of the tax that they would bring in. In other words, if the Liberals brought in a 15 per cent broad-based consumption tax, because these items are tax-free at the moment that would be the extent of the tax increase. That is the effect that the policies that Senator Short is calling for tonight would have on these items in the Australian economy. All those things would go up by the percentage tax rate.

However, at the very same time, the broad-based consumption tax policy which the Liberal Party has put forward as a kind of economic panacea, which it says would solve many of our economic problems, would make many luxuries in the Australian economy infinitely cheaper.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Rolls Royce-led recovery.

—Let me take up Senator McMullan's point. The Liberals would bring down the price of luxury cars and limousines enormously. Under this Government, a 50 per cent sales tax applies to motor vehicles retailing for a price of $48,000 or more. But under the Liberal Party's policy, everything would be taxed at the same rate-everything from funerals to luxury cars, wedding dresses and Easter eggs. All those items would be taxed at the same rate. This is what the Liberals are on about. They would bring down enormously the price of luxury cars.
—Who would benefit?

—Not too many people living in the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne, Senator. However, a number of very privileged people would benefit. Dr Hewson let the cat out of the bag on 15 November when he went to the Sydney International Motor Show and said, when asked by journalists what the future was for the 50 per cent luxury car tax under this Government-which I strongly endorse-`Oh, we are going to scrap it: we are going to get rid of that tax'. So that means that luxury cars will be taxed at the general rate of 15 to 18 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: On my calculations, which I have done this week, a motor vehicle currently retailing for $97,000-a lot of that price reflects our 50 per cent sales tax-would, under the Liberals, go down in price to $77,000. So there is a $20,000 gift to the privileged section of the community who can afford to pay $77,000 or $80,000 for a motor car. Meanwhile, Senator Short put forward a motion in this chamber talking about hardship in the Australian community under this Government. It is as clear as night follows day that a broad-based consumption tax under the Liberal Party will bring down the price of limousines by some $20,000 if they are priced at about $100,000. As Senator Loosley pointed out, those opposite are the limousine Liberals. Basically, what they are after is a Rolls Royce-led recovery-as Senator McMullan has pointed out.

The Liberal Party policy is a clear nonsense. It shows just how much it is out of touch with the ordinary people of Australia if it intends to reduce the price of luxury cars and claim that somehow that will restore Australia's health. The mind boggles. How do cheaper luxury cars restore the Australian economy?

TALK.START.PARA: —You gave this speech yesterday. Are you just dragging it out again?
—It is a good message, is it not, Senator Knowles? She still has not answered the comments I made yesterday. She still has not come up with an answer to the analyses that I put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to move beyond cars and look at other products. It is very evident that the Liberals will bring down the price of a whole range of luxury goods if they ever get into power. I confidently predict now that if the Liberals ever get into power the price of diamonds, jewellery and furs will come down. That is horrific on environmental grounds, is it not-the price of furs coming down? The price of cosmetics and gold watches will come down under the Liberals. All those things follow logically from this broad-based consumption tax proposal that the Liberals have put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to tell us what goes up?
—Yes, Senator. I have never supported a broad-based consumption tax. I have always been totally against such a tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that at present, under this Government, there is a sales tax of 30 per cent on diamonds, jewellery, furs, cosmetics and gold watches. Under the Liberals-and the cat is now out of the bag-that 30 per cent sales tax would be replaced by a broad-based consumption tax.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber. I call Senator Maguire.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Over the top of that verbal barrage I talked about the 50 per cent sales tax rate items that exist at the moment and was going on to talk about the 30 per cent rate items. There are a number of items that are currently taxed at a rate of 30 per cent under this Labor Government. These include diamonds, jewellery, furs, cosmetics and gold watches. If the Liberal Party policy is to bring in a broad-based consumption tax to replace that sales tax with a general rate tax, so that everything is taxed at the same rate, those items-diamonds, jewellery, furs, cosmetics and gold watches-will be taxed at a rate of 15 to 18 per cent. There will be massive falls in the price of those luxury items. That is incredibly regressive.

SPEECH.PARA: It is most disturbing that a major political party could be pushing such a policy of bringing down the price of luxury goods. Senator Collins invited me to list the items that would go up in price. Everything in the fruit and vegetable area would go up in price by 15 to 18 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —But furs will come down?

—And furs will come down. All groceries would go up in price. Everything in a supermarket that is not taxed at the moment-and that is 99 per cent of the items-would go up by 15 to 18 per cent. All clothing items-children's clothes and shoes-that are sales tax exempt at the moment would all be taxed at the broad-based consumption rate of 15 to 18 per cent. So we will see massive price rises in the items that ordinary Australian families spend most of their income on. In the past Senator BjelkePetersen has talked about the price of children's shoes. That is a very clear case of prices being put up.
—Are you trying to talk this out?
—Senator Short criticises our policies. It is about time we got on the record what logically follows from his Party's policies.
—Do not so distort what we are talking about.
—I am not distorting at all.
—You are being totally selective and totally misleading in all your comments.

—Which part is wrong; tell me. I have done a great and detailed analysis of this tax proposal. I have written a 10-page paper on it, and economists have not said that there is anything wrong with it at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now get on to the linkage with the economy. The mind boggles. We have been talking about the concept of luxuries but most luxuries in this country are imported; they come from other countries. So how can the Liberal Party of Australia claim that it has policies to close the current account deficit when it will give an enormous boost to imports of luxury goods? It will make luxury goods cheaper; it will bring down the price of luxury cars, diamonds, cosmetics, furs, gold watches-a whole range of things. All these items will come down in price-and they are all imported. Ninety-nine per cent of these items come from overseas. I ask Senator Short and his colleagues: how on earth will the balance of payments be improved by boosting luxury the growth in imports? I am waiting for an answer but I do not hear one.

It is also a very inequitable tax system. Those opposite are proposing to bring in a grossly unfair tax system. I ask Senator Short: what is fair about taxing Mercedes Benzes and margarine at the same rate? Why should yoghurt and yachts be taxed at the same rate? Why should basic items be taxed at the same rate as yachts? Is there any equity in this? I cannot see any. Those opposite want to bring in a very unfair tax system, they want to put up the price of everyday basic items for ordinary Australians and they want to bring down the price of luxuries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are invited by Senator Short to debate the damning admissions by both Mr Keating and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about the economy and about their engineered recession. From the figures before us, it is quite clear that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were indeed wrong in their economic policies and that the objective of their engineered recession has not been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: The objective has always been to improve the balance of payments. Obviously that can be done in two ways: by increasing exports and/or by reducing imports. The Government appears to have concentrated on reducing imports and has done so in the most damaging and clumsy way. To achieve the specific target of import reductions, the Treasurer has chosen to damage economic activity as a whole and the predictable result is before us-a recession and only a marginal improvement in our trade figures; in fact, they continue to deteriorate.

In November we showed a trade deficit in seasonally adjusted terms of $1.36 billion; in December we showed it as $1.77 billion-a deficit of $3 billion in just two months in seasonally adjusted figures. Clearly that strategy is not working. The utter stupidity of that approach-it is like using a sledge hammer to crack a nut-becomes very apparent when one considers that, to even maintain that sort of minimal progress or slowing down of the deterioration, one would have to keep the economy at recession level forever after.

When it became apparent that the strategic objective was not going to be achieved in this way, the rhetoric changed to combating inflation. But now, with a 2.7 per cent consumer price index increase for the December quarter and a current annual rate of 6.9 per cent, there is no dramatic improvement here either. In fact, the marginal drop from 8 to 7 per cent in the annual rate has been achieved by an increase of 250,000 unemployed since October 1989.

But there are other figures to document the utter failure of these economic policies. Retail turnover growth plummeted to 2.6 per cent in November 1990 and is still trending downwards. Bankruptcies have skyrocketed with almost 3,000 occurring during the December quarter. This compares with 1,874 in the previous December quarter-a rise of 56 per cent. Similarly credit growth has collapsed from the speculative binge of the late 1980s level of nearly 20 per cent down to 7 per cent. It further appears that the banks have over-reacted because of the massive bad debts and so-called non-performing loans and are actually rationing credit even though interest rates have dropped considerably.

These sober figures hide social breakdown and human misery on a growing scale. Recently, on behalf of the Australian Catholic Bishops' Conference, the Bishops' Committee for Justice, Development and Peace issued its draft report on wealth distribution in Australia entitled Common Wealth and Common Good. The report demonstrates that inequality continues to grow at an alarming rate. It documents recent surveys showing an increase in the proportion of high income households balanced by a reduction in the proportion of middle income households at a time when the proportion of low income households has continued to grow. As the bishops' report observes:
Clearly the rate of increase of already high incomes and the fact that they're less heavily taxed than in the past have contributed to the widening of the gap.

In his submission to the bishops' report, Phil Ruthven, Chairman of IBIS-international finance analysts-said that Australia's legendary middle class was shrinking while the poverty area consists largely of sole parents, disabled persons without employment and families lacking a bread winner.

We do not compare all that well to other countries in this regard. Dr Peter Saunders, Director of the Social Research Centre at the University of New South Wales, has been studying income distribution in eight developed Western countries. He has found that the share of income going to the 60 per cent of families in the middle to low income range in Australia is smaller than in any of the other countries he studied. Further, contrary to prevailing mythology, Australia spends less on social welfare than most other developed countries and we are not as heavily taxed as most comparable nations.

But the social outfall of this Government's economic policies continue to come before our eyes. Child poverty still exists. The Burdekin report estimated that we have at least 250,000 children who are homeless or are at risk of being homeless. Poverty in farming communities is increasing alarmingly and surveys indicate that the level of child poverty in rural areas is double the national rate.

Two hundred thousand Australian households are on public housing waiting lists. To cap it off, domestic violence is on the increase as families suffer increased economic stress. In a 1989 New South Wales study it was found that families with annual incomes of less than $15,000 were 11 times more likely to experience domestic violence than families enjoying material comfort.

While deregulation, high interest rates and cutting government expenditure are all discredited polices of the Government, the Opposition's remedies are clearly worse. Firstly, it wants to tax all goods and services, as Senator Maguire has demonstrated, and cut high income earners' income tax even further; and, secondly, it has no plan to assist manufacturing industry. Rather, it is in favour of cutting tariffs to the point where manufacturing industry in our country will be destroyed at an even faster rate than the Industry Commission recommends. The car industry is a major employer in my State of Victoria, especially in Geelong, and this industry will certainly not survive without some tariff protection. The same applies to the textile, clothing and footwear sector.

At this point it might be useful if I refer to an article by Mr Ken Davidson in today's Age newspaper. He recounts the results of his survey in the last few weeks in some of the Asian countries which so often are paraded before us as examples of entrepreneurial push and a free market operating on an even keel. The article states:

. . . the fact is that the economic planners in Taiwan and Korea believe that it is necessary to first create international competitive industries that may then be exposed to international competition without government support.

While Singapore has no border protection and the economy is shaped by international market forces, the Government's planners in the Economic Development Board pick winners and offer tax holidays and venture capital on a concessional basis if the company concerned has reasonable prospects of becoming competitive and is in an industry compatible with the overall economic strategy of the Government.
There is no such planning and no such desire to intervene to assist our industries to become internationally competitive in the Opposition's box of policies.

The Opposition's desire not to lift a finger to make constructive action possible can be illustrated by the fact that when accelerated depreciation allowances, for instance, were put on the table as one of the measures, Dr Hewson very quickly sprang into the fray and said that the Opposition would certainly not be supporting accelerated depreciation allowances to assist those industries that had a hope of becoming more competitive and more productive in our export sector. The Opposition is prepared to abolish capital gains tax to fuel speculation, usually of a non-productive nature, where an asset is held for more than five years.
Clearly, the Opposition's policies are a disaster. The Australian Democrats cannot possibly accept paragraph (d) in the motion that Senator Short has moved. That paragraph states:
urges the Government to pursue the policies advocated for so long by the Coalition, to restore sustainable private sector growth and employment.

What a laugh! Clearly the policies that the Opposition is advocating are not going to do any such thing; they are going to deliver our farmers, our workers and our industry to the wolves-they will go by the board. That is the policy of the Opposition and we cannot support it. I will be moving an amendment at the end of my address to delete that particular paragraph from the motion that Senator Short has moved in the Senate today. I believe that the Government is prepared to support that amendment. I trust it has not changed its mind.

I believe that the time has come for us to take specific action in Australia to achieve an increase in our industrial activity, an increase in our competitiveness and, particularly, an increase in our employment. The time has come for governments to accept responsibility to institute policies-and to intervene in the economy-which will achieve the sort of future that is the aspiration of Australians.

Specific measures must be introduced to limit imports. The luxury car tax is actually a very good example of a specific tax which is having a significant impact on restraining unnecessary production, sales and consumption of luxury motor vehicles. Clearly, this move will boost local industry and it certainly helps the merchandising trades and our current account. The Democrats see similar scope with other luxuries such as clocks, watches, furs, weapons and ammunitions, to name but a few.

As I said yesterday, we believe that the procedures for our anti-dumping action need to be improved. At the moment, when dumping of products is discovered it can take up to 12 months before any action is taken. An industry can be destroyed in that time.

The further option which the Democrats believe should be examined is a self-limiting system of controlling imports which has been developed by the Society for Balanced Free Trade and one of its directors, Mr Ernst Rodeck. The proposal involves automatically limiting imports to export performance. No individual quotas would be necessary for any specific product, as the right to import goods would have to be purchased from exporters who automatically obtain the right to import an equivalent value of goods to that exported.

No public money would be necessary and significant benefits would be earned by exporters, thereby providing a huge incentive for international orientation of Australian business. Obviously, certain capital goods and components for products being assembled in Australia would need special treatment, and transitional implementation measures would be complex initially. I believe that the Government should give this proposal serious consideration.

We also believe that the tax system must be further oriented towards production and jobs and away from speculation, otherwise the current trend of relocating production and employment offshore will continue. As mentioned before, we believe that industry should be assisted by accelerated depreciation in selected export sectors that are capable of increasing our export development.

The Democrats believe that the interest withholding tax should be lifted from 10 per cent up to the company tax rate where possible. Many tax avoidance loopholes would be closed by this move but, more particularly, the result of this measure would be to reduce the value of the dollar, thereby assisting our export industry significantly.

In our belief, the most important policy change which must occur is an ideological shift away from deregulation. There is, indeed, a role for government-especially in industrial development-and Australia, because of its high transport costs arising from its isolation, needs an interventionist industrial policy. This approach is so different from the one advocated until now by the Government and, to a much tougher extent by the Opposition, that, as I said, the Democrats are unable to accept paragraph (d) in the motion moved by Senator Short. I move:
Omit paragraph (d).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways this debate is a re-run of a debate we had only yesterday. I will not rehash the points I made yesterday because those concerned would have had the opportunity to hear or read that, and because time would be taken up that others might wish to use in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Suffice to say that as Senator Short failed to make any progress yesterday, either in the debate itself or in gaining any publicity from the attempt, I guess that is why he is trying again today. The debate, I suspect, will go no better for him because the substance of the matter runs so substantially against him. That is not to say that anybody can take joy or comfort from the current economic situation in which Australia finds itself. I do not, and I spoke about that yesterday.

We have had further statistics today which show a small increase in unemployment. Broadly analysed, they may indicate, though it is too early to be sure, a plateauing of the unemployment problem, but in human terms the position is very serious for those individuals adversely affected and a source of reasonable and proper concern.

Today I turn to the part that is different from the proposal that was put forward yesterday. I shall give brief attention to some of the matters raised by the Opposition in its own policy proposal. That which differs in today's motion from yesterday's is paragraph (d) to which Senator Spindler referred, namely, the call for the Government to adopt the policies of the Opposition. There is one thing one can say of the conservatives in Australia. They may not have many redeeming features, but I suppose that one is consistency. Over the 20 or so years in which I have been involved in politics, conservatives have always had the same solution. They oppose inflation by putting up prices, they fight unemployment by putting people out of work, and they deal with workers' living standards by keeping down wages. The rhetoric has changed a little over the last 20 years, but the outcome has been the same. It is serious and important that we should continue to focus on that. It is a stark contrast which the Australian people cannot be allowed to forget.

One of the most important possible achievements that an Australian government can contribute to the success of Australian business is a reduction in inflation. I want to talk more about inflation and alternative strategies for dealing with it in good time. We are at the moment poised in a position where, for the first time in a generation, Australia may be able to break the back of inflation and inflationary expectations. Serious economists are predicting-and yesterday I read into Hansard the Westpac Banking Corporation prediction and others-that by 1992 we may be back in a reasonable growth economy of 2.5 to 3 per cent growth with inflation at 4 per cent, following a year in which inflation in 1991 is predicted at about 4.5 per cent. That is creating the situation where expectations of inflation may be broken, and therefore we can start to see a long term downward trend in inflation reinforced by the wage-tax agreements between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Therefore, it will lead to a long term fall in interest rates, reducing the cost of capital to Australian business and making business significantly more competitive.

What is the very worst thing one could conceive of in a climate where one might be about to break the inflationary cycle? It would be a massive one-off increase in prices through a consumption tax. There is no doubt that the Australian indirect tax system needs reform. It is a matter to which I am giving significant time and to which the Government is giving attention, and it is a long term and important task. But it would be fundamentally flawed economically to now give such a stimulus to prices on the first occasion for a generation when we have a chance to break the back of inflation. It would be fundamentally flawed socially for the reasons that were outlined so eloquently by my colleague Senator Maguire. He was absolutely correct in his analysis of the social consequences of the type of broadly based consumption tax proposed by the Opposition.

In dramatically changed circumstances in 1991, the Opposition is plaintively pursuing what it saw as a golden opportunity in 1985. We now have the situation in Australia that is far different from 1985 or at any other time in Australia's history, when the balance of direct and indirect taxation in Australia is similar to the average in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Because of the changes that have been made in income and consumption tax, the revenue gain is not and will not be sufficient to provide proper compensation for the less well off to enable cuts in marginal tax rates to offset the high price level associated with a consumption tax.

We also have the situation where the top marginal tax rate now is lower than that proposed in option C. The proposal in option C in 1985 to say that there needed to be a change in the indirect tax base so that we could fund a cut in the top marginal tax rate to get it down to internationally competitive levels was for the top marginal tax rate to be cut dramatically to 50c. It is now 47c. Therefore, the whole rationale has fundamentally changed. Now, the lust for a consumption tax is driven by the desire to feed major tax cuts into the best off in our community by further reducing the top marginal tax rate for those on the highest incomes. It will also deliver to those people the most substantial benefits because the luxury items that they consume will be those in relation to which prices will fall most. It is those people who spend the lowest percentage of their income on the goods whose prices will rise the most. It is economically irresponsible, it is socially adverse and unjust, and it is trying to adopt a 1985 solution to a 1991 problem. Therefore, it is fundamentally flawed and should be rejected. Its most profound problem is that, at a time when we have a key opportunity to give priority to breaking the back of inflation, a one-off boost to prices would be disastrous.

Far from the problem of tax being the most serious in our society-not that I underestimate it-I believe that the most serious social problem generated economically is that of unemployment. The Opposition's solution to unemployment would only make the situation dramatically worse. Every economically literate person knows that in a time of tight fiscal policy proposals to advocate dramatic further cuts in fiscal policy will only exacerbate unemployment. I am not saying that Opposition members are a malevolent bunch whose intention is to throw people on to the scrap heap. Those are emotions of the past. I say that those people are wrong and ill-informed and that that would be the unintended consequence of their actions. In 1991 in a situation involving a uniquely tight fiscal policy in Australia, a situation in which we are in a recession, to advocate dramatic cuts in fiscal policy is socially irresponsible and can only exaggerate the profound economic and social problems that we have in Australia.

At present, fiscal policy is loosening cyclically because, in the post-1930s Depression world, the change to the welfare system whereby people receive unemployment benefits when out of work has led to a cyclical correction being built into contemporary economic policy. Welfare payments go up and the tax take goes down in a recession, loosening fiscal policy and leading to some automatic correction. To be advocating at this time that a part of the solution to the recession is to cut fiscal policy further is the height of social irresponsibility. The most profound contradiction of all is the concern that one frequently hears expressed that wages have not risen sufficiently and that workers have lost real wages during the time of this Government. Those who so argue ignore statistics, such as household disposable income, which do not suit their argument.

Let us deal with the subject of wages. In the 20 years I have been involved in public life there has never been a time when the Liberal Party has supported any wage increase at all on any occasion. However, Liberal members are now shedding crocodile tears about workers' wages while they are advocating that the $12 wage increase scheduled for the first half of this year should be abandoned, which is hardly the way to improve living standards for ordinary Australian workers. Under the guise of so-called deregulation of the labour market, the only way that that can achieve the purpose that those opposite advocate is if it leads to lower wage outcomes.

The solution is obvious. Why is the Opposition supporting the crushing of the opportunities for growth by tighter fiscal policy? Why is it supporting the cutting of wages? Because it has no other anti-inflationary strategy and because it cannot deal with wages policy. It has no anti-inflationary strategy other than crushing the growth out of the economy through restrictive fiscal policy and cutting wages. Therefore, any party that is proposing to introduce a consumption tax and to give a massive one-off increase to prices cannot deal with the inflationary consequences without crushing growth. Any chance of the recovery that this Government is creating the preconditions for out of this recession-which will come-can only be dealt with by a conservative government with no anti-inflationary strategy and by cutting fiscal policy and cutting wages.

As I say, the only thing we can say for the conservatives in Australia is that they do have consistency. They have always advocated coping with inflation by putting up prices; coping with unemployment by putting people out of work and coping with the problems of workers' living standards by cutting wages. They are advocating nothing different now and that is why this motion ought to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot help but feel sorry for the Australian Labor Party taking part in this debate tonight. We have had Senator Maguire giving us a diatribe of arrant nonsense which purported to pass for an attack on the policies of the Liberal Party of Australia. Yet the real intent of his speech was, `Do not worry; stay happy; she'll be all right because this Labor Government is really doing a good job'. Senator McMullan in more sophisticated language has told us exactly the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Prime Minister of the day (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer of the day (Mr Keating) have finally had the decency to acknowledge that even the most willing support by Senators Maguire and McMullan is nonsensical because they have finally admitted in the words of the Prime Minister on the Sunday program on 10 February:
We obviously got wrong a proposition that said there would not be a recession.
The Treasurer on 8 February said:
The Government did not want a recession; it wanted a slowdown.
He also told us that we were having the recession that we had to have which, in turn, means that the unemployed are having the lack of employment they also had to have.

In all the speeches tonight from the Labor Party and in all the speeches from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer there is not an excuse, no explanation offered, no remorse, no apology-simply a statement that they got it wrong and they failed the Australian people. There are 600,000 people who are now unemployed and they deserve better than that. The business men and women who have had to close their doors on years of hard work and saving, only to find themselves bereft of everything they have worked for, deserve better than to be told by the Government leaders that they got it wrong.

The suffering that this country is having under this Government's economic regime is as sad and debilitating as any we have seen in place in this country for more than 60 years. The inflation rate announced yesterday vindicates what I said in this chamber when the last quarterly consumer price index figures came down. That is when I said that the then 6 per cent inflation figure was an illusory figure and that it reflected prices during the Treasurer's petrol price freeze at the time when oil prices were being blown out of the water by Saddam Hussein. Prices rose considerably after the freeze was removed and we see this reflected in the annual inflation figure of 6.9 per cent announced yesterday. It is apparent that inflation will tend to fall in the short term. Let there be no mistake as to the reason that it will fall. It will not be the result of any anti-inflationary policy which is sadly lacking from this Government. It will be the direct consequence of the collapse of asset prices, the like of which we have not seen since the 1930s.

The trend of corporate decline and the record levels of small business failures will be directly reflected in the general price level. This lower inflation rate will be unsustainable and will be the by-product rather than the goal of any distinct positive policy of Mr Keating. The continual failure of the Treasurer and the trade union movement to realise that the need for inflation reduction is dependent upon wages and fiscal policy and the fact that we have a centralised wage fixing system have simply institutionalised the expectation of inflation and, accordingly, increased wages.

That institutionalised expectation was borne out only yesterday and again on the AM program this morning when the National Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, Mr George Campbell, said that the high cost of living rise for December justified bringing forward from 16 May to early April the claim of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for a wage rise of $12 a week. This would be the worst possible option we could have at the time when unemployment is skyrocketing. This is the Government that has said to us again and again, every time that there was a negative response to its policies that, after all, it had kept employment growing; it had kept people in jobs. That is just not happening now. Every ounce of the Government's policies is putting additional pressure on employers who are simply buckling and unable to keep those employees they have already, let alone add new employees to their payrolls.

The problem with the labour market is that it is not a labour market at all. It is not a market. Wages are determined by the ACTU and the Treasurer together. Employers are excluded and, indeed, so are employees. The idea that employees and employers should be allowed to talk together without having the need for a third party to negotiate the best wages and conditions for them is part of our policy. It is not part of this Government's policy. It is certainly not the aim of the ACTU, whose vested interest is to keep its finger in every pie.

The Labor Party will tell us that the accord has been a wonderful solution and served the country well. Indeed, the accord is part of the problem. Mr Keating has completely failed to consider the micro-economic implications of the accord and its failure to generate desirable micro-economic incentives. The centralised process is anti-productivity, anti-competition, as wage increases are applied across the board irrespective of the condition or strength of particular firms or industries. The result is a disequilibrium and the only way in which the market can clear is through rampant unemployment. Surely this is an inhumane policy.

This, and the impact it is having, can be demonstrated in various parts of Sydney, for instance, particularly in the west of Sydney. Today's Sydney Morning Herald shows how the Government's policies have impacted on the ordinary decent Australians who live in the west. Over the past year the dole queues have grown by an average of 33 per cent in western Sydney with areas such as Mount Druitt experiencing increases of 64 per cent; St Marys, 66 per cent and Merrylands, 70 per cent. So much for a soft landing. So much for hope.

These are the policies of disillusionment. Indeed, the word to describe these policies that the Government has wrought on this nation is shameful. The cold hard reality is that this is the Treasurer's own personally designed recession. In the past year, new capital expenditure was down by 3.4 per cent; new motor vehicle receipts were down by 10.6 per cent; dwelling approvals were down by 12.1 per cent; the value of building work was down by 10.6 per cent; commercial finance commitments were down by 12.1 per cent; job vacancies were down by 28 per cent; and after Cabinet's decision on Monday, it is official that the bottom has finally gone from the wool market.

By tying fiscal policy to wages policy, monetary policy has been all that the Government has been left with to deal with the economy. The result has been that tight monetary policy has led to an unnaturally high exchange rate, despite the intervention on the foreign exchange market, and crippling interest rates which, in turn, have strangled investment and stifled demand.

The net outcome has been a record number of personal bankruptcies, small business and bank failures, the collapse of investment and staggering levels of job losses. We may well say that the Treasurer's view has been that Australia had to be brought to its knees before we could see any improvement. We have one of the worst recessions in 60 years. But the Treasurer is not the only guilty party. In other areas, those requiring micro-economic reform, he has had handmaidens and accomplices. Micro-economic reform was the catchcry of the third Hawke Administration; yet we have had a failed industry policy, overseen by Senator Button, and we have seen nothing but dismal failure.

Quite simply, we have seen the failure to bring about a systematic revitalisation of Australian industry. Whether this has been brought about by sectoral plans, bounty and grants schemes, procurement and offsets policies, partnerships for development, the scandal of the Australian Customs Service or the failed management and investment companies scheme, Senator Button and his Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce have failed to establish tangible benefits for manufacturers, exporters or consumers.

The latest monument to the failing policies comes in the form of the McKinsey report on the operations of the Australian Trade Commission. That body, known as Austrade, was bitterly fought over by Senator Button and Senator Evans. Which would have it-the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade? If the policies of the Government were to remain the same it would not matter which department it went with.

The findings of that report-which Senator Button said in answer to questions today he would release, and I hope he keeps that commitment and releases it immediately-have been leaked to the Australian, to Chris Wallace. Senator Button said in Question Time today that the McKinsey report undertook a very frank review and a lot of faults were found. `Frank' could be the understatement of the year. Chris Wallace wrote, from her leaked version of the report, in a way in which the key words gave an indication of what is to come when we are finally able to read the report. She wrote that Austrade `lacks focus'; has an `inadequate management structure', `poor priorities' and `poor performance'; is `too desk-bound and paper driven'; that resources utilised overseas `are being devoted to the wrong markets'; that it has a `topheavy, highly centralised structure'.

It is no good saying that the Commission is an autonomous body and outside the reach of the Government and the Minister of the day. It simply will not do. When the Government claims to be the elected government of the nation, overseeing and implementing policies, I am afraid it has to take responsibility for the bodies even though it has purported to turn them into so-called independent entities. The report, apparently, will point out that about one-third of Austrade staff are deployed overseas, and that there are more resources in the United States than there are employed in Thailand, Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia and India collectively. The emphasis needs to be on establishing markets rather than providing information on existing ones.

As I said at the beginning, we have had the embarrassing spectacle of watching Government senators trying to defend the deplorable record of the policies which have been seen, overseen and implemented by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. We have seen the ploy used by Senator Maguire of setting up the straw man and knocking him down. So paltry was his own material that he had to invent what he thought would be our version of the goods and services tax. One can only suppose that he had to go back to his own Government's proposals for such a tax in 1985. There is plenty of that material around, acres, volumes of it-all the statements of Mr Keating saying why we had to have such a tax. Quite clearly, whatever recollections Senator Maguire was relying upon came from the documentation prepared by his own side of politics. As I said, one did have a smidgin of sorrow for the plight and the difficulties into which it was put.

Nobody tonight has had the gall to defend, at this stage, the industry policies that have been put in place-except that one of the Australian Democrats tried to say that Victoria needed to have more protection because the only industries it had were protected industries and that somehow that would make things better for Victoria. If we compare it with New South Wales, where we got rid of most of those industries and we have a booming economy, I think there are some lessons to be learnt.

We are looking forward on 12 March to the industry statement and to see what pious hopes the Government might try to hang, or salvage, its reputation on for the remaining and dwindling months that it will remain in office. Although the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have at last admitted that they got it wrong, this country has not got too many chances left. If the Government is fair dinkum about letting Australia have a chance, then it will pick up the policies that the Opposition has been offering and we will give it our bipartisan support. I ask Senator McMullan to think about it seriously because the future of millions of Australians depends on that decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Short's motion, which notes the damning admission of policy failure by the Treasurer (Mr Keating):

SPEECH.PARA: the Government did not want a recession, it wanted a slow down-
and-
it is a slow down, not a recession, that Australia requires.
and which notes the equally stunning admission by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):
We obviously got wrong a proposition that said there would not be a recession.

It condemns the Government for the massive hardship its disastrous miscalculations and mismanagement have wrought on all Australians and urges the Government to pursue the policies advocated for so long by the coalition to restore sustainable private sector growth and employment.

What a terrible mess this country is in after eight years of this Government. Senator Maguire came into the chamber before and started to talk about equity and justice and what someone on $20,000 would receive as a result of what this Government was going to give that person. That person on $20,000 cannot see any equity or justice in what has happened to him or her because unless his or her partner is also earning $20,000 they, frankly, cannot survive on $20,000 under this Government. They are having the hell taxed out of them at $20,000 under this Government. There is no equity or justice in that. There is no equity or justice in what the people out there are suffering-the pain and hardship and the unemployment that the Government was going to do so much about in 1982. Has the Government forgotten all of that?

TALK.START.PARA: —And did.

—What does Senator McMullan mean by `and did'? By robbing the country of its resources it created some employment, some jobs, for the short period of time and now it has all collapsed on the Government. It is exactly the same as the State of Victoria. It managed to reduce its unemployment by a very substantial amount by selling off all the assets of the State. It has sold off all of the assets of the State, it has bankrupted the State, and now let us look at what is happening to unemployment in the State of Victoria. It is absolutely disastrous-again, under a Labor government. A Labor government in South Australia has created havoc there and a Labor government in Western Australia has created havoc there. Senator Maguire comes along in here and starts talking about equity and justice in Australia.
—Eighteen per cent unemployment in Victoria in the last 12 months.

—I thank Senator Short. There has been an 80 per cent increase in unemployment in Victoria in the last 12 months, and that Government managed to hide those despicable figures at the last election by clever manipulation of its media sycophants. The Western Australian Labor Government managed to hide its figures prior to the last Western Australian election thanks to its media sycophants, and this Government by clever media manipulation until now has tried to hide, and has succeeded in hiding from many people, the terrible things that it has been doing to this economy that we have been talking about since 1985-86. But finally it has got through.

SPEECH.PARA: Even as late as last December, when it was clear that the economy was in a state of deep recession, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were saying, `It is not a recession. We have not had two successive quarters of negative growth'. Everyone out there knew we were in recession, but the Government still manipulated the media and the Treasurer is still manipulating the media even now and talking other figures. But the people out there are fed up with it; they are not putting up with it any longer. They are fed up with this Government and they are fed up with the misleading that this Government continually goes on with in its media releases and what Mr Keating says during his press conferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —The big lies.

—The big lies continually. The Government is very clever at it; one has to acknowledge that. It finds some other figure and talks about that. The media sycophants report all this other information but somehow or other keep missing the big figures.

SPEECH.PARA: The current account deficit is a disaster. It has been a disaster for five years. For five years the current account deficit has been a disaster, and this Government has known it and has not done anything about it. The current quarterly rate of inflation is over 10.4 per cent per annum. What does the Government do? It produces a figure and says-those opposite would not do this when we were in government-`but, if we add it all up together, the current annual rate is only 6.5 per cent' or something or other.

The rate at which inflation is running at the present moment is nearly 10.5 per cent, and that is on the Government's revised figures. Honourable senators opposite will recall that from time to time this Government in office has changed the calculation of the consumer price index so as to reduce the CPI effect in the figures. This has been done repeatedly; the big lie in relation to the CPI. It has been happening all the time under this Government. But the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have finally had to concede that there is a recession. The current account deficit is a disaster and the CPI is a disaster-an absolute disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —The foreign debt is a disaster.
—The foreign debt is a disaster. Notwithstanding all the talk, notwithstanding all the yapping by Hawke and all the yapping by Keating--
—Order! Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President. Notwithstanding all the yapping by Mr Hawke, by Mr Keating and by those people on the other side of this chamber, what we have been saying to them for years has finally been revealed: they are not doing enough to fix the problems of this country. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.PARA: The big levers that Mr Keating talks about have been pulled in the wrong direction. The micro-economic reform that honourable senators opposite talk about frankly does not exist. It is peripheral nonsense. Most of it has been devised to enable people employed in the government statutory authorities to get an increase in their salaries so that they can catch up to the private sector, and the Government has called that a micro-economic reform. The Government has changed the name and the constitution of some institution so that, instead of its being a government statutory authority responsible to this Parliament, it has become a company not responsible to this Parliament, and in that way the members of that body have been able to give themselves an increase in salary. The Government has called that micro-economic reform. That is not what micro-economic reform is all about.

Yesterday I asked Senator Collins about waterfront reform. He tried to tell the Parliament that there have been very significant changes in waterfront reform in the last 12 months. But the waterside workers on Wednesday were still having their annual picnic. They were still having their annual picnic as if it was about 150 years ago when they all went by horse and buggy down to the beach for the day. Where did they have their picnic in Sydney yesterday? Did they all go to Bondi beach or somewhere for their annual picnic? Of course not; they took the day off. Most of them probably managed to flex off on Monday and Tuesday so that they could have a long weekend running right through until Wednesday, or flex off on Thursday and Friday so that they could have a long weekend running through this weekend. The Government calls that moving substantially towards micro-economic reform on the waterfront! It is absolute nonsense in 1991. Those opposite will not address that problem. They cannot address that problem because of their relationship with the trade union movement. They do not have the courage.

The coalition of three parties opposite cannot work together to produce any substantial micro-economic reform in this country which is worth while. They have been talking about it now for five or six years and achieving absolutely nothing. It is totally inadequate. Mr Keating knows about it. I am sure he addresses those opposite about these matters and he certainly would address his Cabinet about them, but those opposite cannot organise it. They cannot organise it because the left wing will not allow them to do this, the right wing will not allow them to do that, and the trade union movement will not allow them to do anything even if the three of them could agree on what they were going to do. Talk about a coalition of hopeless politicians!

It is an absolute nonsense to think that this country is being run by people who simply cannot achieve the sorts of things which this country has to have done this decade-which should have been done in the last four or five years but just have to be completed before the year 2000. We are going down the drain so fast that we have probably already become the equivalent of a Third World country. We can see that by the poverty out there in the streets. People on $20,000 a year are being taxed to hell, as Senator Maguire talks about, and are unable to meet their commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had we realised what was going to happen to this Bill in the 3 1/2 years from when it was introduced until it was voted on, we would probably have considered moving some amendments to it. One potential amendment stands out. That amendment, which we would have dealt with at this stage, is that it would be a requirement in the Act that there be a chairman of the Australia Council. There is still no chairman. It is probably too late for us at this stage to amend the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to raise this matter because it struck me as curious that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, in his summing up of the second reading debate, replied to most of the other points made by members of the Opposition, and indeed by the Australian Democrats, but did not mention the point that there was still no chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might be keeping it open for Keating.

—Yes, the ex-manager of the Ramrods may be as inappropriate, and no more inappropriate, than a lot of the other names that have not only been touted but for whom I believe the job has been `hawked', if I can use that word loosely, unsuccessfully by this Government. I remind the Committee that, when Donald Horne was appointed to this job, he was appointed to it seven months before the due date that he was to take over chairmanship.

SPEECH.PARA: In the present situation a whole host of people were approached and one very publicly knocked it back. We are well into February and, although it is St Valentine's Day, the Government does not love anybody as far as this job is concerned. As I said, this would have been an amendment had we realised that there was need for such an amendment when this matter first came before us.

I ask the Government through the Minister in charge of the Senate at the moment, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), whether we can expect a response to the concerns that we have about the lack of a chairman of the Australia Council. Can he give us any indication of when the Government intends to get around to actually appointing a chairman of what is supposed to be the most prestigious arts funding body in Australia? Does the Government intend to keep going on without a chairman? Will the Government take the advice of Mr Nelson of radio station JJJ and appoint Mr Geyer, the Penrith second rower, as the chairman in the hope of getting some strength in the ruck?
