SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the issue of Question Time in this chamber. As many honourable senators will be aware, there is considerable concern about the number of questions which are answered during Question Time. Why does this Government answer only some 22 questions, on average, in Question Time when all other governments in memory could answer some 28 questions or more? The issue has been canvassed in this chamber. As far as I am concerned, no satisfactory explanation has been given. One view that has been put is that there are too many structured questions.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have much experience in this chamber, but I am at a loss to understand why a so-called structured Question Time would involve longer answers than a so-called free Question Time. Indeed, judging from recent experience it could be argued that a structured Question Time can produce a record number of questions. For example, as Senator Tate will attest, on 10 May last year we had some 31 questions at Question Time, which was a record for this Government in recent years. A majority of these questions were directed to Senator Tate regarding a press briefing he gave on an issue relating to drug charges before the court. I was not a senator at that stage, but on reading the Hansard it seems to me that we had a structured Question Time with a vengeance.

Another view which has been put is that a too strict enforcement of Standing Orders produces chaos. I do not deny the fact that flexibility is needed, but what of the counterargument that a loose interpretation of Standing Orders-which is the current practice in the other place-produces very few questions? The other place is lucky to achieve 14 questions in 45 minutes; a performance which, it has to be admitted, is even worse than in this chamber.

No-one denies that we have had a more liberal approach to Standing Orders in recent years. That is stated in the recent report of the Procedure Committee which Senator Ray brought before this chamber. Yet this more liberal interpretation of Standing Orders has produced, on average, low numbers of questions being answered per day compared with previous governments. I think that we must look elsewhere for an explanation.

Another view put forward-by Senator Coates, I believe-is that we have many senior and very important Ministers in this chamber. I do not argue with that. Whether they are good Ministers is a different matter. I do not plan to enter into that issue this evening. In any case, history will make the final judgment. In some cases they are certainly very verbose Ministers.

Can we say that the reason the numbers in Question Time have fallen so precipitously is the fact that we have eight Ministers in the Senate rather than the six we had during the last Fraser Government? Have the number of answers to questions fallen because we have six Cabinet Ministers in the Senate rather than four, as was more typical during the Fraser period? I do not think that that type of argument stands up. I would have thought that the most obvious and satisfactory explanation is that Ministers are simply taking too long to answer questions. It is not complicated; it is straightforward. We have one hour for Question Time and very few answers are given. What is the reason for that? Essentially, but not exclusively, the reason is long answers. Of course, some answers must be long because they deal with important and weighty subjects.

In response to a question by Senator Hill today, Senator Evans gave a long-I am sure this is the view of all honourable senators-but important answer. The Government would respond that some of the questions are too long. Senator Faulkner sometimes makes that sort of accusation. I agree. Senator Powell today, for example, seemed to be making a speech rather than asking a question. Whatever the sins of Senator Powell and the rest of us concerning the length of questions, let us face the fact that it pales into insignificance compared with the length of answers.

I think we make a mistake if we try to think of too complex explanations for the poor performance, on average, of the Hawke Government Ministers in answering questions. It has little to do, in my view, with a structured Question Time or the number of Cabinet Ministers in this chamber, as Senator Cook alleges. It has more to do with longwinded answers, often by Senator Bolkus, Senator Cook and possibly Senator Collins. No-one will deny that long answers are often in response to dorothy dixers. At times these answers are more like ministerial statements than answers to questions. This is an issue for Standing Orders. We all seem to agree that it is better to answer more questions in Question Time than fewer. Even Senator Ray said yesterday:
. . . in Question Time we should try to get more numbers up . . .

To that I can only respond: hear, hear! The final point I wish to make is that I do not think the statistics sustain the point that the performance of Ministers in Question Time is improving. I have carefully examined the statistics tabled by the President yesterday. For the life of me, I cannot discern any significant improvement in Question Time performance as measured by the numbers of questions answered. Indeed, the performances seem remarkably consistent over the period of the Hawke Government. In the past three days the number of questions, including supplementaries, that have been answered is 21, 21 and 17. If this trend continues, 1991 may well be one of our poorer years. As Senator Ray said, it is important to get the numbers up. Yesterday I said in the chamber, and I quote:
I am not urging--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not too much of an authority.

—We always wait for a contribution from Senator Faulkner; we really do. Senator Faulkner never makes speeches in this Parliament, but on the odd occasion he can work up his courage to make some utterly inane comment. As I was saying-and I quote myself as an authority-in respect of Question Time:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not urging that it be tightly constrained by rules--

TALK.START.PARA: —You were yesterday.

—Senator Ray should read the Hansard. He should get his Hansard out. Senator Ray makes a lot of accusations but he should read the Hansard. I will quote again from my speech in Hansard yesterday for the benefit of Senator Ray.
—History repeats itself.
—I am repeating myself, but Senator Ray did not listen yesterday, so he might listen today.
—Good authority, too.

— Thank you, Senator Macdonald. This is what I said yesterday. Senator Robert Ray should call for his Hansard, get it out and read it. I am sorry that my quotation is causing such enormous controversy from the Minister at the table. If I can make my fifth and final try, this is what I said about Question Time:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not urging that it be tightly constrained by rules, but I am urging that we should see a tighter application of standing orders.

This was, somewhat surprisingly in view of the astonishing reaction yesterday, the effect of a recommendation which the Procedure Committee presented to this chamber via Senator Ray and which was accepted by the President. I say that we should get the numbers up; Senator Ray says we should get the numbers up. There is no argument there; Senator Ray and I are both agreed on the matter. I say that there should be a tighter application of Standing Orders; Senator Ray says, in the report presented to the chamber yesterday and accepted by the President, that there should be a tighter application of Standing Orders. No argument there. The question I ask myself is: why should I have been subjected to such a vitriolic attack by Senator Ray? Let us recall what he said. In effect it was: `I am not a man of vengeance but, if I am ever over that side, I will get you'. That is really an impressive performance by a senior Minister in the Hawke Government. You will have a pretty early chance to be over on this side and then you will have a really good chance to get me and the rest of my colleagues, and it will be a long time in the getting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, if you have any more to say, can you say it through the Chair?
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I certainly will, but you would understand that I am being unduly provoked by the senior Minister at the table.
—Harangued.

—Yes, thank you, Senator Macdonald. What was missing from the debate yesterday-and now we are blessed with the presence of Senator Ray at the table-was any recognition by Senator Ray, by Senator Coates and, indeed I have to say regrettably, by the President that the fundamental problem of too few answers in Question Time was excessively long answers by Ministers. That is not complicated; it is straightforward. But why was it not said?
—Because of Senator Cook.

—I will come to Senator Cook shortly. We do not need any other explanation for the poor performance in Question Time during the Hawke Government. I suggest that this message, which was noticeably missing from yesterday's debate, now be given. I sought the chance to seek leave to make some comments yesterday, but Senator Ray, in his usual abrasive and aggressive fashion, refused leave. Senator Ray must now sit in the chamber tonight to hear the perfectly reasonable and sensible comments that I would have made yesterday. Frankly, Senator Ray has brought this on himself. Had he adopted a more constructive approach yesterday, he would not be sitting listening to me this evening. Even Senator Ray would agree that that would be a blessing.
—So does everybody else in the chamber.

—It does not matter. I am focusing on Senator Ray and I can see from the strong support I have received from Senator Macdonald and Senator Patterson that they are delighted I am in this chamber making these points.
—Proud.
—Thank you, Senator Macdonald.
—Wait until there is a double dissolution preselection and see whether you can get Senator Patterson's support.
—Senator Ray has to worry about his preselections in Victoria. Kim Carr of the socialist left is joining Senator Ray, and Senator Ray is not pleased about that one iota.
—Order! it might be better if we were to return to the main subject.

—I was diverted slightly to speak about Kim Carr of the socialist left, who is now waiting anxiously in the wings to join Senator Ray and his colleagues in the Senate. Senator Ray, I am pleased to report to the Senate, shows no enthusiasm for the advent of Kim Carr. Some honourable senators on this side ask themselves why Senator Button is staying on when he looks so tired and exhausted. The answer, colleagues, is simply this-and Senator Ray knows it; I know it and everybody, including Senator Faulkner there, knows it--
—It will be made compulsory by the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party.

—That is another great interjection from Senator Faulkner, to be recorded in the Hansard. I am being provoked by the Minister at the table, but I would make an obvious point: Senator Ray seems to be worried about the Liberals in Victoria. Does Senator Ray know what the Labor Party-his Party-in Victoria is currently recording in the polls?
—Have a guess-30 per cent, 25 per cent?

—Wrong, Senator Macdonald. So often Senator Macdonald is right, but on this occasion he is absolutely wrong; it is 22 per cent. The Labor Party-the Party of Senator Ray, who sat at the table and provoked me and who insisted that I stand up tonight to respond to make some points about Question Time, which could have been done yesterday-is scoring 22 per cent in the polls. What a great Party! Senator Ray called it the Albania of the south in Victoria. I did not call it the Albania of the south, but I will tell Senator Ray that his mates down in Victoria are turning it into the Albania of the south. However, the happy thing is that, like communist parties all through eastern Europe, the Labor Party is facing wipeoutsville in Victoria. If you want to speak about the Labor Party in Victoria, I will do so any time you want to.
—Order! I ask Senator Kemp to direct his remarks through the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. But I am being provoked by Senator Ray.
—Senator Kemp, there is no need for you to be provoked. Just direct your remarks through the Chair.

—It is very hard, Mr Deputy President. I am a new senator facing a very experienced person at the table. He has been very provocative in raising issues concerning the Labor Party in Victoria. I do not think anyone in this chamber would get up and defend the Labor Party in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to get back to the issue which I seek to address on the adjournment tonight and which I sought to address yesterday. I sought the leave of Senator Ray at the table to make some comments. You were in the chair, Mr Deputy President, and you firmly asked me to seek leave from Senator Ray and he denied it. I could have made all these points last night, but Senator Ray insisted that I come in here tonight and make them. I appreciate his being here.

TALK.START.PARA: —All your colleagues are squirming.
—Order! I think you might be being provocative.
—It is the only time I have ever been provocative.

—We have been complaining in this chamber that occasionally the Chair should turn its attention to the other side of the chamber and we certainly appreciate your instructions to Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner, Mr Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the issue of Question Time and the dreary length of answers which we are subjected to in Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think you are on firm ground talking about great length.

—Senator Collins comes in. He saved up for an hour to make that comment and it was a real zinger. Last night when he had a chance to make a comment on the adjournment what did he do? I looked at the Hansard this morning eagerly awaiting his incisive comments, but he left the chamber without making a comment. He was struck dumb for once in his life.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to conclude my speech on the adjournment debate. It may help, Mr Deputy President, if you could give some instructions to the two Ministers who are now in the chamber. I must say I am flattered that two Ministers have come into the chamber for the adjournment debate. However, I would like to conclude.

TALK.START.PARA: —So would we all.
—You are really embarrassing your colleagues. You look behind you. Senator Bishop is embarrassed.

—Senator Faulkner's colleagues are ceaselessly embarrassed by him. He is one of the most embarrassing new senators to have come into this chamber. To suggest that the distinguished Senator Bishop is embarrassed is complete and utter nonsense.
—I have to say again that this is not as good as you think it is.

—Well, why is Senator Collins in here? He should go out; it is quite simple. I do not recall asking Senator Collins to come into the chamber. He has come in and now he is complaining. There is no issue involved; he should get out.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may conclude, Mr Deputy President--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have our permission-that was a conversation stopper.

—Would the Minister like to repeat that? It was such an incomprehensible interjection. The message regarding Question Time which was noticeably missing from yesterday's debate should now be given, and it is this: if Ministers become self-indulgent and excessively long in their answers, the President should use Standing Orders, which are available to him, to bring answers to an end. If this is done we will certainly achieve more questions being asked in Question Time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators, right around the chamber, for their contributions tonight. It was very good to hear the honourable senator from Victoria trying to make a better speech than he obviously made yesterday. Turning to the reason Senator Kemp was not given leave yesterday, one of the disadvantages of speaking early in a debate is that one gets sweated on. One puts up all one's arguments early and other people come in, not always even representing one's arguments accurately. They often knock them down, irrespective of the logic that one has used. That is one of the unlucky points of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: When Senator Kemp has been here a bit longer he will notice that a senator from Western Australia always speaks at the end of debates. He never misses. If there are 30 speakers on the list he is always twenty-eighth. He has learnt the lesson that if one speaks last and this side runs out of speakers, one never gets attacked. Unfortunately for Senator Kemp yesterday, he had to get up and make his cogent points and he had other people come in and attack. Some of the attack was valid and some was not. He felt frustrated and therefore he wanted to respond yesterday. But politics is a bit tougher than that. One has to learn to win or wear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are in here tonight and you don't want to be here.
—Order! Senator Kemp, we have heard from you tonight.

—My car is not booked until about 20 minutes to 12. I am quite happy to be here. If Senator Kemp wants me to turn this into a half-hour speech I will. However, I will not do so. I have a couple of points to make on the substantive issues that Senator Kemp has raised. Whether his obsession with Standing Orders is healthy or not for his political career, I do not know. I would not mind seeing him broaden his horizons just a little, but maybe that is unfair. Just concentrating on Standing Orders will get him nowhere. I suggest he go to some of the broader issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the numbers in Question Time, 21 : 21 is an average performance. Today was a very poor performance in terms of achievement. Maybe Senator Kemp should come and sit on this side in Question Time and hear how many times Ministers are interrupted. Senator Button, in answer to one question today, was interrupted 30 or 40 times by those opposite. So, when they call the President to rule things orderly and to make achievements here and tell Ministers such as myself to sit down, at the same time the President is going to tell them to shut up and stop the constant barrage of interjections. No-one objects to the odd barrage. What Senator Kemp was subjected to tonight is what most Ministers are subjected to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Yes, you were, just by two or three people. When 15 or 20 people are doing that-interrupting the flow of answers-the answers will lengthen. When we talk about behaviour in this chamber it is a two-way street. I do not know what the perfect number is in Question Time-whether it is 20 or 25. I have often thought that even the formula we use in this place is probably unnecessary. I think that sometimes some of the questions we get from our own side are unnecessary. Some are; some are just fillers. It has been ever thus since the existence of parliament-either in the House of Representatives or the Senate. We take our quota to fill in the time. If it had taken Senator Evans seven minutes to answer Senator Hill's question today, I do not think anyone in this chamber would have objected. It was a serious, current question about the tragedy in Baghdad yesterday. So one would expect a seven-minute answer to that.
—Why do we get 10 minutes from Cook every time?

—We do not, and we have not this week. With all due respect, the one long answer we got from Senator Cook today was when we had a continual barrage of interjections from those opposite-non-stop. Quite clearly, this week Senator Cook has abbreviated his answers. That is obvious to anyone.
—What about multiple questions within questions?

—That is right. We are getting these long questions. Meanwhile, Senator Alston and others are firing more questions in. Some of us ignore them and others try to be helpful and answer them. If we actually added up some of the questions answered by way of interjection today, we would be up around 25 or 26.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem of people being frustrated by not being able to ask questions has been exacerbated by many matters. The fault is neither on this side of the chamber nor on the other. And, if it is, it is fairly evenly divided. Again, we will remind our front bench to try to cooperate and get as many questions up as possible. Some of the interjections we hear in Question Time are clever, witty, and make their point and some are very wounding, but loud grunts and groans from one or two people-a barrage from foghorn leghorn at the back here-are not helpful to the progress of this chamber. These interjections can be dealt with in several ways. They can be dealt with by a loud shout. I defy the whole lot of you to shout me down if I hit top key in terms of voice level, but that is not particularly desirable, especially when we are televised.

In summary, there is some substance in the point being made by Senator Kemp. I do not agree entirely with his analysis because I do not think that he recognises all the factors. But the Standing Committee on Procedure has looked at it and will keep it under review. I have enormous difficulty in accepting Senator Kemp's point. The President tries to be non-partisan. He is non-partisan in these matters. He tries to adjudicate. To try to adjudicate on relevance is very difficult. How can a President know the substance of every policy area covered here and know whether it is still relevant?

It is very hard to know at which point of answering a question it becomes debating or simply an embroidering of the answer, which leads me to the final point. Questions may have to be standardised. If questions are poorly based with misassumptions in them, why can the Minister not debate them? I do not see an answer forthcoming immediately. I, as Manager of Government Business, do not mind reminding all the Ministers that a notional figure of 24-odd questions a day, including supplementaries, would be desirable. It would be nice if some people did not come into this chamber with a supplementary question already written out. Some do it with a bit of dash and elan; others get up and ask a supplementary question even though the question has been answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some of your side ask the same question; the same dorothy dixer.
—Hang on. I do not think Senator Ray was confining it to this side.
—Oh no. Of course we often have it. I remember a great time three years ago when the same dorothy went out to two different people, and one person was late.
—The second answer was good.

—I agree it was somewhat embarrassing. I do not think it is absolutely necessary. When my side misses a question my colleagues here have the job of making sure they get one later. I never panic about that. So we get two in a row. So what?
—It happened today.

—It happened today. I do not care about that particularly. Maybe some on our side take too seriously the fact that we have to get every alternate question. There have been occasions when we have been short. It has been a poor day and when the clock has gone off I have said to Senator Button, `Give the Opposition one more'. It has happened a few times. I do not think that the Opposition ever recognises that, but it happens occasionally.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyway, it is time to go home. But this area could be improved and the improvement could come from both sides of the chamber. If anything, the people who are not here are the ones who ask the worst questions in terms of length. They have obviously already gone home.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.53 p.m.
